  Sea Bass w/Drunken Noodle - Lightly crispy on the outside and super flaky on the inside. Paired very well with the noodles and the flavors were well balanced. Worth trying, but definitely small for the price ($30 I think?). I'll be trying something else next time.
  Crispy Duck w/Panang - Very yummy! You get to choose your spiciness level from 1-10 so I got 8. The spiciness wasn't spaced out very evenly, as the first couple of scoops of sauce/duck were very spicy and the last few bits weren't spicy at all. The sauce was delicious with rice, but I think I'll try the dish with mint and chili instead. I feel like the sauce made the duck less crispy. 

AMBIANCE
Looks very unassuming from the outside. You would never know that such a great restaurant was located inside an old plaza like this. The restaurant itself is pretty large as they bought out the space next door and expanded. They even have a wine cabinet/wall displayed with TONS of wine to choose from. Everything from the decor to the music is pretty Asian/traditional.

SERVICE
Monday lunch service was super quick and our food came out within 5 minutes of ordering! The servers are also very knowledgeable and gave us some good recommendations.

OVERALL
Definitely coming here again! I'm so glad we were able to stop by, especially at a good time and with no wait! Even if you've never tried or don't care for Thai food, I still recommend trying this place. The quality of food is something I've never seen at any Asian-owned restaurant.

I almost hesitate in recommending this place because I know it just makes it harder to get a table there.  However, it is no secret.  This restaurant has won national acclaim for its authentic Thai cuisine.  What the restaurant lacks in ambience and location it more than makes up for in food quality and menu.  Extensive selection of Northern/Southern Thai dishes and an impressive wine cellar.  Garlic prawns are amazing, as are whole fish dishes of various preparations.  Spice levels go from 1 (mild) to 10 (hot) and Thai spicy (beyond hot).  Go with a large group and enjoy many different dishes to share.  Reservations are difficult.  If you can't get one, go at 5:00 and wait outside the restaurant.  Most likely you can get a table right when the restaurant opens at 5:30 for dinner.

I always come to Lotus of Siam when in Vegas. It's simply delicious! I've had the drunken noodles (very good), duck (yum), but my favorite is the Khao Soi with shrimp. It's magnificent!! It's a difficult dish to find in other Thai restaurants. The service is fast. I always make a reservation as soon as I book my hotel.

I am not sure how I have managed to live in Vegas my whole life with the exception of my college years and have never eaten at Lotus until late 2014. My first time coming the line was out of the door and there was an hour and half wait. I waited cause I figured it had to be good to have all of these people waiting and taxi after taxi dropping people off. The walls are covered with numerous pictures and accolades which is always a good sign as well. The location is definitely in a shady area but well worth the trip. My favorites are the crab fried rice garlic shrimp prawns black pepper chicken shrimp chow mein and bacon wrapped prawns. The service is good as well I've only had bad service one time at this restaurant. But it is definitely the best Thai restaurant in Vegas!!!!

I ate the crispy duck in Panang sauce and briefly went to a utopian heaven where everything is always right, and delicious, and beautiful. I can't get over it, I think about it all the time.
 
Find your way to this oasis of exquisite food in the middle of the desert that is Las Vegas. The duck is perfectly fried, and the flavors in the sauce are perfectly balanced. I got it at a 6/10 on the spicy scale, and it can be taken up a notch but do not overdo it to be able to appreciate the other subtle flavors.
 
We were told that the wait for 2, without a reservation would be 45 mins. Grabbed a glass of wine from their extensive list and sat in the backroom. We got a table within 20-25 mins, worth the wait. Don't be disheartened when you see a line of people outside. Also, there are plenty of cabs there to go back to your hotel on the strip.

I came back again and got the crispy duck- OMG SO GOOD!!!!!! The duck is cooked perfectly - MUST GET THIS DISH. I think it's the best one.


In Summary
- Note the store hours, they are closed in between lunch and dinner
-Cab ride from airport is about 44 and it is also impossible to get a cab back- have to call
-Order CRISPY DUCK, CHICKEN PAD THAI, CURRY ROAST DUCK  
Bonus: garlic prawns are pretty good too
- Warning: You will have dreams about this place and coming back....I miss it :(

I can't believe I have lived In vegas for over 8 years and just got around to trying this place. By far the best Thai restaurant I have ever been to. The food is so flavorful and stimulating to the palate. We ordered many different things and all were great. I'm sure there is something on the menu for everyone. Next time I will be trying the whole fried catfish with garlic and red chilies. The people next to us ordered it and it looked so yummy with a beautiful presentation. Now this place is in the ghetto ghost town part of vegas, the place looks worn down and outdated inside and out BUT who cares as long as the food is as tasty as it is. I also happened to love the owner of this restaurant. An older women who is involved in every aspect of her restaurant. I loved the way she would step out of the kitchen to check to see if everyone was enjoying the food and atmosphere. I even saw her washing drinking glasses, now that is one humble lady. I'm also assuming she has not opened another location due to the fact that she can't be at two places at the same time! Asian business lady, I salute you! You have accomplished so much to where it's said to be rated the best Thai restaurant in the USA.

I chose this spot for my employee Christmas dinner  this year. We had about 20 people and I made a reservation a couple weeks in advance as I heard that this place is really popular. It was great! The atmosphere was fun and lively and all of my friends had a great time. The wine list was absolutely amazing! They had something like 500 varieties of wine! The best of all was the food! It was delicious! We ordered Tom Kai soup, pad thai noodles, basil chicken, fried rice and a bunch of appetizers. I can honestly say this is the best Thai food I've had in Vegas. If you want to eat here make sure you make a reservation because there is typically a line out the door before they even open for dinner!

I do not know what you people are talking about when rating this restaurant higher than a two star. My wife and I had lunch several weeks ago at Lotus and wife ordered the Prawns that everyone raves about...yuc! She could not tell the prawn from the tail it was so stuck together. I ordered the duck since so many people were raving about it. Thought I was going to be sick! Worse meal we had on our three week trip. Do not go!!!

I feel like every Thai restaurant I've been to, the food was always decent to good. I would never say " out of this world' until I came here. It was a Friday night and we were seated right away when we got there ( no wait time, how cool is that?!) but maybe we were lucky. The ambiance isn't all that great but the delicious food makes up for the lack of decor. Anyone that thinks they've tried the best Thai food has to come here. My boyfriend and I shared the fried chicken with garlic appetizer. It came with about 7 pieces and they were all super crunchy and juicy on the inside with just the right amount of flavor from the garlic spices. For our main dish, I ordered the short rib curry noodles for my boyfriend and the pad-see-ew for myself. My favorite was the short rib curry noodles. I thought it would've tasted weird adding curry to noodles but the noodles were flat and light that it went well with the thick soupy sauce. The short rib was just so tender and it fell off my fork because the meat was so soft. I would definitely come here again the next time I come to Vegas. It's not on the strip ( probably about 3 miles off ) but so many people go there that there are taxis going back and forth from the restaurant to the strip. If you're planning on drinking, taking a taxi would be a smart idea.

I found Lotus of Siam in Zagat's list of top rated restaurants in Las Vegas. A quick lookup on Yelp showed that it had a pretty good rating with 2000+ reviews so I decided to try it when I was in Vegas a couple of days ago. We tried calling them at around 7 pm to make a reservation but could not get through as their phone was constantly busy. We decided to take a chance and landed up at around 8:30 pm. To my surprise I found that Lotus of Siam was located next door to the now defunct Namaste Indian Cuisine a place that I had been too many times when it was open. Anyway even on a Monday evening they were completely packed and had a wait time of 45 minutes which stretched to almost an hour before we were seated. The restaurant is not very big but is a decent sized place that does not feel too cramped.

As there was only 30 minutes to closing we ordered a bunch of standard Thai dishes all at once like Crispy Fried Garlic prawns ($26.95), Pad se-ew ($9.95), Red Curry with shrimp ($13.95), Penang Curry with chicken (12.95), Combo fried rice ($11.95), Crab fried rice ($13.95) and Khoa Soi (10.95). Food was out in another 10 minutes so apart from the long wait to get a table service is pretty fast. I approached the food with a lot of skepticism as I've been burned too many times by these super hyped up places but after the first couple of bites it was clear that Lotus of Siam was legit and completely deserving of its high rating. The crispy fried garlic prawns were amazing, lightly battered, perfectly fried with a balanced taste that did not overpower the delicate crustacean. The pad se-ew was perfectly cooked noodles with just a mild sweet tang. Literally one of the best that I've had. The crab fried rice was another gem. Perfect taste without even a hint of the smell of crab. The Penang curry was also great. The noodles in the Khoa Soi were a little overcooked and hence were clumped together while the curry base was a little too watery so I thought that the dish did not come together very well. Taste-wise I thought that it had a good balance of sweet and spice, but most people in our group felt that it was too spicy for them. The red curry was not bad, just that it tasted very similar to the Penang curry. 

I felt that prices at Lotus of Siam were less than what you would pay at other similar Thai places but when compared with the inflated prices on the strip they seemed out-rightly cheap. Considering the overall package of service, cost and quality the only drawback that I can think about is the long wait to get a table. I'm almost tempted to deduct a star for just that, as it could seriously keep me from returning, but I'm going to overlook it and give them the rating that they deserve.

I guess maybe my expectations were too high? Perhaps I was too hyped on all the hype. The only things I found to be impressive were the service and the wine. We ordered a bottle of burgundy style Pinot noir that was heavenly. We arrived on time for out reservation and were seated and greeted promptly. *Be on time or they will give your table away if you're later than five min*. 

The wine list... Insane. Pages and pages of wine... Unbelievable. I definitely would recommend ordering a bottle, considering the price per glass. Once you taste the food, you will definitely understand why. 

The service was wonderful. We never ran out of water and there was someone constantly checking on us. I love that. 

The ambiance... Way way way too bright. I felt like I was in a hospital. The lights... Just too much. No table decor. No candles. Paper placemats. The decor was really dated. And considering their extensive wine list, I was expecting more umph. But it was okay. 

The food... Left so much to be desired. We had a jack fruit vegetable curry. It was more like overly spiced watery vegetable soup. We usually order a 7 or 8 in spice. We love heat. The 7 was almost un edible. Beware. The curry wasn't sweet at all... Just really really watery and hot. I'm not use to this style of Thai and obviously not a fan. The rice... It was good, but they gave one small bowl for the four of us. We order three meals. (Our friends were not impressed either). The price of the food is fitting for the ambiance. Will I return? Maybe for a birthday, but never on my own. We will stick to komol (same shopping center). They have the style of Thai I prefer apparently... And their food is just... It's so good. 

Give this place a shot and form
Your own judgments though. Happy yelping.

I had somewhat of mixed expectations of this restaurant as several friends/colleagues have raved about their dishes, namely the garlic prawns (fried version) and the duck panang; and others have not enjoyed it.

My SO made reservations here for 7:30 PM, which I'm glad we did, because we were seated immediately. There were groups of folks waiting by the door, and I overheard the host tell a party that the wait would be at least an hour and 30. yikes.

At the servers recommendation, we ordered the Tom Kha soup (he asked how spicy we wanted it on a scale from 1-10). The soup was okay- we ended up mostly pouring it over the white rice.

We also ordered the fried garlic prawns-- right below this dish on the menu, there is a fried garlic prawns with drunken noodles- and that is not the same thing. The server said they use different seasoning for the prawns. I was disappointed by this dish, as I felt it salty and underwhelming. We ended up eating only a couple pieces.

I was deciding between the poached salmon and sea bass- server highly recommended the sea bass so I ordered it with the ginger sauce. The steamed sea bass was very buttery and so good! I would definitely re-order this dish if I come back.

Although I did not enjoy their most popular dish, I would come back to order other dishes and the sea bass. The entrees came out rather quickly (less than 10 minutes) and the service was great.

I hadn't been here in years, other than getting the occasional buffet lunch.  Four of us set out to try some of their signature dishes, and we are now HOOKED!  We started with a glass of wine at the bar - by the way they are a Wine Spectator Restaurant Award winner.

My sister and I decided we would make it a tradition to try the chicken wings at any restaurant that offered them, and what a wonderful tradition it is!  The Spicy Chicken Wings were wonderful, with a slightly sweet yet complex flavor of chili with hints of basil.  We also chose Nam Kao Tod as an appetizer - we'll definitely do this one again!  The crispy rice was a wonderful texture with the meat and ginger sauce.

We were feeling adventurous and decided to try the who deep fried catfish.  There are 3 kinds, and we tried the Plar Dook O-Cha.  I swear this was the best catfish I've ever had.  Hands down.  It was cooked perfectly, juicy and tender.  The slaw-like vegetables on top had a hint of sweetness, and they paired perfectly with the fish and the Reisling we had with dinner.

The guys picked out a Northern Thai dish that I can't remember - all I know is that it was very, very good.

This is definitely on our go-to list to try again and again!

I have been eating at Lotus of Siam since 2006 and the food is awesome, but they have become a victim of their own success. They expanded their seating capacity but not their kitchen and it shows. I'm writing this after waiting over 40 minutes for my food and watching people walk out the door, giving up after waiting too long for their food...very sad. I also noticed the food portions are smaller than before. Breaks my heart as this one of my favorites in Las Vegas. If you decide to eat here, ask for Tony, he is the best.

I have been here 7 times and each time has been an amazing experience. 

Today however was not so great. 

I brought 3 co workers in for dinner after work and was so excited to have them experience the awesomeness that is Lotus of Siam. 

The bar tender had me try a drink that she said was similar to sparkling blueberry sake. It wasnt. It was like lemoncello. It was good so I offered to buy my co workers each a glass of it. The bar tender told me to buy the bottle and said its a good deal. It was $70.00. She didnt even tell me ahead of time. This wasnt a huge deal because I did like the taste a lot.

Then I ordered Nan Mao Tod and asked for it to not be Spivey. It came out with 4 Thai chili's in what equaled about 2 cups of rice. Crazy spicey. When I mentioned it to the waiter he didnt react at all other than to walk away.   This wasnt right as my mouth was on fire. I order this dish everytime by the way and its the main reason I come here. Couldn't even eat it.

I also order the rad Nah. It was good but very few noodles and mostly gravy. 

The pad see we was delicious though. Highly recommend it. 

Once we finished our food. We were finishing our drinks and our waiter asked us to hurry up and leave so he could have our table. It was between 5 and 10 minutes. I dont find this to be an excessive amount of time.
I have been there many times. Despite the long wait times, now they even automatically add 18% gratuity for part of 4... And the service is bad, rushing you to finish your food...

I have been wanting to try this place for a long time and finally got the chance to! I'm so happy I did. All the food is super fresh and has a very rich authentic Thai taste. I've tried a lot of Thai restaurants but the taste of food here tastes a bit different, in a really delicious way! Try their Tom Kah Kai soup, it's sooooo mmmmm good!!

I haven't eaten here in a few years but I can see from the reviews that it is still the best place to eat in Las Vegas. We are here for lunch during the week the first time and you never know who you will be eating with because it is a locals favorite.

I know I've reviewed this place before, but it was so long ago that another review had to be merited. Besides, soft shell crab pad kee mao is good, but in terms of actual exoticness it's not really all that exotic.

The big problem is two-fold because I'm almost never here on a weekday. They only do lunch on weekdays, and I'm not dealing with that line for dinner time (and let's be honest, no one actually plans dinner in Vegas if you're gonna go out). EXCEPT LAST TIME I WAS HERE ON FRIDAY AT NOON. Sorry Tacos El Gordo, I love you much but my lunch choice that day was not a hard decision to make.

The reason you go to lunch is simple...you walk in with zero wait. At least that's what's happened the only two times I've been here! And the thing about Lotus is this...it is unquestionably the best Thai restaurant in the city of Las Vegas and arguably the best in the entire country. So you don't go in there with the intention of getting the basic options. Unless for some reason you are a basic person, in which case I hope the gods have mercy on your soul.

My "get all the options you can't get anywhere else" principle truly applies here. My friends were just like...dude, have at it, we trust you. Well, here's the list:

1. Crispy duck with penang curry: OMG IT'S THE BEST!
2. Soft shell crab pad kee mao (again): I know it's a tad basic, but hey it was really good last time. Besides, you don't really see soft shell crab on pad kee mao anywhere else...so don't judge me! Next time though...sea bass pad kee mao. Because of this next item.
3. Sea bass with chili sauce: Anyone that knows me knows I'm the biggest sea bass homer there is. This was so freaking good!
4. Chicken pad thai: Ok fine we got the most basic thing you can possible get. But that's because my friend says it's his favorite dish to cook and he wants to see how every restaurant cooks it since it's always different depending on the cook. He approves!

Yeah, everyone was satisfied. I think I know a thing or two about decent Thai food options here lol. And the great thing is that because the menu is so ridiculously deep, I could come here 5 times and never order the same combination of items. 

Only problem is actually finding time to come here again. I ain't trying to mess with that weekend line bruh.

I love Lotus of Siam!  We usually order off of the special list at the back of the menu, but there's only so much stomach room and we usually order the same thing over and over.

1.  Any red curry dish on the specials page (short rib, duck, etc.)
2.  Tom Yum Goong soup
3.  Mango Sticky Rice (dessert)
4.  Pad Thai (random, but its a little different here)

MUST MAKE RESERVATIONS ahead of time.  The only way around this (if you don't want to wait forever) is to go right before they open, so you'll get seated right away. 

Oh yeah, and they aren't shy about the spicy level, so if you ask for a 10, you better be prepared!  We like spicy and usually just go a little higher than what the dish is normally. 

Good luck and happy ordering!

I love it. The charbroiled prawns were amazing, even with mouth on fire from the chilis (we got the spicy ones). Definitely order some of the northern Thai dishes the place is known for.  The only thing we got that was just average was the Drunken Noodles - I've had better elsewhere.  But even they were devoured by the end of the meal.  I will make this a must-eat on Vegas trips!
I love their soups and curries!

I love this place ! Do not let the plaza fool you, this place is a hidden gem. 

Here is what I ordered for a party of four: 
1. Crispy garlic Pawn: OMG, I don't need to say much. You just have to order it !
2. Soft shell crab drunken noodles: they definitely know to flavor well.
3. Crispy duck penang- The highlight of our lunch. We can see why everyone rave about this dish. 
4. Coconut soup #23 on the menu: it's good but I wouldn't order it again. I couldn't finish my bowl, maybe I don't like coconut milk in my soup. 

 I love their thai tea as well. Wish there is a location near home.

I love this place. Delicious food and such great flavors. I went for dinner since there were some negative reviews for their lunch buffet and I am not disappointed. We ordered the garlic prawns, a south Thai beef noodle dish and Chilean sea bass flat noodles. Even though we weren't hungry from our other food destinations, we demolished everything. I wished I had ordered the garlic prawns just for myself because it was unsightly of me to stab others in the hand with my fork as we fought for the last piece. The shrimp is fried so well and smart. By that I mean that they actually separate the meat from the shell so that the shell comes out like shrimp chips. One of the reasons I will be coming back to Vegas is so that I can come back to eat here again.

I love this restaurant - the food is amazing - the best in Las Vegas.
 It is in a bad neighborhood and the outside is no frills - but I think that adds to its charm -the food is absolutely incredible.
 Make reservations and arrive early - they will give away your table if you are 5-minutes late because of demand.  They are always crowded.
it is about $25 cab ride off the strip - $50 round-trip, so good thing the food is reasonably priced.

I really wanted to love this place because Lawd knows I love love love Thai food!  This was dubbed as The Best Thai Restaurant in America (even the concierge at The Palazzo raved about this place) by Food Network, but alas! FN has failed me again. 

First, it's in a seedy area in Vegas.  Second, for a very 'famous' place, the waiting area barely fit 6 people.  It's hot in Vegas! Waiting outside feels like waiting in an oven.  Third, everything is wayyyy overpriced.  $25 for 4 pieces of mid-sized prawns.  Those prawns tasted superb but geez! 4 pieces?  Fourth, the service is mediocre.  They took forever to acknowledge us after we sat down and for drink refills.  

Other than the crispy fried prawns, the rest of our meal were just ok.  We ordered Pad Thai with shrimp& chicken (this is how we test new Thai restos we try, if you can't do this impressively then you fail as a Thai resto), Thai fried rice, and two other dishes I don't even remember (one was fish and the other was sautéed seafood with vegetables).  Our bill totaled way over $150.  $150 for 'just ok' is unacceptable.  

Compared to our fave Thai resto in San Francisco, this place is no match.  Like I said, I really wanted to like this place but as much as the chefs in FN and the concierge raved about it, it's just not that impressive.   

The two stars is just for the crispy garlic prawns!

I think everyhing I have to say has aleady been said. In a nutshell:
make a reservation and arrive 15 minutes early; be careful in the creepy, ghetto parking lot (I was approached by two old people on bikes asking for money); order the prawns and duck Panang and be make sure you ask about their spice levels! 

I've only had water here but their wine list is very extensive.

My only regret is that I ate most of my curry and was pnly able to have two prawns. I took them back to my hotel and had another 2 in the morning. They were still good then, but it hurt to have to leave the rest behind.

I was a bit skeptical leaving The Strip and coming to a deserted parking lot at about 9:00 pm.  I was blown away by the groups of people waiting by the entrance door of the restaurant.  We made out way past the people and found even more inside the waiting area.  We managed to put our names down on the wait list, and the hostess said it would be a thirty minute wait.  We decided we would leave, explore outside, and then come back later.  

Don't judge us for what we decided to do next.  Just a few steps away was a massage parlor.  The GF and I decided to treat ourselves with a thirty minute foot massage.  I wonder if the massage place gives the restaurant a cut of the profits, since I can imagine a lot of the customers also eat there.  The massage was not that great, but that is another review for a different day.  

We came back to the restaurant seven minutes after they had called, informing us that our table was ready.  We were seated fairly close to the entrance, next to a secluded room.  The interior of the dining establishment looked quite remarkable.  Everything looked new, and well maintained.  The exterior was very  misleading.  You would never expect to see such grand chandeliers, a vast wine selection, and well kept furniture.  

We decided to order the fried wontons to start, thai fried rice and khao soi for our main course, and for dessert, we had the fried bananas with coconut ice cream.  The fried wontons were just okay tasting.  I enjoyed their homemade sweet and sour sauce.  As for the wonton , they were a tad overcooked, causing them to dry out. The skin to meat ratio was disproportionate. This was the only item that I felt was not worth the price.  

We ordered the thai fried rice without tomatoes, and with a fried egg on top.  Our server even repeated all the items we ordered back to us.  Somewhere along the way, this was not communicated to the kitchen.  Not surprisingly, there were tomatoes everywhere!  So, we sent it back, and hopefully there was no spit in the new one we received.  I am almost positive they used the same egg from our old one because it was only room temperature.  Overall, the thai fried rice was delicious and the egg was cooked perfectly.  With the slide of the knife, the yolk oozed everywhere.  

The khao soi was definitely the star of our meal.  Be warned that a 6 is super spicy.  You get to choose the spiciness level from 1-10.  It was so good though.  The curry broth had so much explosive flavor.  The noodles were cooked perfectly, and all the ingredients inside the bowl complimented each other perfectly.  My favorite part of the dish was the coconut curry, hands down.  

For dessert, there are three options.  They are ice cream, fried bananas, and mango sticky rice.  We decided to get the ice cream AND fried bananas, which are two desserts.  I have to admit, I have not ever seen fried bananas served without ice cream.  It was surprising that people order it by itself.  When it finally arrived, we were already so full.  I wish there was more ice cream to go with the bananas.  We finished the ice cream with about four more banana pieces left.  

Overall, a very good dining experience.  It was quite nice to get away from The Strip.  Out of the less than ten times I have been to Vegas, this was my first time eating outside  casinos and away from the gambling addicts.  It was a pleasant experience, and I can see why this place is doing so well.

I was back in Vegas for a one-night business trip.  Couldn't help stopping by Lotus of Siam for the amazing garlic prawns (now up to $26).  I also had the Thai beef salad, which was terrific.  Based on two visits while in Vegas, I'd say their top dishes are tops, but some of their other dishes are no better than and simply on par with other great Thai restaurants.  Their style feels a little heavier than some places I've been to in Los Angeles Thai Town, but their great dishes are very tasty indeed!

They are a busy restaurant, and service is good, not great.  It takes a while for the waiters to come take your order.

I was ecstatic to try this place after seeing Anthony Bourdain dined here.

The hype is real. I love Thai food, but the options here are more unique and the menu is extensive!

The Drunken Noodles Topped with Duck and the Pepper Fried Prawns were amazingly delicious. Everything was piping hot, fresh, and super flavorful.. not just slabbed in sauce or deep fried in batter.

Overall, I would say this place is optimal for larger parties, ideally 4-6 people. We had 10+ people and it was great ordering dozens of dishes and sharing family style. But, I would imagine for a pair - it would be more challenging to try all the variety of dishes!

Inexpensive and absolutely worth it!

I was in Vegas for a business trip and my co-worker had been here before and I love Thai, so we made a reservation and went. It was absolutely delicious (and FREE on the company!). We got Prawns in a Blanket-- absolute must-try!, Beef in Tamarind sauce (also great), green curry, and a rice dish (I forgot which one, unfortunately). Service was great, atmosphere was chatty, but not too loud where we were seated, and I was surprised at how affordable it all was, although it's worth splurging a little in order to try lots of different things. If I visit LV again, I will definitely come here again! Definitely need reservations, though.

I went here after a long day.  Now, the outside of the place, parking lot and surrounding areas are less than desirable.  However, the inside was a stark contrast.  It was very nice, bright and very clean.  I would definitely make a reservation.  The food was really good and tasty.  We had the Pad thai, Garlic Prawns, combination fried rice and beef pad prig king.  The beef was awesome.  Very good flavor and just the right amount of heat.  The worst dish was the fried rice but most Thai places don't make fried rice that well so it was not a deal breaker...the wait staff was very good and efficient...overall a very good meal was had

I went here after watching Bourdain's episode on Vegas and I wasn't disappointed. The golden fried garlic prawns in particular were incredible. We went here at 1pm on a Thursday and the place was packed with locals. We had the nam prik ong, the crispy rice rice salad, the jackfruit vegetable curry, golden fried prawns and the house special fried rice and another item that Bourdain ate (don't remember it now)  Everythign was great. I'd recommend to not get the crispy rice salad to go, because...well.. it doesnt stay crispy.

I went with a reservation of 17 people. They were very accommodating, seeing how they are always booked to capacity. The food was great. The only issue we had with this place is that we didn't get our fish dishes. We ended up canceling it because it took too long, everything else had came out and we were already full. According to the waitstaff it was ok to cancel because they didn't start cooking it yet. What's up with that? Yes, I don't except everything to be perfect when you have a party of 17 but at least the fish should have started to be prepped or something. 
All and all good experience, food was great, service was great, will be back when in town.

I would definitely come back to this place when I'll go in LV again. Everything was delicious but the garlic prawns at the end (we took them as a desert lol) were outstanding! Note that the place opens about 5:30pm and make sure you are there 20min/half hour in advance to get to the first seating. Yes it is crowded!

I would give this a five if they narrowed the menu down to their best selection. The wait is killer, but worth it. Service is always great. The garlic shrimp is something you might not want to share. It's really good. Crispy fried, garlicky salt sweetness actually makes the shell into a chip like snack almost. Everything else pales in comparison. I recommend sticking with the classic salads, pad thai and tom yum soup. I once or twice I veered off course and was a little disappointed. The curry without coconut milk tasted like a tom yum soup. I probably wouldn't be disappointed if they called it a soup rather than a curry. Their beef soup is more or less flavored for the white man's taste buds. Considering two people can only eat so much, I wish I tried something else. It was like a very sweet pho. Overall, my experience was great and I wish I could trust Yelp reviews on what to order, but everyone has different preferences.

I'm a Vegas native, and why it took me so long to eat here - I don't know. It is wonderful! 

My cousin came into town and requested we go here. She had heard nothing but great things and boy was she right!

The service was great. The hostess was super friendly. Our server was so on top of things. He provided great recommendations since some of us are vegetarians and others at our table were not. The eggplant was delicious!

I will for sure go back and definitely would recommend.

I'm a foodie that loves Thai food. I've eaten at many Thai restaurants. This is without a doubt, the BEST Thai food I've ever eaten! And prices were very reasonable. This place is a hidden gem and I will be coming back every time I visit Vegas.

I'm kinda teetering on what to rate this restaurant.  I've read a lot that this is the 'best Thai resto in the USA' and I'm really not sure.  I can't say I know everything about Thai food, but it's one of my favourite cuisines and I've been to Thailand in the last few months to know really good Thai food. 

We went with a group of five so we were able to order a bunch of dishes and share family style.  We started off with a hot pot of tom kah kai soup ($15) which was nice.  It was lemongrass-y with mushrooms and chicken in it.  Nice start to lunch.  Aside from the soup we ordered pad thai ($11), papaya salad ($9), crispy duck penang ($23), and garlic prawns ($24), and thai iced tea for me ($2.50).

The superstar of the afternoon was definitely the crispy duck penang!  I will order it again and again every time in the future.  The portion was not huge for a $23 dish but definitely worth it in flavours.  I could eat the sauce it comes with, with anything.  Second superstar were the garlic prawns.  A big platter of butterfly'd prawns that were extra crispy with lots of super goodness to it!!

I know pad thai is pad thai - everyone orders it at a Thai resto and probably shouldn't be ordered in an 'authentic' place like this.  We should have listened.  I didn't like the pad thai and thought it was too tomato-y for me.  The papaya salad was nothing special either - was pretty basic.  It was also made a little too spicy for our mild request.  The thai iced tea was spot on though!!  Tasted just like the ones I ordered off the streets in Bangkok!

I would give this place 3/5 because I literally just had some amazing food in Thailand a couple months ago so my standard is pretty high, and half of the stuff I wouldn't order again.  But service was pretty good, there was no line-up when we went for lunch on a Friday afternoon, and I really loooove a good thai iced tea.  I'll be back.

I'm so happy I got a chance to eat here. The restaurant is tucked away in a strip mall off of the strip and isn't much to look at. When you get inside at first it looks like your typical Thai place. Then you take a moment and realize the walls are covered with celebrity chef pictures who have been to this place. You then notice the very impressive wine collection. The place is also consistantly packed. Now to the food it was literally a party in our mouths. The food was so incredibly flavorful and bright. It was hands down the best Thai food I have ever had and will make a point to come back every time I'm in Vegas.  I highly recommend this place to anyone. The service was also very quick and attentive.
I've been coming to this place for years. It has a wonderful ambiance. The food is delicious and the service is wonderful.

I've been dying to visit and finally made it last weekend.  We were lucky to get the last seating of the night.  So you primarily come for the food and to see what all the Bourdain hype is about.  We shared a bunch of different things everything was delicious - pad thai, crispy duck in curry, fried shrimp, crab fried rice, and maybe 1 other meat dish which was good.  

Prices are reasonable, and service is good.

I've been here twice before, and was there again recently. It gets pretty packed, but for good reason. The food is absolutely delicious. There is an extensive menu ranging from vegetarian dishes to wild dishes such as trout, deer and even frog. Service is always great, but no 5 star since wait time to get seated is sometimes beyond long. Last time i waited over 2 hours to get seated....

I've been meaning to sign up for Yelp for a while, but my experience at Lotus of Siam made it happen. I lived in Thailand for about 7 months including Chiang Mai (where I found out the owner is from) for 3. I've never tasted Thai food in America that comes close to the street food out there, until I tried Lotus of Siam. 

We got the Khao Soi, Tom Yum Gai, Pad Thai, and Panang Curry. Everything was perfect. It's as authentic as it gets, which I can see turning off some people who are used to Americanized Thai food, but everyone in our group loved it. The soup was the perfect balance of sour and spicy. Khao Soi is one of my favorite foods and I don't remember the last time I saw it on a menu - Lotus of Siam did it perfectly. The Pad Thai and Curry were great too.

Prices were reasonable for the quality and they had a surprisingly good beer selection (at a great price for craft beers). Our waitress and the rest of the staff were very friendly. It was one of the best restaurant experiences I've had in a while. If I lived in Vegas I'd eat here multiple times per week. Only downside is you need a car or a long taxi ride to get there, and while the place was beautifully decorated, the boxes of wine stored behind the glass didn't look great in an otherwise impressive display. That is a very minor issue that I probably only notice because I work in the industry. There seem to be a lot of Thai places in Vegas but this should definitely be the one to try.

I've eaten at all of the major restaurants in town and this is still the only one that is a "must have" for me if I only have 1 meal in Vegas. It's a true gem and no one I've ever taken here has ever been disappointed which I can't say for the likes of Guy Savoy. The two standouts are the Tom Kom Gai soup and the mango and sticky rice dessert!

I've eaten at this local gem a million times & it is great each visit. The restaurant is pretty & service is always great. The location is a little sketchy in a strip mall but the food speaks for itself. Must visit if you love good thai food.
The soups are all good as well. The service has always been good, and attentive. Overall, Lotus Of Siam is among the better restaurants in Vegas, for quality of taste.. And, it's probably the best thai in the city as well. But, I must be honest. I've had better Thai in other places. So, to call this the best thai in the country is a bit of a stretch IMHO. But, many would argue, so I suggest to stop in and try it for yourself.

I've wanted to try this place for many years! I love Thai food. I also used to be able to handle the spice, but that still doesn't stop me from enjoying it. I finally got a chance to try this place with one of my favorite people Dyanna. Since it was her lunch break we went at 1pm because at lunch time there can be a line out the door. 

The outside building is run down, but the inside of Lotus is huge and very chic. I was surprised to find table linens and cloth napkins instead of paper. They have a huge wine cellar that greets you as you are being seated. The waiters and waitresses were also dressed up. Really made me feel fancy. 

Lotus of Siam's menu is huge! They have anything and everything you could ever want when it comes to Thai food. I love that they separate the menu by regions of Thailand. In the end I decided on one of my favorite Thai dishes Pad See Ew with shrimp. (I used to be able to handle spicy food, but since my sleeve surgery three months ago my stomach can't handle it.) So I ordered a spice level 1. Dyanna ordered the Baby Corn and I think she got a level 6 or 7. 

Our food came out super fast. I have to say they made the best Pad See Ew that I've ever had! Talk about flavor! Wow! It exploded in my mouth. The noodles where all perfectly coated in sauce and were cooked al dente. Plus, they had it loaded with tender sweet shrimp. Dyanna let me try her Baby Corn dish and it was really tasty too. (I'm a total sucker for baby corn.) 

Our waiters were so attentive. When we were done they took both our dishes and boxed them up for us. They also brought our check quickly. Which is always nice when your on a time crunch. 

What a great lunch! Wonderful company and some bomb Thai food. I seriously can not wait to go back. I've been telling Joel I have to take him there. He had my left over Pad See Ew cold, hours later and he loved it. If you are a fan of Thai food like I am this is a can't miss spot. I'm looking forward to trying all their other tasty items.

If I am in Vegas I have to stop by here. The best Thai food, hands down. Not only is it so good, the service is great and food comes out fast.

He must haves are the garlic prawns, tom yum kai soup, and crispy duck panang curry.

Make a reservation to avoid the lines.

If it weren't for yelp, we would've never found this place.  It's a really sketchy and deserted area of Vegas.  The food is terrific.  Came here with 5 others and ordered stuffed chicken wings, soft shell crab with drunken noodles, crispy duck with drunken noodles, pad thai, short rib, and garlic prawns.  Everything was delicious.  Definitely the best thai food I've ever had.  However, it's also the most expensive I've had and the portions were small.  My group friends all left their still feeling hungry, but we all thought the food was really good.
If you are looking for authentic Thai cuisine here in Vegas, this is the place to go. And they have an crazy wine list!

If you're going to venture off the strip for a single meal, make it this place. It's located in a seedy strip mall a mile or so from Fremont Street, but food-wise, competes with the best restaurants in Vegas. While everything we ate was delicious, the Tom Kah Kai soup, the Nam-Prik-Ong dish (spicy goodness with pork rinds) were the most memorable, and the Singha's washed down the Thai perfectly.

In my opinion one of the best Thai food restaurants in vegas. You can see that by how busy they are no matter what day or time you go in. The wait is usually not too bad as they get food out fast. The crispy duck is simply delicious. Most of the other dishes I have had here before were very good too. Prices are very good too unless you are getting seasonal fish. Overall highly recommended.

It has become a tradition of my fiance and I, to comeand eat here every single time we are in Vegas. The service and food is phenomenal. It's not a "cheap" thai restaurant. It's actually a bit expensive but worth every penny. The ingredients and quality of food is superb. 

You can even see all the celebrities and well known figures coming to the restaurant and their picture with the owner is on the wall. Even top chefs from all over the world come here to eat! It's seriously THAT good! We always get the prawns and sausage.suer tasty! I am a bit boting and I also get the pad see ew and thai tea but its so yummy, I just can't help myself. But they are more known for Northern Thai cuisine so I highly recommend you select their specialties instead.

It is far from where I normally habitate. It has been featured on Anthony Bourdain's show, which I think surely contributed to the hype. 
It's good food, definitely worth for you to come in and try. I hear a lot of government officials come in here, must be because of it's proximity to downtown I guess.. 
I must take a star away for the decor and ambiance,  in all honesty it is not a five star restaurant. 
I didn't think it was pricey at all.

It was a sketchy place as many have stated but great once you get in. The food was overall great. We were given  a recommendation for crispy rice and it was not good but the curry and the pad Thai was awesome. Made finitely recommend the restaurant!!

It's been a while since I went to Lotus of Siam.  I returned and noticed that they had expanded since the last time I was here.  They were on a wait due to a holiday and they took our name.  They told us we would receive a text when our table was ready and that it would be held for 15 minutes.  Great!  We don't have to wait around, we can go do stuff.  So we did.  And headed back.  As we pulled in, (15 minutes before the quoted time), we got the text.  Our table was ready.

The place was bustling and was busy.  The servers worked together as a team.  I tried the garlic prawns after reading several reviews.  They were good and I ate the fried shells as instructed by the reviews.  Not bad.  But there were a lot of shells that didn't  have meat in them.  That was slightly disappointing.  

We were happy with the service, although had to request water refills several times.  Definitely a place to take Thai food lovers.  Not a place to take my mom.  Her idea of exotic eating is Panda Express.  (Ok, maybe not really).  But then again, she doesn't like cilantro.
Just an unbelievable Panang Curry with Crispy Duck... Can't say enough about how great this place is. Ditch the strip; head here.
Just had lunch and was very disappointed. Wife had the garlic prawns. Did not have a lot of flavor and very expensive. I had the crispy duck. Not impressed. Way overpriced.

Just had the best meal. Sea Bass and drunken noodles. Garlic prawns and crab fried rice are all simply amazing. The flavors were all commentary and yet different. The perfect place to go with a small group because everything sounds and looks so delicious. You will want to order more. This place lives up to all the hype and awards.

Just love this place. 
Crispy Duck with Panang is arguably one of the best dishes I've had. Just so satisfying. The textures and flavor are amazing. For typical diners, stick with mild spicy. Don't kill your taste buds :)

LOVE this place. I've come here twice now and enjoyed everything I ate both times. I would definitely try to make a reservation or come during off hours because during those busy dinner hours (haven't tried going during lunch yet) this place gets PACKED and you'll have to wait a while. 

Basically, you should go ahead and try everything on the menu. I've had a lot of different dishes and they were all delicious. I would trust this place to make everything taste good, it's THAT good. 

One thing to beware, however, is if you can't eat spicy foods or you don't like pungent foods. Thai food generally has strong flavors because they use lots of herbs and spices and fish sauce pretty liberally. This place takes that to the next level. The flavors are very strong. Also, if you can't eat spicy foods, be careful here. I love spicy foods and prefer my food to be very very spicy (basically, the more it burns/hurts the better it tastes lol) and when we came here, even though we didn't ever specify spicy level, most of the foods came out pretty spicy. Their papaya salad was surprisingly very spicy. So just be careful. If you can't eat spicy, make sure to tell them that.

Like others, I came here expecting the best thai food in the country after seeing it on bourdain. I even ordered only northern Thai dishes, supposedly their specialty. The homemade sausage was okay, but everything else was very disappointing. This place is all hype. Will not be coming back.

LoS is unbelievable. Location is 100% sketchy but inside is one of the best restaurants I have ever dined.  Incredible food, reasonably priced and the absolute best wine program I have ever seen (rarely do I see a list fairly priced with such amazing small productions and great finds).

Had crispy duck in curry sauce. absolutely divine.

Absolutely blown away.

Located in a nondescript, strip mall, this restaurant has to be the best place for Thai food in all of Las Vegas, if not the country. And if you are looking for an incredible wine selection, look no further. Wow. From the rare, hard to find Bordeaux to your favorite California Zin - this place will have it! Family owned and run with a casual, homey ambiance, this restaurant allows you to focus on the food and wine - just as it should be!

Lotus is by far my favorite Thai restaurant.  When I was living in Las Vegas, I wouldn't want to go anywhere else for Thai, and when I did, I was disappointed.   This has been my preferred Thai restaurant for the last seven years.  Their best  dishes, in my opinion, are expressed through the Northern Thai selection on the menu.   It is their specialty.   My go to selection consist of the fried garlic prawns, steamed sea bass served over a bed of apples and grapes, in a peanut and fish sauce,  the seared scallops in a garlic sauce, and Tom Yum shrimp.  You really can't go wrong with anything on the menu, just be sure to specify the level of spiciness desired, or you'll tango with a mouth of fire! 

The restaurant itself is old and located in a less than desirable area.  I say it adds to the charm lol.  Make reservations!  Monday through Saturday this place is BUSY!  If you don't make the prior arrangements prepare to wait in line.  The staff is wonderful and very knowledgeable of the menu.  My favorite dishes have come from waitstaff suggestions.   I suggest going between 530 and 630 p.m or anytime after 830 p.m.  This is the less busiest time to dine in Lotus.   Consistency in flavor, texture, and presentation is slightly neglected when the restaurant gets slammed.

Lotus of Siam is considered by many to be the best and most authentic Thai food in America, and is a favorite of renowned chef Scott Conant. 

It's located on the north end of the Strip, and about a mile east. This makes for an easy cab ride. We made it there just before the lunch hours ended. That actually worked out well because it meant we had no wait time whatsoever. We decided to order several menu items and share, although it takes 10-15 minutes just to flip through the extensive menu. Everything sounded amazing, but we settled on the Issan Sausage, Kraphao Moo Krob, and Drunken Noodle Soft Shell Crab.

The Issan Sausage is their housemade grilled sour pork sausage (complete with a secret blend of ingredients), served with fresh chili, ginger, and peanuts. Delicious doesn't even begin to describe this dish. There were hints of sweetness and acidity throughout, and each bite was packed with flavor.

I also loved the Kraphao Moo Krob, which is stir-fried crispy pork belly with Thai basils, bell peppers, and minced dry and fresh chilis. The pork belly was spectacular, and the thai basil added a great dimension to the dish. I only wish there had been more of it.

The Drunken Noodle Soft Shell Crab is a deep-fried soft shell crab with homemade fresh chilis and Thai basil, served atop pan-fried flat rice noodles. We ordered the medium heat level, and that was just hot enough. It was very tasty, and I enjoyed the crispy crab coupled with the juicy noodles.

If you're looking for a fantastic lunch spot that won't break the bank, definitely try out Lotus of Siam.

Lotus of Siam is simply good but nothing special, particularly since it is so expensive for Thai food.

Lissa G and I wanted to try out Lotus for quite some time and we finally got a chance to stop by. We went for lunch and arrived shortly after they opened.  The inside is much larger than it looks from the outside. Be sure to get there early or expect a wait. After being seated we ordered some of the recommended dishes.

We asked for all of our dishes to be 7 out of 10 spice level. BTW...not high enough if you like it spicy.

Nam Prik Noom (Green Chili Dip)
The dip was an excellent start and made us excited for the next dishes.  It was the spiciest dish we had and it could be explained as a chucky Thai salsa. The crunchy pork skins and vegies to dip were perfect for the dish, especially if you are trying to stay away from carbs.

Nam Kao Tod (Crispy Rice)
Ok this dish was pretty addicting. Basically crunchy rice with all the typical great Thai flavors. A must get.

Very excited at this point...
but unfortunately down hill from here.

Garlic Prawns
Very disappointing especially for $24. The ingredient's quality and portion size was well worth the price but the flavor and preparation was lacking. You could tell the oil the prawns were cooked in was not hot enough since they just weren't crispy enough to eat the shells, and we LOVE eating shrimp shells and all. The prawn were also lacking any flavor besides fried prawn.

Panang Beef
Basic dish which was mediocre even compared to our local hole in the wall Thai restaurant we go to locally.  Also, not spicy at all at level 7. Again disappointment.

Sometimes it depends which dishes you get a restaurant and that may me the case for us. You will not have a bad meal here but temper your expectations if you had good Thai elsewhere like in LA or SF.

Lotus of Siam lives up to the hype! It's busy and is quite a wait, but well worth it. I ordered the prawns for an appetizer and the roasted duck curry for my entree. Sooooo goood! Definitely my go to place in Vegas for Thai food. I can't wait to go back and try more!

Lotus of Siam never fails. Located in a nondescript shopping center a mile or so from the strip, LoS has become a staple for every Vegas visit. Personally, I love their spring rolls and their Panang curry- perhaps the best Thai I've had in the U.S.! Prepare to wait if arriving during peak hours- also be advised that their spice scale (1-10) climbs very quickly!

Love this place!!!  Great curry!  We thought it would be a 45 minute wait for dinner and were seated within 15 minutes.  Really good service and fantastic food.  Have been here a number of times and every experience there has been consistent and enjoyable in every aspect.
Love this place. My friends and I waited 45 min before opening just to get a head start since there were no more reservations available. Group of 12, got right in. Well worth the wait!!!

Love this thai food!! Whenever I eat thai food everywhere Me & my husband alway order the same food..Pad see ew & curry ( red,yellow,penang).. The first time I ate at Lotus siam 2012..I really like their food & always go there whenever we want eat thai food.4 months ago we went to Nothern thailand & try their traditional food 'Kao soi kai' & we love it. So when we came back to vegas & eat at my favorite thai place 'Lotus siam', I saw they have 'Kao soi kai'.. It's really good & authentic, the flavor is really balance.. So GOOD!! Long short story..all the food I try there really GOOD!! (Kao soi kai,beef pad see ew,beef pad thai, shrimp drunken noodle,red curry,yellow curry,beef penang) you should try it so you know what is the real authentic food!!
Loved the veggie pad thai and garlic shrimp. Next time tofu/veggie pad thai and bbq shrimp instead.

Luv this place! Thai food here was excellent. Very authentic. Only 10 mins away from the strip. When we got there they said 1 hr wait but we ended up waiting only 35 mins for our large party of 7. Their coconut ice cream wasn't so good...wanted to eat their mango sweet rice dessert but there wasn't any since it's out of season. Had their spicy shrimp salad and that was very good. All the dishes were great. We always order papaya salad, angel wings, garlic wings, spicy seafood soup, pad Thai noodle, fried pompano fish with spicy sauce.
Make a reservation now. Duck, pork, beef, chicken you can't go wrong! Amazing wine selection, prompt and friendly service. Don't be thrown off by the location.

Make a reservation, you will be so happy you did.  This very special Las Vegas treasure is the best.  Only sorry we could not try everything.  Thai beef salad, short ribs served with egg noodle and curry sauce, soft crab drunken noodle and steak tartar. Ask your friendly wait staff for their favorites you will not be disappointed.  Our very special find was a raw shrimp with a small slice of garlic, tamarind paste, a lime oil spice sauce and all wrapped in a mint leaf.

Man I am going to die dreaming about the crispy duck with coconut curry sauce. If only I could rest on a bed of duck in a sea of coconut curry...

Ordered:
-Crispy duck with coconut curry
-Garlic Prawns 
-Coconut Ice cream
-Fried Rice
-Pad Thai
-Green Curry

The crispy duck is a huge filet of duck floured and deep fried then cut into slices and drenched in a creamy and spicy coconut curry sauce. The skin is still incredibly crispy and the fattiness cuts out the spiciness of the curry very well.  MUST GET.

The garlic prawns: basically tiger prawns half de-shelled so that their bodies are chilling outside of the shell but still wearing them like a cape. Then they are deep fried and tossed in garlic and white pepper. The shell was the best part! So crispy, salty, slightly spicy, and not the least bit oily. It was just endless crunchfuls of deliciousness. MUST GET. These fried shells are better than chips. Better than fried pork skins. Better than any crunchy savory combo item you can ever dream of. GET THESE. They are expensive.

The coconut ice cream was very interesting. Order it. Creamy yet refreshing, it had a flavor almost similar to taro.

Other stuff were whatever. The portions here are small. Be prepared to spend more here than at your regular Thai restaurant.

Also, we tried to get a thai ice tea to go and the waiter told us they were out of to-go cups... while standing in front of a huge unopened bag of plastic cups......

May be my favorite restaurant, period. Their shrimp dishes (especially garlic shrimp, grilled shrimp) are like nothing else you've ever tried. The best thing to do is ask the waiters what they suggest. No lie, every single dish here is amazing.

My boyfriend and I intended to make reservations for dinner and called the restaurant 10+ times over two days before they answered. Come to find out they are booked out about 3 weeks for dinner reservations. Definitely go for lunch! They open at 11:30am and if you get there before noon you probably won't have to wait. We took a cab from the middle of the strip to the restaurant before flying out (cab ride was about $20) for lunch. We were in and out of the restaurant in a half hour! Service was incredibly efficient and nice; after ordering, the food came out in about 5 minutes. As many other people said, the portions are a bit smaller than other Thai/Chinese restaurants but the quality is incredible. We had chicken pad thai and chicken panang (curry) and both were incredible. Hands down both dishes were the best we had ever had. I ordered the curry as a '6' on a scale of 1-10 of spiciness and it was delicious!

My fiance and I went there on 6/18 for breakfast.  We had 2 omelettes with 3 pancakes.  I must say everything was awesome. The server and people working there were very nice and efficient. It only took a few minutes to get our food and it was very good.  Unlike most mainstream IHOP or Denny's type restaurants, the food had lots of flavor and the servings were very large.  The pancakes were as large as the plate and tasted terrific. You can tell that the restaurant is old and in need of some updates...but who cares.  Great food and prices.  Our large omelettes with potatoes and toast were $8.99 a piece and our cakes were $2.99  I believe.

My first time at this place.
When my group was driving up, my cousin noticed this area, not the prettiest area.
In this shopping complex, half the spaces are abandoned.  There was one complex with no store name and two guards standing outside.
Anyhow, here's my review on the food.
We were seated after a half hour wait on a Saturday night.  
The food is definitely overpriced!  The garlic prawns are $25!  The plate didn't have that many prawns on them!
One of my cousin's ordered a chicken dish, around $22.  The amount of chicken barely equaled one chicken breast.
The food is definitely overpriced for the portion amount.  I feel like it's all because of the hype.  However, the food tasted DELICIOUS!
I'm not sure if I'll stop by here again, maybe if I win big in Vegas...

My friend and I picked up a to go order a couple of days ago.. I give this place two stars because the spicy wings were good... Other than that, I don't get what the fuzz is about. I expected really really good food but everything else we ordered was pretty mediocre. We ordered a spicy soup that wasn't spicy (we were asked how spicy on a scale of 1-10 and said 8), chicken chow mein that hardly had any bean sprouts, spicy beef with a sauce that was just watery, and they forgot our cucumber salad orders. The saddest thing is that the portions are really small. If that's the standard, then that's ok, but don't charge an arm and a leg for mediocre food. Disappointed.

Not a big fan of duck but tried the crispy duck on yelp recommendations and found that and the drunken noodles were the best I've eaten anywhere. I'm always disappointed now trying the Noodles elsewhere. Not even the plain strip mall type location can detract from this being a 5 star experience. Kids loved it and I expected the bill to be much higher for the experience we had. Make reservations!

Not worth the fuss! Food was good but VERY VERY small portions. I ordered take out and spent $80.00 for 5 portions. I was expecting $80.00 worth of food. When I opened my take out I was so shocked.. I called the restaurant, I explained to the manager how my food was so rationed that Im sure there was a mistake. I sent the photos of the entrees. They commented back and the manager said, "yes thats how we serve very small portions." It was less than half for each take out box. I felt so ripped off. It is worth the posting to inform you of a cheap place that can't give you full portions. You're not that good..

Le Thai is the new place to eat. East Fremont Great food and excellent portions. 702-778-0888
King and I   Great food . Friendly staff.  affordable  Next to UNLV and Tropicana 702-256-1568
Kung Fu Awesome place for take out Based in China Town. Affordable. 702-2474120

OMG. this was absolutely incredible dining. A must if you are anywhere near Vegas. The food is authentic and fantastic. We had som thum, nam Kao tod, crab fried rice and crispy duck panang curry. Every dish exceeded our expectations! I would strongly advise recommendations as the wait in this restaurant can be very lengthy without.
Obsessed with the Drunken Noodle. No wonder why so many people go here. Excellent!

Oh heavens finally a THAI restaurant that I truly adore!! 
If my #MCM Anthony Bourdain dined here before and it was featured on Travel Channel's "No Reservations", then you know this place is a hit.
It hasn't even been a week yet and I'm back.

We came for the KHAO SOI! (Egg noodle with curry soup and chicken, northern Thai) best for your hangover! My favorite Thai dish ever.

Everything here is authentic and pure.

Not in the best location, but hey the best places are usually "hole in the wall places".

Oh my.  This Thai food lover is still in awe of last nights dinner.  Wonton soup was wonderfully light and full of rich flavorrs.  Hot sour vegetable soup was a fantastic contrast of flavor.  The garlic grilled prawns with chile and lime were delicious.   Chicken red curry had a grrat flavor.   The garlid fried prawns had their shell on - a great comination of texture and garlicky goodness.  Ordered off menu for sauteed vegetables in a spicy chile garlic sauce - off the hook flavor.  Service was great as always.

Oh. My. God.

You cannot come to Vegas without visiting Lotus of Siam. You would be missing out on the best meal of your life! 

My Dad and I decided to stop by after a friend recommended it to us, and it was honestly the BEST Thai food either of us had ever had. And we've had A LOT of Thai food in our lives. It was so good that we ended up coming back two days later for more!

We tried the fried prawns, fresh spring rolls (not on the menu, but definitely worth ordering!), fried chicken wings, shrimp pad thai, crispy duck with drunken noodles, and soft shell crab with drunken noodles, and everything was EXCEPTIONAL. I'm practically drooling right now just thinking about it. I can't wait to go back! 

This restaurant is an absolutely CAN'T MISS stop if you're visiting Vegas. I couldn't recommend it more highly.
One of the best I have ever had.  Must go must have.

One of the best Thai spots. The crunchy rice is amazing. They have a surprisingly large wine list and the variety is impressive! It's no wonder this spot is one of the top restaurants in America. Each time I've been here the service is on point and so is the food! It's in a sketchy part of town and the strip mall it's in is hysterically ghetto. I think one of the shops is a Vietnamese wig store. And I think just a little bit over is a transsexual bar. Go for the sights and be happy you did because the food is oh my god good!

One of the best places in Las Vegas -- make sure you get a reservation because it fills up quickly. Second time we have been here and our group loved it once again. It had been 4 years since we had gone initially and it was exactly what we remembered.

When ordering for spice, I would say shade about 1-2 degrees lower then what you think you can handle, because their degrees are higher then what we usually see here in DC.

Only had take out from this place a few times and by far it's the best Thai food I've ever had. Drunken anything on the menu is a must try. 

If you love Thai, there's more Thai than you can handle and I'm not talking about Thai girls or any ladyboys.

Over 2,000 people have already said the food is AMAZING, and I agree! The Thai tea didn't taste like it was from powder, but instead had a flavor that stayed on your tongue even after you drank it. The Pad Thai had just the right amount of sweetness to flavor combo to make it addicting to eat. The duck curry had pieces of duck that had more meat than fat, but just enough fat to give it that great taste. Everything we ate was great!

So, I'll review things I don't really notice. I was hesitant because the plaza where Lotus of Siam is located is pretty ghetto. I thought it would be dirty or run down. Wow was I wrong. Upon entry, you see all the awards that place received, including the James Beard award. Host was welcoming. Drink orders were placed right away (get the Thai tea). And most importantly, THE PLACE WAS SO CLEAN! Our table didn't feel sticky or wet. I saw a server wipe down our table but then dried it off too, which many restaurants don't do and just leave it wet (I hate that). The utensils were shiny clean, not even any dry water marks on them. Same with plates. Floors weren't sticky or stained. Walls were clean. Bathroom was exceptionally clean. All this just added to how great the food tasted. 

DEFINITELY eat at Lotus of Siam. Don't be fooled by outside appearances, as beauty is found within. And yes, food beauty is definitely found in Lotus of Siam.
Over Rated & Over Priced!!!  Being Thai and having ate at numerous Thai Restaurants, the food quality was poor 2/10.  The service was good though 8/10.  Hope this review will save you time & money!

Overhyped. While definitely serving up good food, it definitely didn't blow me away. The curry was good, the pad kee mao (drunken noodle) was good and the chili dip was good but the prices for the chef's specials are rape! $25 bucks is not worth it. The portions are meager.

It's a great place for those who don't know what great Thai food tastes like, and for those who should know and still rave about this place, I want what you're smoking.

TLDR: Overpriced dishes, small portions. "Must try" dishes are $25 bucks. Not worth it.
Panang curry is amazing- So many flavors!! Lots of veggie options. Thai coffee is also very good. Service is kinda mixed - 5 mins to get our food; 15 mins to get our to go order and check.

Part of the fun of Lotus of Siam is the bizarre, strip mall, risky neighborhood location. You can't help but be surprised when you enter and are greeted by walls covered in raving reviews and crowds of people. 

Maybe you read about Lotus of Siam in Gourmet magazine (that's how we found it), or you saw Anthony Bourdain enjoying the Garlic Prawns on CNN, or maybe you just kept hearing how amazing it is and that you simply must dine here if you're in Vegas!

Now that we've been here a few times, we have our favorites, and our favorite strategies. First, if you're going to dine in, be sure to call for reservations. We, however, love the take-out strategy and their take-out is fast! Just be sure to check your order before you leave, because they might have forgotten something, like your ... 

Garlic. Prawns. We almost left ours there because they didn't get included in our take-out order, and I think we would have shed tears if we had arrived back at home without them. They are crispy, flavorful, and quite unlike anything else I've tried. 

Our other favorites include the Kao Soi, which they make for us with just vegetables, and we enjoy most of the other items from the "Northern" menu, like the Tom Kha Gai. Be sure to specify how spicy you like your food -- on a scale of 1-10, a "4" here is pretty hot, and we like spicy. 

We visit Vegas at least once a year and stop here every time. It's an adventure that's worth a little drive!

Penang curry with crispy duck, garlic shrimp, and pad Thai was delicious! I normally get pad see ew but these other dishes definitely outshined my go to dish. The Thai iced coffee and mango and sticky rice was average but enjoyable! Good serving sizes too!

Please don't forget to make a reservation. We didn't and decided to get our food to-go for 30 minutes instead of the 1.5 hrs wait for a table.. Don't worry, in case you forget, there's a bar in the back complete with lime drink (get this!), Thai tea and coffee, and a very very extensive list of wines! Impressive.

Brought our food back to the hotel, and it was still good as ever. 
- Pad thai noodles were al dente. Thank god. I've had some pretty good pad thais in my life so this one didn't stand out too much, but it was really good.
- Fried prawns - yes! I loved that I was able to devour the whole thing - skin and all. It was a little too hard/crunchy though and felt like there was too much breading on the prawns. 
- Penang curry was just the right consistency. Not as memorable though, but it was delicious.
- Crispy rice - omg!!!! If nothing seemed memorable from above, it's because THIS is the thing to get. We got 2 portions of this and I'm SO glad we did! The flavors were out of this world - the lemongrass really shone through. Good on top of the raw cabbage.

Would go back, but maybe I would prefer to dine-in instead. But still good!

Pretty amazing Thai food- you get the vibe as you walk in, full and vibrant place, long lines, well off the strip in a somewhat seedy area in the Commercial Center.  I have made it a point of hitting this place for some of the best food in town.  Like it spicy- they are serious but you can opt out.  
Be prepared for a long wait but its worth it.  Or you can get stuff to go and spice it up at home.

Quite possibly the best Thai I had in a very long time.   I had the Crispy Duck with Drunken Noodles... Absolutely amazing!  The dish was made with fresh basil, green peppers, garlic and onions.  I ordered with a medium heat of "5".  Service was wonderful.  We walked to the location from the SLS Las Vegas, I would recommend driving.  The place doesn't look like much from the out side but its a nice casual atomsphere inside.

Really wished I could have gone back for the 3rd time! This place really is a "not so hidden" gem. The duck panang is my absolute favorite. Some of the appetizers and soup were too sour for me ( yes I know it's hot and sour soup but they were really generous on the sour side). If you don't like too much spice I would stick to scale of 2-5. I was ambitious and tried 8 on my second visit and could NOT handle the heat. The green curry and garlic prawn are delicious. We broke the rule and tried the pad Thai as well (I know so basic) but it was decent. This place does not disappoint as the food is warm and fresh. Make sure to call ahead and make reservations! Can you please open this restaurant in DC?! Pretty please? I don't wanna wait until my next visit to Vegas to have me some duck panang!

Regularly ranked as one of the best restaurants in Las Vegas and one of the best Thai places in the country for a reason. The menu is epic. It is pages long and full of hundreds of dishes. You could eat here every day for a year and never repeat a meal. The curries are my favorite dishes but the garlic prawns are also phenomenal. They're fried with the shells still on and end up with a potato chip quality crunch and texture. They're also swimming in garlic. It's stupendous. I highly recommend this place.

Rumored to be the "best Thai restaurant in America," I can say the hype isn't too far off.

You can tell LoS was born from a small mom and pop restaurant that has been expanded to meet demand, and blossomed through word of mouth alone. This is not a calculated restaurant, and reputation was built on the merit of the food. Pulling into the dilapidated strip mall parking lot, I had a small tinge of "where the hell are we?"

The garlic prawns feature Jurassic-sized shrimp, the shells peeled so they dangle by the same tail -- battered and deep-fried for a garlicky crunch. 

The Khao Soi curry was a bright curry with egg noodles, light on coconut milk, cut with lime juice. Highly recommend getting it with the roasted duck -- where the fat has been carefully rendered down so that each piece is crunchy and moist without excess fat. Tastes like they cut up duck confit to add to their curry.

The Tom Yum and Tom Kai soups were very complex, but very concentrated. Sharply sour, incredibly spicy (despite a "medium" level of spiciness.. they are NOT messing around). 

Admittedly, the papaya salad -- while good in its own right -- was a little under developed compared to the other dishes. The papaya wasn't thoroughly beaten to soften it, and thus was unable to really take up the flavor of the dressing. Can't win them all!

Lotus of Siam will be a place I will insist on stopping by every trip to Vegas from now on.

Show off your foodie prowess by bringing your friends to this gem off the strip, worth the cab fair. Having had the Anthony Bourdain stamp of approval this spot does not disappoint. 

Main tip, after ordering your typical go-to Thai dishes turn to the back of the menu to a page titled Chef's Choice. Here you will find items that your typical Thai restaurant may not have. 

We tasted the Crispy Duck Panang, Drunken Noodle Soft Shell Crab, Sea Bass Som Thum amongst other delicious entrees. The flavors are robust. If you are not on your paleo diet, this is your spot. Mix all the spicy sauces in with your rice and leave happy. 

Bonus: they have a decent bar for you to get some beers while you wait for your table.

Simply the best Thai restaurant in the entire universe! You will not believe that a world-class restaurant could exist in this shopping center but it does. Huge menu, nice wine selections, great service and AMAZING food. There will probably be a huge wait and the best way to spend it is a couple doors down getting a foot massage.
Simply the very best Thai any where.  Thanks for the service!!  Thanks for best soup you will ever taste.

So I came here because my friend had seen it I'm top chef or whatever... I thought whatever...we decide to take the transit there and walk because we were drunk and it's smart that way. It was a cold dark Vegas night and we're asking asking some scandalous back Vegas road... Come up behind the place and we're like is it open...And how do you get in.. Well we wonder around the front of the strip mall and hell yes it was open open and jam packed. We put in our names and go to the over packed bar...40 minutes later we get seated.. no biggy. We order typical Thai food and it was amazing. My curry was hot... And I kept eat the "bell" peppers... Until I found out that they were Thai chilies... I start sweating profusely. The email waiter brings me a nice Thai milk drink to soothe the fire. I got the green curry.. next time I need to try the recommended regional Thai food

So glad I had the chance to dine here while in Vegas.  It was or maybe is still voted the top Thai restaurant in America. It's located in a somewhat ghetto area but don't mind the location! A reservation is a must if you want to dine here. It's always crowded inside! The restaurant is actually quite big. All of the staff are Thai. This is some authentic Thai food!

The portions of the food are all small and meant for sharing. I honestly do not remember much of what I ordered (but it was tons of food) but here's what stuck out to me:

Garlic Prawns- this dish is simply perfection. It's deep fried prawns!! It was so good and it was actually the last thing that came out to my table. Easily my favorite dish from the restaurant.

Crispy Duck Panang Curry: I normally don't like to eat duck but this dish was pretty good. The duck was perfectly fried and the Panang curry was perfectly seasoned. 

We got free dessert as well! It was fried bananas!! And a lot of them! It was soooo so soo good. Literally the best fried bananas I've ever had. 

I really hope to come back one day!

So we ordered the drunken noodle soft shell crab, crispy duck panang and the gralic prawns. Prawns 3 stars, crab 2 stars and panang 4 stars.  Not sure what the hype with this place is about. Had 1 night in Vegas for a nice dinner and although the food wasn't bad, I do regret my decision. btw, this place is definitely not the best Thai food around.
Solid food at decent prices.  The stuffed chicken wings were my favorite!

Solid food but a bit pricey.
