A Thai restaurant which is pretty close to Stratosphere.  The inside is very large. There are pictures hanging on the wall w/ celebrities such as Nicholas Cage, etc.  The bathrooms and inside are pretty clean.

The food is pretty solid.  Most dishes run at about $12-$15 each plate so it's much more expensive compared to LA prices.  I also prefer some of the Thai restaurants in LA but the food is still pretty good here.

Stuff that's really good - 4/5
-Pad Thai - Pad Thai is solid.  It's not over the top sweet (I don't like super sweet Pad Thai).  Probably the second best Pad Thai I've had.
-Spicy Catfish Fillet (No bone) - I usually prefer the catfish w/ bone-in, but this was a fillet.  It was surprisingly really good.  Nice crunchy texture and sauce was good.

Slightly above average - 3.5/5
-Pad See Ew - Enjoyable.  It wasn't out of this world awesome but it's good.
-Panang Curry - Solid.  Beware, it's got a lot of coconut milk so in it, so I wouldn't recommend eating this before something sexy/romantic like clubbing - lol.
-Tom Yum Seafood soup - Enjoyable.

Average - 3/5 - All of this stuff was decent, but you can opt to pass on it if you fancy.
-Rad Na - Decent, but nothing special.
-Spicy Beef Noodle soup - In general, this is one of my favorite dishes to order at a Thai restaurant.  Unfortunately  this wasn't anything special (I didn't see any liver in it and I felt the soup base was a bit bland) 
-Skewers - Decent, but nothing special.  The peanut sauce was really good though.
-Spicy Sausage - Decent, but nothing special.

Bad - 2/5 - 
-Crispy fried rice appetizer.  It's like I was eating Mexican fried rice due to the red onions and overloaded green onions/cilantro.  I'm used to eating crispy fried rice but this tasted odd.

TIPS:
-Reservation necessary
Solid thai.  Not sure that it's all that it's cracked up to be, but it is good.  Pad thai is not recommended, but I consider myself a pad thai snob.
Some of the best, most authentic Thai food I've ever eaten. Be careful with the spice scale! It goes from 1 to 10, with 3 roughly Tobasco, and 7 "Thai spicy."

Still a 10!

Short Rib Panang - $22.95 - Short rib was tender and cooked perfectly. Not much seasoning on the meat itself but the panang curry just elevates it. The portion size was decent. but on the small size. 

Softshell Crab Drunken Noodle - $22.95 - Crab was fried perfectly. I do not know how the keep it so crispy when it is covered in sauce. The noodles are nothing special though, just filler for the yummy crab.

Seabass Drunken Noodle - $29.95 - Fish was flaky and cooked well. Again the noodles are nothing special though, just filler.

Also got the crispy duck panang and garlic prawns again and they were still wonderful.

They charge $2 for rice if you want more.

They messed up our orders, I told them they put level 10 on the wrong dish because I could see all the chili oil and they did not believe me. When my friends ate it, it was level 10 and mine was level 7. Sometimes the customer is right!

Super Busy!!! Obviously, this is where all the locals of Las Vegas go to get Thai food. It's located way off the strip past Sahara. When my husband and I parked we were a little anxious because the location is in a not so nice looking plaza strip with lots of-careful cuz you might get robbed-signage!! 
However, there's a reason locals come to a joint and that is the food is actually really good! Quite authentic. I didn't care for the Tom Ka soup, but the pad Thai noodles, and fish dish (can't remember the name) were excellent! 
I suggest coming earlier in the day so you don't feel so intimidated by the location and enjoy some nicely prepared Thai food.

Super delicious foods with the prices to match. The deep fried garlic prawns ($25) were crispy on the outside with the right touch of sweetness and garlic.  I literally devoured the whole prawns with shells, heads, gills and everything. They are that good.

We also ordered a 4-lb deep fried catfish ($40).  It was perfectly cooked, crispy on the outside and moist, flaky on the inside. It came with shredded salads topped with peanuts and prepared in a perfectly harmonious light fish sauce balanced with sweetness, acidity, heat, and saltiness. The sauce is so, so tasty I could literally eat white rice with just the sauce for a meal.

The pad thai was good.  We also ordered a soup (forgot what it was) but found it lacking in flavors and spices.  

The service was fast, friendly, attentive, and efficient.  The visit to LOS was a highlight of our trip to Vegas.
THe best.  Period!  No comparison.  Everything on the entire menu is amazing.  Make sure you call ahead for a reservation or you may end up waiting 2 hours.  The wait is worth it though.
Terrible service. Bad attitute .. Wait so long. We came at 4 pm to wait 5:30 pm. The owner ia cold  face. Bring all her friends coming. Never come again..

The Thai food here is excellent. Went with a few locals and they reccomend the Northern Thai dishes that are on the menu. My favorite of them all was the curries, great balance of flavor and depth within the sauce. Great beer/wine selection. The food was worth the wait! Reservations reccomended, went on a Tuesday night and it took us an hour to get a table.

The Thai food here really authentic. I ordered the chicken larb salad medium spicy. It was great and spot on. I can taste the spices and herbs ingredients incorporated in this dish. The spiciness level was perfect. I give this place a 4 star because I walked in 45 mins before closing time during lunch. As soon as I walked in I didn't get greeted immediately or was acknowledge, didn't felt welcoming at all and the two staff there notice me standing by the register for a good minute to two minutes before seating me. Probably because it was close to closing time... Overall, I enjoy the food experience.

The Tom Yum Koong, Drunken Noodle Soft Shell Crab, Khao, Soi, Prick Thai Onn taste is excellent.  However, today must have been the worst service ever.  After getting the soup, it took 30 min of waiting for the rest of the food.  Other tables that came later than us received their food first.

The absolute best Thai restaurant in America. At least that I have experienced so far. Yes, it is in a busted up strip mall in a sketchy part of town, but once you step through those doors (prepare for a wait unless you get there and line up PRIOR TO OPENING TIME), you realize you have just entered a real institution where food, and pride of food, is King. 

As you make your way to the table, just take in the energy of this place as servers hurry along, pushing out cart after cart teeming with crispy golden garlic prawns and lobster. It is truly a sight to behold.  

While the curries and other standards at Lotus are wonderful, I am sure, this is a special Thai restaurant that offers so much more, so do venture outside the usuals. Definitely an emphasis on fresh seafood here... And their Northern dishes really stand out as well. 

Stand outs that we've ordered: 
Koong Sarong (prawn in blanket)
Garlic Prawns, yes, they are just fantastic as all the reviews have stated. 
Charbroiled Prawns
Suki Scallops (or Seared Scallops with garlic pepper or chilli basil)
Sliced catfish
Fried/Steamed fish and lobster dishes, while I have not yet tried them, seem wonderful as well. 

They have an incredibly impressive, noteworthy, actually, wine selection/wine room -- particularly whites -- that pair so well with their dishes. 

If you are visiting Vegas or live in Vegas and truly want to be wowed, treat yourself at this absolute gem.

The best Korean food I have ever had.  Go for the house specialties.  Softshell crab was fantastic.  Make your reservation well in advance.  This is the best restaurant in Las Vegas in my opinion.  Next time I am in Vegas I may go here twice.

The best Thai food in Las Vegas and perhaps the country. Very deep wine cellar specializing in German wines (Rieslings) which pair perfectly with the spicy Thai food. The staff is very competent, efficient and helpful. Go for the Northern Thai specialties in the back of the menu like crispy duck Penang and soft shell crab drunken noodles. Be sure to make reservations if you want to eat here. It is a very popular restaurant located off the strip.

The best Thai food that I have ever eaten hands down. It's in an older strip mall off of Sahara, but don't let that fool you. The food here is amazing. Our group devoured the following items from the menu: Tom Kah Kai Soup, Beef and Chicken Patay, Crispy Duck Panang, Thai Fried Rice, Shrimp Pad Thai, Chicken Pad Thai, and another dish with chicken and green beans.  We dined here for an early lunch (on a Tuesday). That was a smart move to avoid the crowds. The service was impeccable, the food had lots of flavor and we enjoyed the pictures of celebs on the wall. You know the food is good when there are no leftovers! Great first impression Lotus of Siam! Can't wait to return.
The best Thai in Vegas!

The best Thai in town! Not the most desirable location but it's totally worth it! There's a sweet lady that's a server there and she is the best! Cow (sp?) is her name. We tell her what we like and don't like and let her choose what she thinks is best. Delish every time!

The best Thai on the planet Earth.  This place is off the strip in a strip mall.  The lady has been cooking here for over 30 years!.  Make reservations for dinner at least 2 weeks in advance.  Lunch is easy if you show up when they open.  Crispy Rice, Duck with drunken noodles are the stars of this show. Try the Larb from the northern menu if you want something new.

The famous Lotus of Siam! I've gotten take out before but have never eaten at this mecca for all things Thai food. First of all I must say the service is excellent! You can tell the servers make money here and they are all professionals. Secondly the food is amazing, we already know this. We didn't come not knowing the depth of amazingness, we came to sit back and let Lotus of Siam feed us till we couldn't eat anymore. 

We started with the ubiquitous chicken satay, which was by far the most authentic and best chicken satay I've ever had. The chicken almost seemed charcoal grilled and the peanut sauce was fresh and spot on. 

Secondly we had the Som Tum papaya salad which was excellent! Hotter than napalm but excellent nonetheless. I should of ordered sticky rice with it, my bad. 

Note: I ordered everything level 5 spicy out of 10 because my wife likes hot but not super hot. I must say the 5 here is an easy 7 or 8 at an American Thai restaurant. The papaya salad was easily an 8, I loved it but it was too hot for the wifey.

Next we had the Nam Tok (like a larb but instead of ground meet its with grilled beef). The Nam Tok's flavor was spot on. That lime juice, roasted rice powder, mint, cilantro, onion, shallot, and chili flavor I love. The only downside was the meat was very fatty which i didn't love.

Lastly we had the Chicken fried rice with Spicy Basil sauce. Best fried rice I've ever had. Hot as heck but excellent flavor and quality cuts of chicken. 

Lotus of Siam, some would say the best Thai food in America, is classy, yummy, spicy, and not cheap. But what really high quality food these days is really cheap anymore? I can't wait to come back!

The food here was delicious.  I have eaten at many Thai places in my life and I have to say this place is one of the best.  There papaya was spicy and just right.  There pad Thai was cooked and tasted amazing.  It had the sweet and spicy texture just like how I like it!

The food is great here but I don't think it's worth the hype. I've had better Thai food. I think it's overpriced for what you get. The flavors are well balanced and everything was cooked perfectly. But the portions were smaller than I expected. 

They have a decent wine selection - better than I expected from a Thai restaurant. There is a bar inside the restaurant, so you can get a drink while you're waiting for your table. 

I'd want to go back to try different dishes. I'm just not sure it's worth the wait or the prices.

The food was absolutely delicious; I can't stop thinking about the crispy fried rice. Service was good also. My only gripe was that they serve beer & wine only :) I got past it quickly once I tasted the food!

The food was excellent. I tried the garlic Shrimp and the duck panang. Both dishes were fried to perfection and had wonderful balance in flavor. The portion sizes were a tad smaller than I expected but if you're looking for a Thai place in Vegas this is it!
The good here is amazing. It's a must that you order from the back of the menu hope you enjoy and happy eating!

The parking lot is empty, there are signs up reporting break-ins, and they have two signs indicating status of operation: open and closed (at the same time). Arriving at the door on the strip mall, one does not expect to walk into a beautiful little restaurant with glass chandeliers, a large exhibited wine collection, and a well lit, well furnished, clean restaurant interior. The service was on excellent with our water (which was delicious, and perhaps the best part of the meal considering we had been out drinking the night before) always being refilled. In addition, the food was served timely and tasted delicious. The specific dishes we tried are listed below:

Pad thai - 5/5
Perfectly seasoned, not over-cooked. No sauces were overwhelming, and the dish was not at all greasy

Drunken Noodles with Beef - 3/5
The noodles were fine, and the beef was seasoned okay. The downside of this dish was that the noodles did not hold any flavor and the sauce washed away the seasoning from the beef to make it taste extremely bland relative to the other dishes order; thereby making it not as enjoyable.

Garlic prawns - 5/5
Crunchy, well-seasoned, large serving size, and not greasy at all. This was my favorite dish

Panang curry with chicken - 5/5
The curry tasted amazing, and the amount of chicken included was very reasonable relative to the size of the dish and amount of curry sauce. Goes well with the steamed rice, which is free by the way.

The place was great but only bad thing was the tables are too closed together and one of the waiters got our order mixed and my was wrong. It was a bit noisy in there so you can't really hear the conversation you are having with your friends unless you are yelling or have a loud voice. 

At least the food was still great. My bf calls it a cafeteria. I would still go back even if it is a little far from me.
The real reason I go to Las Vegas! Pay attention to the Northern Thai dishes - here is where they really excel. Oh, and make a reservation :-)

The restaurant looks nothing from the outside but once inside it's nice. The 45 min wait time for a Wednesday night was intriguing, this usually means it's gonna be good right? The wait staff were very pleasant and the service was quick. I ordered 3 staples - Chicken Satay, Fish cakes and Panang Chicken. I'd give them a 7 out of 10 for food. I've definitely had better even in my little local in Scottsdale. Not being familiar with their Northern dishes I didn't want to be too adventurous so went with what I knew. I'd come here again to try some more adventurous dishes but for now not wowed which is disappointing as I'd waited so long to try it.

The single greatest Thai restaurant outside of Thailand..
this place is mecca for thai food - you must come here if you like Thai food.. it's that good.

Note: it's in a strip mall, and on a busy vegas weekend, it can be a wait to get a taxi out of here. best to have a car rental to visit here.

Crispy duck, the panang curry, the Fried Cod, dear god.. it's truly magnificent.

Before Bank, the wine manager left to open his own place (Chada), the wine program was also world class/legendary.. it's now a shell of what it was before (it used to be the best Riesling collection just about anywhere).

All in all.. you just have to come here.. it's that good.

The tom kha gai coconut milk soup was spectacular. The panang curry was not, totally too thin and lacking flavor. Not sure I would go back to this place, as it was not all it was hyped up to be and the lines are long and the service is rushed.

The yellow curry dish was amazing! The portion was perfect. The dish wasn't as hot as I'd like but he brought me a spice rack. I love wine and the wine selection is very long. They is a wine case that's clear and is seen when you walk through. I  recommend this restaurant for those who like Thai.

They have a big menu that includes fish and duck dishes some other Thai restaurants don't have.

Their portion size is also not the typical Thai restaurant portion, I would say half of what you get at other places. Our soup (Tom Kha kai) came in a pot with flame in the middle which was cool, but it wasn't the best I've had. Their duck dishes are pretty good. Curry came in a very shallow, and wide bowl which made it go cold after a couple of minutes with their A/C.

They were super busy and we didn't want to wait too long for dinner so we decided to order take out.  The gal at the counter was super nice and was accommodating when we made some changes to our order.  Considering we were stuck in traffic for a while, got back to our hotel and it still tasted great.  Will definitely go back to try the dine in experience.

This establishment would have received five stars if it were based soley on the food. The prices are very overpriced. It may be because it is known as one the best Thai places around. The garlic prawns are a must. You can eat the whole thing including the shell. They are crispy and delicious. The panang curry has just the right amount of spices and heat. It is great with the crispy duck. The papaya salad is sweet and goes well with any of the other dishes, especially the spicy ones.

This is a legend in town, so I had high hopes when we went. The food was good, but I feel as though everything we had was fried. It wasn't far and beyond some of the other Thai restaurants in town, but it was good. I will probably go back.

This is an exceptional Thai restaurant.  The food was fantastic, and there is a HUGE menu to choose from.  You have the perennial favorites like Pad Thai on up to the more rare things like crispy fried pork bellies.  We were impressed and wish it was closer to us.

Service was quick.  Even during lunch rush we had our food surprisingly fast.

This is by FARRRRRR the best Thai restaurant you will ever eat at definitely in Las Vegas but probably in the United States. All I have to say is you have to get something from the Northern Specialties. I got the beef stew with the sticky rice and it was absolutely phenomenal! They have one of the most amazing selections of wine and they even have a few amazing beers like Firestone Union Jack. You have to get a reservation way in advance but trust me, it's worth it.

This is by far the best Thai food I've ever had! 

We arrived at 5:30pm at the time of opening and there was already a line forming. Do not take that as an exaggeration. If you want your taste of Lotus of Siam, get there early and throw elbows because this is a must-try! 

Among the two of us ladies, we ordered the garlic prawns, crispy duck with drunken noodles, and thum ka noon. This is excessive eating for two but we were on a mission to try as much as we can until our next Vegas trip. The garlic prawns were huge with the shells loosely hanging on its meat. The flavors were blatant and the meat texture was done with the right crisp. For $25, there were eight pieces to share. The crispy duck was deboned and casually sitting on top of a pile of juicy and sticky bed of drunken noodles. There is an assortment of green and red peppers in the pile hence making it a very exotic dish. The thum ka noon is ground pork with shredded Jackfruit. It was a very flavorful dish that would be a good complement with rice but we ran out of room for the carbs. 

Service and food delivis exceptionally good and quick. We sat down at 5:35pm and were on our way in exactly an hour.

This is on my list for one of my favorite Thai restaurants I've ever had. The other one is in my hometown, Fort Worth, TX. Everything seemed very authentic! The flat noodles with duck was so good! I've never had that type of dish before at a Thai resturant. The breaded fried prawns are to die for. I've haven't been to s Thai restaurant that serves prawns that way. I do not think we had a bad dish here at all.

The service here was ok. There were many times we had to wait for the waiter for quite awhile. They are possible short staff. Who knows! 

The tom kha was really tasty, too and came in an authentic Thai hotpot. This is a very unique and different Thai restaurant.

This is one of my best meals in Vegas! I have never experienced real Thai food until now. Normally I would have settled for the usual pad thai and pad see ew. However, I wanted to be adventurous this time. I tried the nam kao tod as an appetizer, and it was AMAZING - the crispy rice with the pork sausages, lime juice, chili, and green onions make my mouth water. Hands down, the best Thai dish ever!!! I even looked up recipes online to try to replicate this dish at home. 

We also tried the garlic prawns that were deep fried; the dish was deliciously crunchy. Our third dish was the crispy duck in Khao Soi (thai egg noodles in a curry sauce). The crispy duck was yummy, but got a little soggy in the Khao Soi. It would have been slightly better if the crispy duck was separated from the Khao Soi, and combined the two later to maintain the crispness in the duck. 

The menu is quite extensive. My boyfriend and I were quite overwhelmed. We could only fit in three dishes between the two of us. I would highly recommend this place. You'd be really missing out if you don't give it a shot! 

Service was friendly and fast. 

There is plenty of parking in the plaza.

This is probably one of the best Thai food I've tasted here in Las Vegas. We had some chicken skewers, tom yum kai, panang curry with chicken, chicken with cashew, and crispy duck with drunken noodles. Everything was delicious!!!

This is some of the best Thai food you'll ever find in Vegas.  A lot of nice restaurants in Vegas are overhyped and overpriced.  While the quality of food at this restaurant may not compare to the new fads of cuisine, it certainly lives up the the standards of Americans and Thais alike.  It tastes great and it's affordable.

Skip the casino food and come here instead.

This is the BEST thai restaurant in the US, in my opinion.  I cannot come to Vegas and not take a detour to eat here.

First, MAKE a reservation and make sure you can get there slightly before your reservation as they will only hold your table for 5 minutes.  There is still always a wait.  Anticipate about a $16-$18 cab ride from the strip and about 15-20 minutes to get there depending on traffic.  Try to not go on a Friday or Saturday as it is always overly packed. 

Second, its not on the strip, it's in a mini mall in the middle of nowhere.  At first, you look at the outside and it looks like a place you are not sure you want to trust eating at, but trust me...you will thank me. 

They have a pretty high tech checkin system with an iPad and they actually have things organized when you get in.

Now for the food, when you get the menu go straight to the chef's specialties or the Northern selection.  It's what they specialize in so take advantage. 

They will ask you a scale of 1-10 for spiciness..the food is SPICY.  A 10 is only for those who have replaced their stomach with Iron.  A jalapeno is more at a level 2, a habernero is at a level 5...Scotch bonnets are level 8...I don't even know what they use.  Mind you the spice is there but so is the taste..its not like you burned your mouth and then nothing.

The wine list is also pretty impressive for a strip mall thai restaurant.  And well priced.  For $150, you can easily feed 4 people with a reasonably good bottle of wine too. 

Food Recommendation: Short Ribs in Penang Sauce

This is the best Thai food in Las Vegas, and maybe the best Thai food in America. Anthony Bourdain visited here in one of his tv shows and specifically praised their Northern Thai menu selections. 

Everything I've ever ordered from here has been fantastic. This place is incredible, and was very reasonably priced ($10 - $15 per person, approximately)

This is the best Thai restaurant that I've experienced. Because of this it is a famous "must visit" dining destination for Las Vegas visitors. When I have business in Vegas, I always plan an outing to Lotus of Siam. 
Don't come here and order typical Thai dishes like Pad Thai, Panang and Drunken Noodles unless you jazz it up with something like crispy duck. Order from the Northern Specialties since that is the most special part of their menu and arguably what they are best at.
Khao Soi, another comfort food dish with noodles and meat in a panang curry like soup with pickled vegetables and raw red onions is delicious and a go-to dish for me.
Nam Kao Tod (a puffed crispy rice salad with preserved sour pork sausage) has volumes of flavor (spicy, sour, minty) if you're looking for something different.
Try Nam Prik (a composed room temperature chili based salad),  Jackfruit salad, Hung Lay (pork curry braised down with garlic and ginger), Northern Larb (their version of comfort food).

The garlic prawns are a crowd pleaser and a safe choice for non-adventurous diners. The Drunken Noodles with crispy duck is another crowd pleaser.

This place had a lot to live up to, as many reviews and articles claimed that this is the best Thai restaurant in the U.S.  I'm sure there are others that are just as good, but I have to say that this place didn't disappoint.  The garlic prawns were amazing, and the service was great!  We came just in time, 8 minutes before it opened, so we didn't have to wait long.  They came to take our order as soon as we were ready, and the food came in a flash.  Will definitely be back next time we're in Vegas!

This place is a solid 4 stars! Their pricing is high for the amount of food they give. Pad Thai is delish and legit! Cashew chicken was very small and wasn't filling. Each chicken or beef order portion wise is comparable to a single side item from Panda Express. Their Tom yum chicken soup was very good. I will be back here every time I revisit LV.

This place is amazing!!!!!!  The first time I came here was about two years ago and right after enjoying the Nutcracker at the Smith Center. 

I had read about this place before and looked at its list of reviewers.  One after the other giving it praise.  

I convinced my family to try it out and once we parked I could tell no one was thrilled about the way it looked from the outside or the sketchy area it seemed to be in.  Once we walked inside, I could tell it was huge, way bigger than it gives off from the outside and it was jammed packed ( always a good sign when trying someplace new).  The host told us it would be a 2 hour minimum wait.  At those words my BF began to walk back towards the door, he hates waiting, let alone two hours ( which, when youre hungry is an eternity). I was so excited to try it but two hours is kinda long, we could always come back! 

As I begin to make my way to the door a man standing in line, leans over and tells me its worth the wait.  Dammit, now I want to wait.  

I round everyone back up and tell them its going to be amazing.  We can wait!  Plus we can enjoy each others company and spend some quality time chatting with each other.  

If youve ever been there before, youll know that there isnt really anywhere to wait. Sure, you could go outside, but in December its a bit chilly.  Inside, theres a little waiting room that holds about four people max.  Its pretty tight and those chairs should be saved for someone that perhaps cant stand as long.  

We end up against the glass wall to the wine room.  In the direct path of all the waiters pushing carts loaded with hot plates of amazingness, back and forth from the kitchen to the large dining room near the bar.  Talk about torture.  

Our wait ended up being about 1:45 minutes and after viewing and smelling the amazing dishes going back and forth we had a good idea of what we wanted.  And you know what?  Completly worth it!!!

We ordered a few different plates and shared them all.  Nothing was left, everything was enjoyed and devoured!! 

I know that I used the word amazing way too many times but that's how I feel about this place!  Simply AMAZING!!!!

This place is amazing.

I have been here 5 times so far and neither I nor my date have ever gotten anything we didn't like. The last time we were here I got green curry and he got panang curry (not the one with crispy duck, although we have gotten that before and it was excellent). We both liked the panang curry better but the green curry was delicious as well.

Usually we also get the pork jerky or the beef jerky as an appetizer. The pork jerky is extremely juicy, the beef jerky is full of flavor, and both come with a fantastic sauce. My favorite thing on the menu is Tom Kah Kai soup, it is just the best thing on this planet. We haven't been brave enough to try the stranger things on the menu, but the menu is so extensive that it doesn't matter. If you don't know what to try, the staff are extremely helpful!

We usually order our food at a 2 or 3 which is spicy enough to make my eyes water a bit but not so spicy that I can't taste the subtler flavors. 

In another review someone complained about only getting one bowl of rice. They do only give one bowl initially--that is so everyone at the table can take some and it's not just sitting there forever getting cold. If you ask for more rice they will give you as much as you want at no extra charge and it will be out about a minute after you request more (edit: apparently they charged for extra for the other reviewer--I don't know if they forget to charge me, don't charge because we are there often, or what).

 I have also seen a few people say that the portions are small. While I personally have always left Lotus full (and sometimes even with leftovers), it is true that the portions are smaller than at your average ten-pound-plate American restaurant. The intended way to eat (at least for the curry and saucy dishes) is that you use the rice to soak up the sauce--and since the sauce is delicious and the rice is unlimited, that is how you fill up if you are still hungry.

The pricing is extremely reasonable. Usually our bill runs about 50$ total--that is INCLUDING tax, tip, appetizer, two entrees, and drinks, and it's easy to keep it under 35$ for two people if you want. I would say this is the most underpriced restaurant in Vegas.

This place is classic, old school Vegas with all of the memorabilia and movie star photos on the walls. It was also featured in Anthony Bourdain's Vegas feature. The food is really good but I wouldn't say phenomenal. I think the draw is the history more than the food.

This place is over rated. If you are from cities with good foods, this place will disappoint you for sure.  We tried Garlic Shrimp, Fried rice, Pad thai, and they tasted all just an average.  The price is expensive too for what you get.  The other Thai restaurant in the commercial center has cheaper and better taste foods.  TOTALLY NOT WORTH THE WAIT. THIS PLACE IS OVERRATED. DONT EXPECT TO BE AMAZED.

This place is the Mecca for all Thai food ! I have been here twice and both times, my experience lived up to all the hype. Their Khao Soi has amazing complex flavors and is the perfect comfort food. Living in Nashville, it's impossible to find khao soi so my husband has very closely replicated this recipe but it's not the original. The staff is so helpful and friendly and their menu is expansive and full of amazing options. I can't say enough good things about Lotus of Siam. It's amazing in every way!

This place makes me happy!

Run down strip mall with an adult day care facility right next door hard to believe the lotus of siam is one of the best seemingly great Thai restaurants in Vegas.

Don't take my word for it go there and look at all the celebrities that have eaten there like New York cities Momofuku's Dave Chang with Lotus's owner and chef Saipien Chutma just hanging on the bottom row as you enter to the left. 

I have eaten there several times and if you can ignore the outside the ambience inside since they remodel is clean, quaint, and slightly upward sit-down nice. 

Food is definitely above par. They have all Thai classics at a standard Thai restaurant price and trust me  you don't JUST come here for the pad Thai and Tom yum. 

Chef special are excellent! Crispy duck in curry woo and the must have---garlic prawns

(Skip this if you don't want to hear about prawns sooooo good) Garlic pawns pricey but worth a drive to Vegas. They shell giant prawns but leave the shells attached. Coat the shelled fish in batter of garlicky goodness (not too much garlic) Deep fried both shells and prawns in extreme intensity so it looks like you have double the shrimp. If you don't like fried yummy shells you may feel a tiny bit jiped but they throw cilantro and green onions to make up for it (jk) the whole thing is delicious and stays crispy for hours. Really. I checked. So delicious.

Overall it's what you expect from a Thai restaurant with a whole LOT you didn't expect. Like a very streamed lined staff. Food took a little time but the servers brought us appetizers, were always accessible, and were knowledgable to point out the water was filtered NOT tap. In a place that is always busy and with an award winning chef it is a culinary experience that is very worth it.
This place really does have great Thai food as well as an extensive wine list. I just wish the portions were a tad larger for the price.

This place rivals some the best joints in LA's Thai Town, but it's a bit overpriced. For the cliffs notes on what to order please see below, and I promise you'll leave  with a full belly and a smile on your face. Also it's ok if you unbutton your pants midway through your meal bro.

The Garlic Prawns 
The Khao Soi Short Ribs 
The Nam Kao Tod (crispy rice) 
The Nam Prik Ong (red chili dip)

APPROVED!!!

This place was amazing!!
Every food item we ordered came out perfect!!
Make sure to order crispy duck Panang!!! We had two orders lol
I can't wait to go back to Vegas and eat more!!!!
This place was fantastic.  Honestly so delicious.

This restaurant is in a unpopulated shopping plaza away from the main strip of vegas. However it is easy to find and there is plenty of parking. The place stays very busy so I'd call ahead and make a reservation. The food we tried was very good, although portion size wasn't that great. The price was a little on the high side considering the dishes that we ordered, but everything was good.

This restaurant is off the strip but definitely a must when you're hungry in Vegas. If you're going to eat here, skip to the back of the menu where the "Northern Thai" dishes and chef selections are because that's what they specialize in. Don't come here for that pad thai or pad see ew stuff. I can go on and on about the spicy garlic prawns - sooo amazing. And the crispy duck curry? Wooow. This place is obviously a local and tourist favorite because the wait time gets pretty long and while we were waiting for a table, others who were waiting with us kept saying this was the only restaurant they eat regularly at.

This restaurant wasn't located in the glitzy part of town. But, don't be fooled by the humble facade. I'd recommend calling beforehand and making reservations as the waiting time was a bit long -- 40 minutes for 3 people -- even on a Monday night.

The inside of the restaurant isn't glitzy either. Except for the glass storage room where they store their wines, the inside definitely needs some modernizing. But, it's clean and roomy.

My friends ordered the Yellow Curry and Pad Thai, while I ordered Sweet and Sour Chicken. The food were served simply: no fancy garnishes or pretentiousness. It was like being served a home-cooked meal. My food was flavorful and tangy. I loved the abundance of vegetables, and the fresh cucumbers were an interesting contrast to the sweet pineapple chunks. My friends devoured their food, and vowed to come more often, especially since they actually live in Vegas.

The service was great. Our server was attentive and friendly. He refilled our rice bowls and drinks when needed. He even boxed up my leftovers for me, and gave me some extra rice to go with it. Overall, I really liked this restaurant, and I understand why it was rated so highly. If I'm ever in Vegas again, I'll definitely be eating here.

This was absolutely delicious! I ordered the crispy duck with chili flakes and mint. WOW is all I can say about that. They have other seasonings for the crispy duck as well, and I really want to try them all. My mouth is watering just thinking about it. My only two complaints are that there was a very long wait just to get in to the restaurant and the portion size was soooo small compared to how expensive it was.  I couldn't help but feel a bit disappointed about that.  But it was WORTH the wait, and I also really loved the atmosphere.

This was the birthday present that I was wishing for. After hearing about this place from multiple people that have been when in the area, we decided to go. First off, this place is a little bit off of the beaten path by Vegas standards, so make sure that you plan for the ride home. It is in a weird shopping center with a gay bar at the end of it. We made a reservation and got in right on time, luckily because there were a boatload of people waiting to get in. 
Service is very good, super fast as they are trained to turn tables. We had wine, which had an impressive selection for what we were expecting, and a squid salad. That was great and literally came out in under 10 min. The rest of the food was amazing. The drunken fish plate was one of the best things that I have ever put in my mouth. The whole meal was spent talking about how great it was. It really is worth the trip/drive out here. I would just make sure that you can get a ride out, as is it is in a weird part of town.

This where I bring all my out of town guests as well where I come to splurge on Lobster and Duck dishes

This place is missing a VALET and that's all, everything is else is on point.

Thought the food was good but just a little too pricey for my taste. Lunch ran about 12 dollars for me versus 8 at Komol right up the street. Still though, a very good meal. Service was also pleasant.

Three of us met for dinner last night so we could share different dishes and try more.  We ordered seven items and asked the server to space them out.  

First was the tom yum kai soup at medium spiciness.  The soup was good, had a fair amount of chicken, but was missing in straw mushrooms.  Before we had much time to enjoy the soup, two more dishes were brought out.  So much for spacing.

The first was nam kao tod which the menu describes as crispy rice mixed with sour cubed pork sausages, cilantro, green onions, grounded dry chilis, ginger, peanuts and lime juice.  The crispy rice were very present but cubed pork was almost flavorless.  The dish was really lacking.  Along with this, we were served the nam prik ong, spicy red chili dip served with vegetables and some fried pork rind.  The chili was flavorful and I found putting it on the rinds was the best way to eat it.  Crunchy texture and heat.

We were then brought the khao soi with beef and the thum ka noon with chicken.  Both dishes were OK.  The winning dish was the khao soi.  Very flavorful with outstanding noodles.  This was one of two dishes that were very good.  I thought the thum ka noon was watery and didn't have a lot of flavor.  

The one dish which was the other star of our meal was forgotten.  We had to have our server come back to the table and remind him that we had ordered the garlic prawns.  We were brought our order.  The prawns were good and the crispy outer shells very delightful.

I had a diet Coke which was refilled several times without asking.  Service was good but I wish they had spaced the dishes out more so we had a little more time with each dish.  

This was my second time at Lotus of Siam.  I think I'd be back only if I wanted to try something different in Thai food.  It was disappointing.
Thus is probably the best Thai restaurant I have been to in the USA, and there have been overt a hundred.  A gem in Las Vegas. Don't be fooled by all the others. I will be back.

Totally overrated. Tried the lobster and was over cooked therefore very dry. The squid salad was very fishy and the consistency chewy. The Tom yum soup was decent as was the crispy duck curry. Will not return.

Tried drunken noodle, spicy chicken wing & crispy duck...great food...i have been here before but forgot to write review and this time this seem to be even better, i think the 108 degree temperature has some effect to this craving for good tasting dinner...i took my time and enjoyed every bite...love the quiet and relaxed ambiance...when you come, take your time and bring lots of company...

Tucked away from the strip in a little mall- this is a hidden gem!

The food is all amazing! Delicious! And spice levels to your taste.

They specialize in Northern Thai- but anything on the menu if good.

Very good Thai food in a shopping center way off the Vegas strip that appears to be a favorite with locals. Amazing garlic crispy prawns, pad see you with beef, pad thai, chicken larb, and BBQ game hen. Service was quick and food was hot and fresh. Very enjoyable meal and reasonably priced.
Very good food.  A little more expensive than I was expecting, but very good food.
Very tasty but a bit busy. The waiter was pretty attentive even with how busy it was.

Very, very good Thai food, but not the best I've had (that honor remains with the much mourned Planet Thailand in Brooklyn). The take-home message: the food is great and there's nothing to complain about, but there's room for improvement here and there in the dishes.

I went with a group, and we shared several dishes. The Pad Thai was very good--fresh, complex, and a good mixture of flavors, though I thought it could have had more depth of flavor--more contrast between sweet and salty, tart and spicy. Our Tom Kah Kai was fabulous--piping hot, spicy, rich and complex. The green papaya salad was fresh and tart, though not quite as flavorful as I would have liked. My Panang curry with chicken was delicious, but extremely spicy even when ordered medium. The service was very good, the beer was cold, and it wasn't too hard finding cabs to take us back to our hotel. Best of all: Lotus of Siam isn't on the Strip!

I'll definitely go back if fate ever forces me to return to Las Vegas.

A note about how I rate: It seems to me that people mean very different things by the stars they give in a review. Here's what I mean: 5 stars means that a place is exceptional in some way, special even among very good peers; 4 stars means that the place is very good in every relevant category but not outstanding or exceptional; 3 stars means adequate--a place I would go to again but not great; 2 stars means unacceptable--a place I would not go again because it is seriously deficient in some way; 1 star is horrible, that the place  was not only unacceptable in some way but that it was exceptionally, unforgivably bad. In every case my rating is comparing the place reviewed to similar places-- thus an outstanding diner gets a 5 even though on an absolute scale its food might not be as good as that at a gourmet restaurant.

WOW! Decided to try this place after all the raving reviews here on Yelp and Tripadvisor. 

It deserves 5 star. Thinking about the thousands of places to eat in Las Vegas, from bottom to high class, Lotus of Siam is just spot on when you're craving for original Thai food. I've been a couple of times to Thailand, and this food was without a doubt perfectly made compared to Thailand. 

Next time I'll be in Vegas, this will be my first place to eat! Yummy!

Was craving for Thai food and we went due to the Yelp reviews!  I usually order just my normal Thai dishes Beef Panang, Papaya Salad, Tom Kha, and Pad Thai. As I was eating I noticed the tables all around me ordered the Fried Garlic Shrimp and thought to myself do I wanna really spend $25.00 for a dish with 6-8 shrimps?????  Whoa was I wrong thee best $25.00 I spent on a shrimp fish and hands down the best Fried Shrimp I have had!!!  I will be back and just order two orders of the Shrimp and Pad Thai and I will be one happy camper!!!!

Was driving through Las Vegas and have been wanting to go here for years and had to make the small detour. It did not disappoint. 

I kept it simple with the soft shell crab over drunken noodles and it was pretty fantastic. The crab was cooked perfectly and the flavor on the noodles and accompanying vegetables was great with a perfect spice level to my liking. Can't remember exactly what my wife got but I do recall constantly reaching over to take more.

Really the only reason I want to drive to California again is to stop here. Also the food came out incredibly fast.
We did have high expectation's due to the Yelp reviews but it didn't meet our expectations at all. We will keep our business at Ping Kao.

We experienced a hugely overrated large Thai Restaurant with a simple and airy atmosphere. The food I ordered was cooked "Thai Street Food" style. I know this, actually having lived almost a year in Bangkok, Thailand. Not only did our waiter lie to us about the our order, but charged us a dollar more than the menu price without warning. It was not even a holiday. My glass was dirty, almost an hour to be seated, and a long wait time for an order of (obviously  cooked pre-order) "Thai BBQ Chicken". The off-flavor Papaya Salad was a (time and labor saving) stick cut (julienne) instead of Shredding the Papaya! ...and it was the tiniest papaya Salad that I ever saw. The soup, Yen-ta-fo, was missing essential items, including meat and fish balls. A big bowl of noodles with two shrimp and a few small bits of meat and a cheaper vegetable replacement. A real rip-off.

We had been looking forward to going here after all the talk, press and reviews and it did not disappoint. My parents (who have never eaten Thai and are quite picky) even loved it and said it was their best meal in Vegas. All of our dishes were great, Thai spaghetti, pad see ew, papaya salad, sweet and sour chicken, and one more I forget, were all great! Service is also impeccable! Try to get off the strip and make it to this awesome hole in the wall if you are visiting (I almost don't want to share that because I don't want the wait to become crazy.)

We have lived in vegas for 6 years and always heard great things about this place. We finally tried it tonight and it was AMAZING!!!! The only reason why I gave it 4 out of 5 stars is bc of the location. It's a little sketchy but don't let that fool u. Inside is beautiful! There is almost always a wait but def worth waiting for. They have a cute little bar you can have a drink at while waiting. I def recommend trying the shrimp pad Thai and the crispy duck! YUM :)
We loved this place! We did the garlic prawns and the crispy duck curry dish and it was all so yummy! Went at lunch and it was crowded but no wait!
Well what can I say !? Just Absolutely Fantastic. What to eat? order what you know or try something new, you simply can not go wrong.
Went for lunch. Had the Khao Soi. It was excellent. Service was fast and friendly. I would definitely go back. Don't judge this place by the exterior. The inside is very nice and comfortable.

Went there for the first time, tonight, with a friend. In a word, awesome! Had the number 55, which was beef and I think Cilantro and some other stuff I can't remember, but it was amazing. Had the yellow curry with chicken as well, both dishes done to a number 2 out of 10 heat level. I'd been told they really crank up the heat and so we went for a low number. Turns out I could have gone up several notches with that, but even at level 2 there was definitely some spice and flavor. 

Anyway, great food, friendly and prompt service, and I will absolutely be going there again.

What a find!!
On vacation in Vegas & we always try a thai place everywhere we go. Always met with disappointment. EXCEPT HERE! IT WAS SO GOOD!!
First time we have found a restaurant that tastes VERY close to our favorite place at home.
Soups & spring rolls were wonderful, shrimp pad thai was yummy & my veggie drunken noodles were on point! 
I wish they delivered to our hotel lol

What's not to like about this place!! The food is fantastic, great menu items. We usually come for a special occasion because it's a tad bit far for us. We recommend all of our friends when coming from out of town to try it.

What. The. Heck?? Why is this place so popular? I had to find out. My in-laws made a reservation here for the six of us to try Lotus of Siam's most popular dishes. We ordered what all yelpers suggest- Northern Thai food:

1. Khao Soi- best dish of the night. The curry base was delicious- not overpowering. very creamy. I've had better khao soi in LA. 

2. Northern larb (I didn't try it but it was well received by the others in our group).

3. Kang Ka Noon (spicy jack fruit curry with chicken)- Just ok. They warned us this dish is more of a soup, and it is. It is difficult to finish this dish without a spoon. The dish isn't spicy as advertised- maybe they tone it down intentionally? Either way, this dish, to me, was like a thin tomato soup with jack fruit. Not worth the $$.

4. Nam Prik Ong (red chili dip)- is described as being the least spicy, and it's true. No spice as all. It is, however, a nice dip for the veggies, but it is way too much ($10.95) for what is basically a side dish. 

5. Drunken Noodle Prawns- the famous deep fried prawns with drunken noodles. Yes, they are good, but not amazingly good. Definitely crunchy, juicy and flavorful, but I've had much better fried prawns at other restaurants, and definitely cheaper. There were probably three prawns in the dish and about 6 pieces of just the shell. And $25.95 for essentially three prawns is a rip off. Also-- there was probably two drunken noodles on the plate. 

6. Drunken Noodle Soft Shell Crab- More drunken noodles than crab. However, if you like your noodles very slippery and gummy, get the drunken noodles. This was the spiciest of our dishes and to me the tastiest. They cooked the crabs well, but no claw meat- mostly the smaller legs. I've had soft shell crab at other restaurants in LA that was much more generous with their crab. 

Overall, the food was OK, but I can't justify waiting for hours to eat here. The portion sizes are small. No, I'm not talking small compared to American sized portions-- they are small compared to what I had in Northern Thailand. You can get much better food at other restaurants with less of a wait and for less $$. Don't buy into the hype!

When I read this had been voted as the best Thai restaurant in the country, this place deserved a visitation. Another off the strip place that had me question if our cab driver was abducting us... The restaurant itself is very unassuming from the outside in a strip mall however all that pleasantly changes once you enter.

The decor is a marriage between the classic Italian restaurants in Chicago that adorn their wall with all the celebrities who have been there and a Classic Thai restaurant you would expect to find. A massive wine cellar in the dinning area adds a unique dimension. 

The service here is impeccable. Our server Somchai was extremely gracious, relaxed and accommodating body language. We accidentally ordered the wrong appetizer which he gladly took back and got us the Nam Prik Ong, ground pork with a red tomato sauce curry served with vegetables and pork rinds to dip, very unique. For entrees we went with the drunk noodles with Seabass and the crispy mint duck. When I say they're both made to perfection, I mean it is perfection. We chose spice level of 5 out of 10 which worked out nicely to blend with the flavor without being too overpowering.

This is a must for folks traveling to Vegas.

When a restaurant - that is in Las Vegas - NOT on the strip and is NOT flashy at all - have over 2000 reviews .. it say a lot about the place!!! ... And yes I was NOT disappointed ..

One of the BEST Thai food I have had in the US ... excellent service and very affordable. The chef and owner used to be a chef for the King of Thailand - a fact that becomes more evident when you taste the food!

Their menu has more variety of Thai food than the number of beers listed in NYC's celebrated Beer bars! - some stand out items - NAM KAO TOD (crispy rice), Deep fried whole red snapper topped with homemade fresh chili and Thai basil, satay, Prawn Garlic Thai style .. etc.. 

So the bottom-line is - If you are in Vegas - skip the madness of the strip and try food here ... its worth the trip!

IMPORANT: DO MAKE SURE THAT YOU HAVE A TABLE RESERVED WELLLLL IN ADVANCE !!

When my husband and I go to Vegas, it is a GUARANTEE that we will stop here for lunch before we check into our hotel. We seriously love this place. The food and service is just awesome. It's tricky to find as it's in a large strip mall, kind of in the back... it's hard to explain. We have trouble finding it every time we go, but it is still worth it. The vegetarian menu is amazing. You have to try this place!

When we arrived at 5:28 there were about 50 people already in line.  The line moves pretty quickly and we were told that our wait would be around 45 min.  However, after 20 min they texted that a table was available.  The reviews for the crispy duck panang curry were spot on.  The duck was nice and crispy and we got spicy level 4 out of 10 for the panang which was perfect.  The panang had a creamy consistency and a great balance of sweetness and spice.  We even put the panang on our sea bass that came with our drunken noodles.  It was fried with mild seasoning but tender as well.  The noodles were more saucy than I've had at other Thai restaurants but still wonderful.  The garlic scallops were delicious as well.  You could really taste the garlic and cilantro. The scallops were seared perfectly.  Great crust and super tender inside.  The star of the meal was the garlic prawns- OMG.  So amazing!!   Crispy and perfectly seasoned!!!  It was fun to see Saipin walking around and all her pictures with celebrities on the wall.  She has one with Elvis!!
Worth the 90 minute wait. Food was delicious, authentic and amazing.  Wish my stomach could have held more!

Worth the drive to the middle of nowhere in Vegas, and despite the location, the food is so good there is still a 45 min wait for a table. 

Close your eyes and order and enjoy.
Worth the wait if you want great Thai food! Curry crispy duck is soooo good! One of the great fines in Vegas. Dont let the outside deceive you.

Wow - this place is definitely worth the hype!  A group of 10 of us ate here last week and enjoyed so many different things on the menu.  The standouts for me were the chicken potstickers, satay, rad na, pad see ew, yellow curry and the crab and pineapple fried rice.  The menu is extensive, so my friends who have eaten here before selected our food for us and they didn't lead us astray.  The lemon sake we had with our meal was downright incredible too.  This is certainly a place to check out in Vegas!

Wow! What they said. All they said and more

Get here. Fly, walk, ride a camel. Just get here.

You will be back.

Wow!!!! This is the best "Northern Thai" cuisine in Las Vegas!!!!
I put emphasis on the term Northern Thai because that's their specialty,
Although, you can order great Southern Thai food here like Pad Thai or Kung Pao but it doesn't meet the high expectation.

Having watched the Andrew Zimmern and Anthony Bourdain videos, I had to check this place out.
It's recommended to make reservations in advance otherwise you better call ahead and be there by 5:00pm sharp to avoid long wait times. 

I asked the waitress whats the most popular and she gave me these suggestions.
She didn't disappoint me and the food was out of this world. 

Nam Prik Noom (Green Chili Dip) - Fantastic! 
Crispy Duck Panang - (Best Panang I've ever had!)
Garlic Prawns - (Mountain of spices with texture like a potato chip!)

Wow, where to even begin? We saw Lotus of Siam when searching Thai food in Las Vegas on Google. I thought it was this place I went to last year, but as it turns out, this one was different. I'm glad I didn't try to nail down the other place and we just ate here. The wontons and egg rolls were deliciously crisp and fresh. The sweet and sour sauce was to die for.

Then we moved on to dinner. The Beef Pad Thai was superb and the spicy fried rice with chicken was excellent. The presentation of everything was elegant and the taste was fantastic. The service was outstanding and efficient. They tend to get very busy here - there was a line running out the door the entire time we were here. We got here at 5:30p opening and there was already a line. Overall, it was a very pleasing experience and we would return.

Yes it has a bazillion awards, yes Anthony Bordain, Max Jacobson, and tons of other food critics have said this is the place to go. Yes it really took me this long to try it. And yes, you can kick me for it! (as long as you bring some wings when you do). 
Ok, first, let me tell you the story of many years ago. My mom took me here for the lunch buffet. I stuck my nose up like, what the heck is my mom trying to get me to eat here. Well let's just say I made a recent call to my mom saying, "I am so sorry I didn't like Thai food at a younger age, you were right". I am sure she enjoyed that. 
I have yet to come here for dinner, and I have yet to try any of these specials that are frequently talked about. However, in the past two weeks, I have come here 3 times for lunch. I get my usual that I normally get when eating Thai food. Garlic & black pepper chicken, green beans and beef, basil fried rice, drunken noodles, or yellow curry. Just a few classic personal favs. I have plans on venturing into the Northern Thai portion of their menu. I recently had their wings as an appetizer. I brought back the three leftover wings to co-workers. Three out of three of them asked where those amazing sweet chili wings came from. I will win them over bringing leftovers from this place. 
Now, let's talk about spice! If you have read any of my reviews, you know I like SPICY!! It grinds my gears when I go to eat any place, they claim something is spicy, and it doesn't make me sweat. Don't tease me! I usually get anywhere from a level 6 to 8. In the past, Pan Asian has been the only place I have had to step back, wipe off the sweat, and shake the hand of the chef to thank them. Well, on my first experience here at LOS, I knew, I had found a place on my level. 
I ordered my pepper chicken at a level 7, and let's just say my Thai ice tea did not last over half my meal. From now on, I will stick with a level 5 or 6 here. Well done Lotus of Siam. There is a competitor in the parking lot, and their level 8 did not even make me turn red. (CUE WAMP WAMP MUSIC)
I will keep you updated as I try more authentic stuff on the menu. However, if your a white girl (or guy), who can handle spice, and loves Thai- GET HERE ASAP! Thank me later!
You won't regret coming here. Perfect for casual dining and business engagements. A huge selection of food, and it looks like they do it all right.

You'd never expect such a small place to be so great! It truly is "a hidden gem". Hubby and I decided to take some take out on our way home and ended up waiting 40 minutes for an order of Chicken Satay and Chicken Panang Curry. They were so busy, and even had taxis dropping off customers on site! The only downfall to this restaurant was the entrance and first impression of it. You walk into a cramped entrance and get greeted by three ladies who weren't very professional or good at speaking English. It would've been nice to have been explained certain other menu options. Although I'd have to say the food we got was definitely worth the wait.
Hopefully next time we could try something new !

You've got to stray from the strip for this one, but it is definitely worth it. On Sundays they open at 5:30. Our group of 12 arrived at 5pm to see many people already lining up! There is one line for reservations, which they will let in first, and 1 line for people without. Don't let the shabby strip mall fool you, this Northern Thai restaurant is worth heading out to. You can tell that it is where the locals go.

The food came out hot and fast. We ordered A LOT. For many dishes you can choose your numbered spice level, so we often ordered a few of the same dishes at different levels. My favorite dish was the Garlic Prawns. These were full of garlic flavor, large and crunchy from being fried. Many in the group enjoyed the Crispy Duck in Panang Curry. The duck is served on top, and you mix it all into the curry. Crying Tiger Beef was another favorite of mine. While it was one of the more simple dishes, the thin beef was perfectly cooked to medium rare, and the jus on the side completed the dish. 

For dessert, I loved the Coconut Ice Cream. They make it with real coconut. It was so light and icy, almost a sorbet texture, while being full of coconut flavor. A great find and a great meal overall.
awesome and authentic- You want to try this!  We went without reservations and it was worth the wait-- looks like the out-of-towners of found this place and are turning it into a Mecca for Thai
best thai food on the face of the earth, without question - that is all.
fab as advertised
great place - order off the back of the menu!

i must say it is between a 3.5-4, not a 5 stars, because they are pricier than some of the other thai places I eat , there food is not that much better.. Service was prompt. the neighborhood is a little shady, the sign posted at the front door says there has been car breakins, make sure you don't leave any valuables in car..I don't recall any real lunch special, but lots of item to select from off the main menu, pretty much a la carte.. Plenty of parking

looked ghetto from the outside but when we ate here Thursday afternoon not even weekends and late night it was already packed! reservations is a must but they will only hold the table for 5 mins which makes sense! so here we go, food! we ordered Thai iced tea, pretty good but not free refill.. ordrered pad Thai, garlic crispy prawns, beef fried rice... the pad Thai is good but the serving is so little it's good for one person only! garlic crispy shrimp is the best. I can eat this all day... it's so good that even the shell of the shrimp, u can eat it. the beef fried rice is ok. little bit oily! the dining area is ok. old fashioned typical Asian resto. their walls are filled with pictures of celebrities like Anthony Bourdain and Nicolas cage to name a few! they have a wine cellar inside.. it looks clean. kitchen is busy! fast service.. eat and go kinda of thing. the servers doesn't really say anything unless u order something. I felt rushed when we came coz we're waiting for some more people to come, they look like they are worried that ur gonna stay there for an hour! overall, good food but very pricey! for 5 dishes including 1 dessert and 3 Thai iced tea, our bill is a whopping 150$... I'm not even full.. but tasty! so 4 stars!!!

lotus of siam has the best thai food in las vegas! been going there since it opened, and SAIPAN CHUTIMA and her family rocks the boat!!she has  been the top thai chef in las  vegas for years, and never fails to amaze with her delicious dishes. the wine list, especially the whites is superb.everything on the menu is top quality, and authentic tasting!!! thanks siapan and girls for a wonderful dining experience!!!!

this is such a piece of jewel in the desert island. We came here after watching parts unknown, and the restaurant does live up to the reputation. Food is extremely out of the league, the portion is moderate while fulfilling, and we got to see the chef as well. Highly recommended. 
For visitors:
- dinner starts at 5:30 on weekend, but it's always lined up with customers 15min prior to 5:30.
- they take reservation 2-3 weeks ahead of time.
- it's like 20 USD by cab from strip.
too expensive and the lunch buffet helped offset the costs but now that is gone.
season2
2nd visit for us during the 4th of July week! This time I had garlic drunken noodle.  It was delish!

4.5 stars!
Great restaurant! The outside is a little funky and the interior is not fancy at all. However the food is fantastic! Very authentic Thai food. We had spring rolls which were crisp and delicious. Pineapple fried rice and drunken noodles with prawns which was absolutely fantastic! 
Again this is not a high end experience restaurant just a gem off the strip with really good Thai food that is reasonably priced.

4.5 stars

Garlic prawns 5 stars
Sliced garlic beef 5 stars
Tum yum noodle soup 4 stars
Chili mussels 3 stars

Been to Vegas many times and this is my first time here. Will definitely be returning on future trips. Service is friendly and fast.

5 stars here for the Crispy Garlic Shrimp & for making my cousin/family believers in their first Thai food experience. I've never had shell on shrimp like this & would recommend it to anyone. Also, the Khao Soi with Duck was as good as Anthony Bourdain's reaction to it lead me to believe. Staff was very quick & friendly, which was saying something for how busy they were on a Monday night. When in Vegas, get off the strip & check this spot out

A far travel to go eat for Thai food. The interior looked really nice and had authentic decorations. At first the place seems small but has a lot of space. We were seated quickly as well.

SERVICE
Friendly and prompt. Waiters and waitresses checked on us regularly.

FOOD
I enjoyed the fish cake, but it was a little on the saltier side for me. The chili sauce it comes with paired well. The garlic prawns were good and crispy (nice texture), I think they're known for their shrimps mostly. The papaya salad (my favorite Thai dish) was disappointing. The flavor was not what I was used to and there was so much sauce which made it liquidly. The coconut tom yum with chicken was good. You can really taste the coconut milk but the soup was too sour (probably from the lime).

CONCLUSION
Good ambience, but I will come again to give this place another shot for their food.

A hidden gem for the adventurous.  I had been forewarned that the restaurant was in a kind of seamy strip mall, but was world class.

It lived up to its billing.  It specializes in a wide range of Thai food, particularly from the north.  We let the waiter suggest an appetizer.  It was so good, we decide to let them impress us with whatever they wanted to bring.

It was amazing, one of the best dining experiences that I have had in years.

A must for lovers of Thai cuisine. Lotus is the real deal, authentic through and through. The flavors may even surprise you, if you have not had true Thai food before. The menu is large but perhaps the most noteworthy dishes are the distinctive Northern Thai options. I never miss the Tom Kha soup, Nam Kao Tod, Garlic Prawns, Khao Soi. Enjoy a Thai Tea or a very refreshigng Tsing Ha to drink, not to mention the excellent wine list.
There is often a wait but that speaks for itself. When locals to wait to eat somewhere, there's a reason. Much has been written about this humble location and it's award winning chef, Saipin Chutima, and the hype is real. Service has generally been quite good, sometimes slow, and yes without reservations you can wait awhile for a table. However, they also offer take out so you can happily place an order and simply pick up your food which I do often.

ABSOLUTELY incredible food. Interesting sort of cafe environment in a not so great area in Las Vegas, but the authentic cuisine brings people from all over to this dumpy area of town. That must mean they think the food is very good. I obviously agree.
AMAZING! Best Thai Food EVER!! Excellent service and reasonable prices. Well worth the trip off the strip to eat at this gem!
Absolutely AMAZING.  Best Thai food I've ever had in the states.  Reasonably priced too and remarkable service.
Absolutely awesome!!!
Absolutely delicious food. Everything on the menu is so good. Can't wait to go back and try more things.

Absolutely delicious!!! I'm craving it RIGHT NOW! We first heard of this place on the airplane while eavesdropping, then our friend we were meeting for dinner suggested it. We typically go to fancy restaurants when we meet up with them, but we were totally down to try this place because we know she knows GOOD FOOD.

When we got in the taxi from the Wynn hotel, the taxi service man told us that it was voted the #1 Thai restaurant by Zagat for over 10 years. WE were sold!

It DID NOT disappoint! They have the biggest selection of Thai food and wine! We paired are good with Riesling which was so delicious for balancing the flavor. 

I can't wait to come back here. The wait IS long. We went at 9:45pm which is when they take the last table searing. The restaurant closes at 10pm
Absolutely the best thai food I have ever had in Las Vegas. Fresh, clean and good service.

After Lotus of Siam blew up from Bourdain's visit, it just doesn't seem to cut it like it used to, and I've been here before the hype and after, like when it was difficult to get a cab to pick you up after that glorious meal. 

While they still kill it with their northern menu dishes, I feel like the prices have spiked and the servings have shrunk the last 1-2 years. This is a shame because the flavor is still there. 

I wish they wouldn't skimp out on the servings like the crispy duck dishes or would add more noodles to the noodle dishes. I feel like they are just mass producing since they are turning tables constantly throughout the night. 

Overall I would come again but only if making a reservation is easy. Not worth it to do a walk-in, which will cost you 60-75 minutes of time waiting.

After only hearing reviews upon reviews for the past several years, we finally made our way to the infamous Lotus! We ordered the Tom Yum soup, pad thai, another soup based noodle dish (I can't remember the name of) and the garlic prawns.

The tom yum soup, slightly different flavor from what we were used to, but it was still really good. Pad thai, not the very best, yet it still ranks up there. The other noodle dish, wasn't the best, that's probably why I couldn't remember the name of it. Lastly, the star of the show, the garlic prawns! Very tasty and filling, one complaint that I do have about it was that it was a little dry and over cooked. The prawns didn't have that moist, buttery taste to it. 

It's a very busy place, if you make a reservation and you're five minutes late, you'll lose your reservation. The popularity of this place is well deserved, yet I cannot claim it was the best Thai restaurant I've ever been to. Yet, it is a legacy restaurant and if you're ever in Vegas, you have to try it at least once.

After seeing so much good reviews on yelp & on the media I decided to check this place out. The location is very concealed away from the strip. I had a bit of a hard time looking for it but after a few rounds in the shopping center I've seen the green light!! I came around dinner time 8ish to be exact. There was a wait and a bunch of people already waiting in the waiting, I was not surprised. I waited less than the 30min they said it would take to be seated. I was very amused at how fast I was able to be seated. The inside of the restaurant is nice and big. I didn't realize it could seat a lot of people AND I MEAN A LOT!! It was packed for a Monday night. 

As soon as we got seated I quickly glanced over the menu and ordered right away. I was very hungry. I ordered the papaya salad, charbroiled pork, red curry, and Tom yum. Let's start with the papaya salad. My server asked what spice level I would like my Papaya salad to have ranging from a 1-10, I said a 3. When I took my first bite of the salad I was expecting a mild taste, but no it felt like a burning 10!!! The spice was too overpowering and I could hardly taste the real flavor of the salad. I had a Thai iced tea on the side & I literally gulped more than half just so my mouth could cool down. I was very upset :( I love papaya salad and just having this to be too spicy really just killed my appetite. I ordered the red curry with beef. I was scared that it was going to be really spicy like the papaya salad but it wasn't at all! It had a small hint of spicy. It was so creamy and delicious. Just thinking about it is making my mouth salivate. The charbroiled pork was amazing as well! But I could compare it to other charbroiled pork I've had at other Thai/Vietnamese restaurants. The only thing that stood out about it was the dipping sauce. I'm not quite sure what type of sauce it was but it had green onions and was a cross between salty, sour, and sweet. The Tom yum was ok. Like other yelpers have mention it's nothing that's great. 

The customer service was spectacular. We always had our waters and rice refilled & asked how we were doing. 

Will definitely come back here again & try the northern menu like others have suggested.

All I want to say is... NO!!
What a MASSIVE disappointment! Best Thai food in LV??? In the US??? NOT! 
The place is nestled in a scary abandoned looking strip mall. Real seedy joint. We almost didn't go in based on that. We should've kept our 1st mind. I know there are loads of positive reviews here... Trust them at your own risk.

We came for early dinner on Friday. No waiting. Great! The sever... Well it took us till the end of dinner to determine who our server really was... He was the worst part of our experience. We ordered Pad Thai, Panang curry, and Seafood Thai Fried Rice. The Pad Thai smelled awful. We didn't eat it. Wanted to send it back, but we were told by the server "It's not my fault, you ordered, someone has to pay for it." Excuse me?!? Nuff said. We'll NEVER BE BACK. Asked for the manager, and we were treated like criminals.

The portions here are small for the prices. Truly nothing to swoon over as far as taste. I've learned that Food Network is not always right. Restaurants probably pay to be on TV. 
I'm sure they weren't treated the way we were for not liking an entree'.

Someone suggested Archie's to us. We'll try them next time we're in Vegas. Stay away from this place!!

Always have to stop by this place when I go to Vegas.
Their curry is not as good as couple Thai restaurants I have been to. But other stuffs are really good. Khao soi is my favorite here. Service is wonderful. Very busy in the weekend.
Amazing Food but be ready to wait to be seated.
Amazing Food! You would never know how great this place is based on it's outward appearance and location but the inside is upscale, elegant and the some of the best thai food in the city!

Amazing Thai food!  Had so many great dishes.  Really enjoyed the Crispy Rice, Coconut Soup, Fresh Spring Rolls, Yellow Curry, Sea Bass Drunken Noodle and Pad Thai.  What really impressed me was what happened when I was leaving.  Because we were a group of 6, gratuity was added to my bill.  I didn't notice and added and additional 20% gratuity.  As I was walking out the door, the server ran up to me and showed me gratuity was included.  Wow!  How is that for integrity!  I will most definitely return to this amazing hidden gem!

Amazing food & decent service.  Make sure you have reservations, there was a line out the door when we arrived and the wait was 2 hours.  The star dish of the night was the drunken noodle soft shell crab but everything was wonderful and seasoned exactly to our taste. Service was friendly and efficient but it was not responsive for refill requests, and replacement forks.  All in All we had a wonderful time and will definitely be dining here every time we are in Vegas in the future.
Amazing food and service. Get there early, or call to make reservation. Green curry was cook to perfection. We also ordered the crispy duck with the drunken noodle WOW! Simply wow!
Amazing food! I recommend a reservation as it will take a while if you just walk in... but it's so worth the wait.
Amazing food. Pineapple fried rice was really good. Worth the wait.

Amazing northern tai food. Cab ride from the strip but worth it. Be careful on the spicy level. I did 4 and It was too hot to eat. Service was great and our dishes were delicious. Had the red chili dip (not spicy) , curry, garlic prawns and coconut soup.

Amazing. Just go. Yes the area surrounding it is a little sketchy, but I mean, you are in Vegas, and what trip to Vegas isn't filled with a little adventure and outside of the norm experiences?

Anyways, get there early as the place is packed. Don't let the wait scare you, put your name in and they will call/text you. We decided to use the wait time to go get our marriage license. You don't have to follow in our footsteps, but then again, you are in Vegas. ;)

Food wise I had the Kang Ka Noon, veggie style. My not-yet-wife at the time had the Khoa Soi.
Both were great but I can easily see that the meat free dishes take a distant backseat to all the other amazing choices.
Another great night with the fam and a meal with garlic prawns, chilean sea bass, pad thai, fried chicken wings. Would recommend to get a different sauce for the wings and the sea bass.

Another spot we visited on our trip to Vegas. Coming from San Diego and living by quite a few Chinese/Asian restaurants and having a Chinese girlfriend I expect certain things at a restaurant like this. There stuffed chicken wings were freaking amazing. I would go back for those but only those. There sticky rice was hard and dry, there garlic wings were the same. The garlic wings looked as if they had made a huge batch hours before we ordered them and they had them under a heat lamp waiting to be ordered. They tasted the way they look, dry and old. There spicy fried rice was ok, but for $13 dollars anywhere back in San Diego I would have gotten three times the amount. Definitely not worth what you pay for it. The service was also weird. Both the guy serving our food and the other guy who was walking around, looking like a manager of some sort. They just had very odd personalities and seemed a bit unsure about every thing lol.
As good as promised.  We ate family style and every dish was amazing.  The wine list is tough to beat.

As usual the best rated restaurants don't live up to it's rank. It was ok, nothing to die for. The garlic shrimp with shell on was certainly very shelly. Was wondering if someone might choke on it and die. 

The coconut soup had chicken so over cooked and dry, where is the art of cooking?

Was expecting exceptional, turns out to be slightly above average. The portions are smaller and the prices are over double the average. This is for a restaurant located in a dumpy old mall.

Ate here Monday 31st August 2015 and wow it was busy, we had to wait a little bit for a table so I can only imagine what a weekend would be like. There were 6 of us. The 5 other people I dined with are American and i'm British.
