I had plan to eat here twice this time and my wife talked about it for the last 3 years she wants to go back to this place to eat.  However, the food disappoints.  I didn't believe my brother, who lives in Vegas; he said that  it is not the same as before.

I always heard about this place while in Vegas, but never ventured far enough off strip until recently to try it. 

The place is small and in a strip mall. The road to get there is slightly confusing and it feels like you're in a factory. The inside is quite nice but small, luckily there was no line.

We ordered a curry and a noodles dish. Serving sizes are smaller than we are used to compared to our normal Thai place in Los Angeles. Food was good, but not worth the "hype". In comparison, we still prefer our normal place in Los Angeles - Original Hoy Ka Noodles (see review).

Worth trying for the hype, and the northern dishes. Slightly more pricey.

I am never disappointed eating at Lotus. This is the only restaurant I have eaten at two nights in a row. The only restaurant I will wait an hour to get in.  I have eaten here at least a dozen times over the last three years. I always go with big groups no one has ever been disappointed. The garlic prawns, drunken noodle shrimp, Tom Kai soup and sea bass are amazingly good. I don't eat duck I really don't like it normally, but here they make it so juice and good that I love it.  I love the Chang beer it goes perfect with your meal. I recently have tried the rice with mango and it was delicious.

Hands down my go to restaurant when I am visiting Vegas.

I ate here with six other people, and we all split our plates with each other. We had a couple of curry dishes (wonderful) the crispy garlic shrimp (amazing), and the drunken shrimp (I think, it was right next to the garlic shrimp on the menu). We all loved the food and had a great meal. I'd recommend going with a big group so that you can try a lot of things on the menu.

I came here with my family and the dishes are quite good for an Asian restaurant in the States.  They have good interior design - it's much better inside than the outside so don't get discouraged when you stand outside the restaurant!

I came here with my team on the last night of our conference. Those who have been here were raving about the place so I was pretty excited to finally eat here. It really did not disappoint. Every single dish we ordered was good. 
We had a party of 9 so we were able to sample a number of dishes. We ordered Nam Kao Tod - spicy crispy rice dish - definitely recommend this!
Tom Kah Khai - Chicken soup with coconut milk - I usually don't like this dish but I like the way they make it. 
Chicken larb - ground chicken dish
Pad Kee Mao - stir fried "drunken" noodles
Chili fried rice
Garlic prawn - shell-on deep fried shrimp
Crispy duck with Penang curry
Beef with string beans - can't remember the exact name of the dish
I liked every single item we ordered and will definitely try to make a trip there again when I go to Vegas. The only thing was - I feel like their portion is considerably smaller than other Thai restaurants. But the taste and quality definitely makes up for it. Reservations recommended for big groups. If you are travelling to Vegas for work, this offers more bang for the buck than eating on the strip.
I can't vouch for authenticity because my experience with Thai food is admittedly fairly limited, but it's simply delicious.  One of my favorite places to eat.

I definitely would give this place a five star. Wait staff is attentive and the food was delicious. Hands down the best Thai food I've had ever! We waited an hour to eat but we were seated at the bar while we waited for a table. Great spot to converse and drink wine and beer. 

The food did not fall short of expectations, it actually surpassed it. The atmosphere was very appealing. From the outside it looks like a hole in the wall, but it was actually very roomy and the decor was beautiful. Not to mention all the pictures of celebrities in their restaurant.

I would definitely recommend their crispy duck Panang curry and soft shell crab drunken noodles. You cannot go wrong with these dishes. It's very appealing to the taste buds, I never knew duck could taste so good!!! 

I look forward to becoming a regular here!

I did it! I went to a sketchy strip mall where pple almost hit our car twice because they were in a hurry to get to the liquor store across the mall. Outside and inside are day and night. Like another yelper said - wanna be fancy. We ordered over $100 worth of food and over all 2 were ok dishes - drunken noodle prawns and sticky rice and mango for dessert... For all the hype and what not really not worth it. Most of these wonderful awards they've won stopped around a few years ago. 

I'd say for the thrill of almost getting killed from the drivers and the sketchiness of the area. Stay for the adult day care located next door.

I don't understand where all the 4 to 5 stars are basing their taste buds on. When I first walked in, I could smell the musky coach roach scent in the air. I have the nose of a K9. Then the man who showed me to the table was rude. Maybe because I am also Asian and he thought I not worthy. He showed me the table and stopped me in mid stride as I was walking to it so that he could walk there first. Utterly ridiculous. 

I always ordered my Pad Thai with less sweet because most places dump a bucket load of sugar into this dish. No exception here. I specifically asked for less sugar but it came out a lot sweeter than I had asked. I just don't get it. Most other dishes I ordered are too sweet for my preference.

When we were done and the waiter was not around, I went up to the cashier to pay. The young cashier girl told me to go back because apparently only the waiter could give me my check. House rules? Are they trying to run it like a 5 stars restaurant when the  smell of roaches waft in the air and foods are subpar at best? To add insult to injury, they tagged on 18% gratuity. Gratuity should never be mandatory. If they want to make it mandatory at the very least, treat their customers better. Needless to say, this is my first and last visit. If there's a zero star or less, I would give it that.

I'm from LA where even the mid tier Thai restaurants are head and shoulders above this place. Pass this place if you're thinking of Thai food. You deserve better foods and better service.

I finally got to eat at Lotus of Siam this weekend and very glad that I did. 

First, I recommend making a reservation or prepare to wait in the long line outside. I book a reservation in advance and we sat down once our time came up. 

My friends and I ordered a lot of food. I had the Green Curry with chicken and it was delicious. We finished our meal with the dessert combo, which included fried bananas, mango sticky rice, and coconut ice cream. It was the best ever. 

It was definitely worth coming off strip to eat here. Would definitely come here again!

I got the crispy duck khao moi and it was absolutely delicious. One of the best dishes I've had across different cultural eating. Great spice for me personally at 6/10 stars. I probably could have done the 7/8 but I didn't want to ruin my first experience by overdoing it. The duck was very crispy on the outside and the meat was still tender and juicy. The flavor of the curry was great and wasn't just spice. The noodles and pickled vegetables were a good balance to my palate. Great dish. Only comment on the bad side is that he cost of this dish is in the high 20's so I wanted to order more but would have ended up having a tab of almost 70 bucks for two dishes and an appetizer.

I had my doubts about this place seeing that it was a rundown strip mall. The location is a little bit on the shady side. Not exactly a place I would walk around alone at night time; however, we went for lunch so I was safe side. My friends had been talking about it for months on how amazing this place is but as a California resident I never come out as often as I'd like. I finally got to try it the other day, and all I can say is that this place is just RIDICULOUSLY AMAZING!!! 

We had drunk noodles with Chilean Sea Bass, soft crab, crispy duck with panning curry, crab fried rice, garlic prawns, and the garlic beef to share between 6 guys. Normally, I would say Thai dishes specializes in a few things and I would be able to rate between least favorite to most, but I have to say everything was simply delicious. Between 6 guys it wasn't a lot, but just right. It was really something where you could appreciate each dish by itself. Eating it together was just heaven. 

I would say it's a little on the pricey side. We shared between 6 guys with each person getting a Thai iced tea or coffee and it came out to $200 or $33 per person. I suppose it could be cheaper if you go a la carte, but if you want to do Thai family style then you order dishes on dishes, but as a once in a while thing when I go to Vegas: WORTH IT! 

I can't wait to come out again and bring some of my friends to go visit the place. Real subtle twists on already tasty Thai food favorites. It was a real great end to an already successful trip!
I had the crispy duck and garlic prawns. They were very tasteful. However expensive for small portions.

I have finally made it here. My first time and it was good. I am a novice to Thai food. I did follow the advice and ordered off the northern Thai part of the menu. I had the northern sausage, the red chili dip, crispy duck with mint and Thai basil and chili. I finished off with mango and sticky rice topped with coconut milk and mong bee seeds. 

I got the heat at 2-3. Next time I'll go for 4-5.

I heard about this place on The Best I Ever Ate on the food network so I was super excited to try it out. It's of the strip away from the glitz of Vegas. even with that I was a little dismayed when I saw the exterior. IM GLAD I did not let that dissuade me. once you get through the door it's a nice clean grade A establishment and the food are AWESOME . if you go to Las Vegas Please give them a try the food is great and the staff is very friendly and inviting even when they are super super busy. the stuffed chicken wings are a MUST!!! I will always come here when I visit Sin City. I hope you will too

I like this place and have eaten here many times over the past 8 years. It is not the best in Las Vegas as some people say but it is still a great option. It's located in an old shopping center near the strip but it's convenient and there is a lot of parking nearby. The service is always good.

I love Thai food and I really want to give this place five stars, but I can't. Yes, the food is delicious but outside the Khao Soi, everything else can be found at nearby Komol and Arawan for cheaper and without the hustle and bustle.

I love coming here to eat whenever I travel to Vegas. I was just there a few days ago with my family & they loved every dish we picked off their menu with many varieties. The quality of their ingredients are always fresh & their food are very unique & flavourful. I find not many "Asian" restaurants in Vegas delivers the authenticity nor delicious flavours but this place is a hidden gem that lives up to my standards! I especially love their juicy satay skewers & green curry! (Drooling) The price is pretty reasonable for its deliciousness & in the city, however the portions are smaller than the usual Thai restaurants I go to. It is always packed especially on Fridays-Sundays, less waiting time to go during a weekday night! The outside looks very sketchy & the inside looks outdated, its decor consists of over 100 framed photos of famous people who ate there with a large display room of wine bottles. One of the things I wish they will improve on is providing free WiFi for its guests like most restaurants nowadays, especially when you have to wait over an hour for a table with no TV inside. You must check this place out if you're craving some Asian flare when you're in town! :)

I love this place! I always get the same 3 dishes: garlic prawns, pad sew ew and their pineapple duck curry. They are a must try! 

There always seems to be a line so be sure to get there right when it opens!

I love this place.  Every time we go to Las Vegas we come here.  This time it turned out that the place had uhmm.... grown slightly :)  Last time we were there this was a tiny restaurant but now it's rather giant and the line up to it was at a glance more than 40 ppl.  LOL. MAKE A RESERVATION! 
Well, we come for the sweet and sour chicken which is perfect here.  The sauce is perfectly spectacular and they make it just as spicy as you want which for me is "tears in your eyes, flames in your mouth hot" :) .  The chicken quality is great -- fresh and perfect.  The service is great -- the staff were very attentive and nice.  I'm very happy to say that despite having grown this place had not lost the quality of its food which is a HUGE relief since it's one of our favorite Thai places.

I mean seriously, Thai food doesnt get better than this. From the Bible sized wine list to the drunken seafood noodles, try it all! you won't be disappointed. Just one tip, be prepared to wait a while if you go on a weekend or during busy convention times or whatnot. Also, it's much less questionable looking inside than out... dont judge it by the scuzzy strip mall location.

I recently purchased Carpet and Lament flooring from Budget Flooring. The price and service was great. I will do it again 10 years from now.
Thanks again, Wayne Whiteman

I saw this restaurant on parts unknown and definitely wanted to stop by next time I was in Vegas. I really admit that it did not disappoint. We got there and the hour wait was worth it. Just grab a drink at their bar and check out all the celebrity photos on the walls. 

The food was amazing, the staff was beyond quick and courteous. They have a lot of thai staff there and they took care of us as if we were family. I wouldn't hesitate to come back.

I spent a lot of time in San Francisco and I've got to be almost all the really bomb spots and Chinatown in downtown... This place is a world-class level... I highly recommend if you're in Vegas and want Chinese food stop by and check these guys out you won't be disappointed...Fried rice appetizer are on another level....Fried duck and shrimp drunken noodles Are a must try awesome

I thought this place was phenomenal! With great, friendly/informative service and a great atmosphere, I really enjoyed my experience here. The noodles that they use for the pad thai were different than what I was accustomed to, but I thought it was great!!

I travel in an RV all over the country. I am always looking for a good Thai restaurant. Thanks to Yelp, I found this one. I had pad woon sen and it may have been the best I have ever found. The staff was friendly.

I was craving the soft shell crab but I didn't come here to not try their northern style dishes! And I definitely didn't haul ass from Arizona back to Vegas to eat pad Thai. 

There were so many to choose from. We went with the Nam Prick Noom, Northern green chili dip dish, and the Nua Nam Tok beef dish. 

The beef dish came out really quick. But it was luke warm. It was very flavorful. Many herbs and spices not used in Thai restaurants where I'm from. It tasted authentic. But there was a overpowering taste of cilantro. Loved the spice to it.

The chili dish wasn't what I expected. It was a cold dish. Green chili with additional items to bring out the flavor, including chicharrones?? Although weird, I really liked it.

Tip: don't forget to order a side of rice. It doesn't automatically come with the dishes.

The service was ok. I asked for recommendations and he just pointed out the northern Flavors page and the chief's specials. But I wasn't really given further advice. We weren't in a rush or anything but that's usually how I indicate that the service is slow. When I'm on my phone and realize 5 minutes passed and my check hasn't been picked up. Because we were there when they were closing till dinner, I'm almost positive we were forgotten a few times as they were focused on closing shop.

The place is decorated with a bunch of pictures of celebrities, reviews, and authentic pictures. A beautiful wine cellar to stare at. I'm glad I experienced it but my high expectations wasn't met.

I was told to wait for 1 hour (Tuesday night). When I got in, there were many empty tables. Do they have to make it look like they are real busy? 

The Tom Yum soup is way too sour.  It taste like vinegar. Took only 1 spoon. Yuck! Wasting $16 for the soup. 
Green curry alone is $12 (round up from 11.95), added $3 for shrimp. $15 for a small bowl of curry. Ridiculous expensive.
A small dish of seabass $31. Not even enough for 1 person. Ridiculous expensive. 
Thai Salad with just salad and a small bowl of sauce $9. Ridiculous expensive. Should not even called a dish.
18% gratuity automatic added to receipt for a party of 5.

Ridiculous expensive. Food is not good enough for that ridiculous high price. I will never come back.

I went here at around 11.30 so there was no line at all. I was immediately directed to a table. One of the best thai restaurants I've ever had! The crispy duck with panang curry was super delicious. The crispiness of the duck skin and the content flavor of the panang curry made this dish really good! I also tried the garlic prawn and it was da bomb! I ordered the crispy pork with chinese broccoli but it was just okay. The only downside to this restaurant was the price! I spent around $80 to try those 3 dishes plus a Thai tea.

I will not wait for 2 hours for this place but I will always make sure to eat here whenever I am in vegas~~~~

TIP: go on a weekday during lunch right when they open and I guarantee that you will not wait in line or wait as much compared to dinner.

We feasted on:
Garlic Prawns-- so meaty and the fried skins super crispy!! (make sure you dip them into the duck curry)
Tom Yum- the best i have had in my life- perfect balance of flavors- most of the thai food restuarants would have way too much sourness that ruins the rest of the ingredients natural flavors
Pad see wu- yum yum yummu chewy rice noodles in my tummy
.. the duck curry?- didn't really like the consistency of the noodles but... the sauce- i will mixed it up with rice anytime

gotta go back to try the rest of their menu soon ^^

I've been coming here for years, originally for the lunch buffet and now for the occasional dinner. It's a little pricey and always packed in the evenings, and for good reason. This food is top notch, better than Komol or any other Thai restaurant I've been to in town. It's an an unassuming, unimpressive, and perhaps uninviting strip mall, but this area's always been home to a mix of dives and delights, don't judge the book by it's cover or the guy hitting you up for money in the parking lot.

Once inside, you'll see the space is kept up well and has a substantial wine collection. I can't comment on that since I've always thrown all my money into food and sometimes a thai tea. Their signature cuisine is northern Thai, and while I don't have other cuisine from that region to compare it to, it is delicious. That said, so are the more traditional dishes. The orange chicken, which was good during the lunch buffet, is outstanding when made to order. The pineapple fried rice has a great depth of flavor and is well-seasoned. Anything with crispy duck is excellent. The last time we had a northern Thai shrimp curry that was top notch. If you're not picky, just give the server some general parameters and they'll take care of it for you. You want a curry, pineapple rice, and crispy duck dish? Say no more. I haven't had something for dinner yet that I felt was "meh." The only problem, if you can call it that, is that the menu is huge which can make it tough to decide but on the other hand always provides some room to explore. 

This is a Vegas must. Call ahead to find out the wait time and see if you can put your name on the list. Expect a 45 minute wait for take-out. Don't think you can waltz in for dinner, any day of the week, without a 30 minute wait.

I've been dying to eat at Lotus of Siam, so last week when I was in Vegas I made sure we had a reservation. 

I was not disappointed. 

The garlic prawns were especially delicious. The prawns and skins are fried separately, then tossed in a sweet garlic sauce before serving. I had never eaten shrimp shells like this before and was completely mesmerized. Like the menu description, they really had the consistency of potato chips! 

The only negative I can find is that the portions seemed a little small compared to the prices. But even with that in mind, it was worth every penny.

I've been going to Lotus since moving to Las Vegas 17 years ago and almost always gravitate to the d the steamed sea bass with ginger seasoning.  This dish is a true delight...always very high quality fish, usually prepared to preserve the delicate texture of the fresh fish and usually well seasoned.The bass is served on a bed of steamed veggies.  The Tom Yum Kai hot and sour soup with chicken, lime juice, lemon grass and straw mushrooms is spectacular and consistent in quality.

Several years ago Lotus did a large expansion,  started catering to tour buses, and in my opinion, at the expense of small groups and locals.  That change has resulted in service screw ups, including forgetting parts of an order several times, being served the wrong entree,  unusually long waits for the arrival of food and at times wait staff that was non-communicative at their best and outright rude at their worst.

Combine the above with the inability to make reservations online or by phone prior to their opening time each day, the inability to get anything but a busy signal once they open, and the mass feeding frenzy created by bus arrivals that has lowered the ambience from mediocre (hey, for years it's been about the food in spite of the mediocre ambience) to an ambience somewhere between an Army mess hall and a bus station waiting room, I've given up on going to Lotus.  When they're good they're really really good and when they are bad they are terrible.  In the past two years they have typically been close to or at terrible.

One way to enjoy the typically outstanding food is to order carryout.  I was uncertain the first time because I didn't know how well cooked fish would taste after a 20-minute car ride, but the answer is that is was excellent....excellent enough that we've used the carryout process several times recently.

I've been here more times than I can count, and way before it was on T.V. This place is definitely worth the wait!! It can be tricky to find if you're new, but a taxi will know where it is, or just remember to turn at the green building. The green chili lime prawns are amazing!! Everything is fantastic, and try something off their Northern Thailand Menu in the back. If possible, have someone in your group get there earlier to put in your reservation, they stopped answering their phones years ago. The strip mall may seem sketchy, but that's typical old Vegas. You won't need your gun in this part of town, you'll be too stuffed to use it anyways.

I've been to Southeast Asia and live in the melting pot known as the Bay Area...this is the best Thai restaurant i have been to outside of SE Asia!!!! The Bay Area has nothing which compares!!! The soup is amazing and their shrimp dishes are beyond compare!! Order #52!!! Fresh seafood and amazing people!

I've been wanting to come to Lotus of Siam for ages, finally made it . . . and I was underwhelmed. Sigh. 

Side note: if you find yourself in a sketchy strip mall and see a tiny storefront with a sign that says Lotus of Siam and are 70% sure you're in the wrong place, you're in the right place. 

Once you get inside, the restaurant is actually really big. Decor is nothing to speak of, but definitely better than the outside would lead you to believe. 

Prepare yourself--the menu is overwhelmingly huge. After consulting Yelp and getting advice from our server, we went with the garlic prawns, drunken noodle with mixed seafood, crispy duck curry, a small Singha and a Thai lime drink, and sticky rice with coconut ice cream for dessert. Our bill, without tip, was almost $90. 

I don't have a problem paying good money for good food, but it just didn't seem like the price was warranted. Our meal was fine, but not outstanding. 

The garlic prawns has a great texture but seemed oily and didn't have as much flavor as I would have hoped. The prawns are pulled out of the shells, but the shells are left attached at the tail, so you have the prawn and shell separately deep fried. I would never known that you are supposed to eat the shells, but, thanks to good ol' Anthony Bourdain, my husband is more up on these sorts of things than I. The texture of the breading and the shell, and the flavor and crunch of the cabbage slaw with cilantro underneath the prawns, which was coated with garlicky goodness, were the best parts of this dish. 

The drunken noodles with mixed seafood weren't bad, but weren't better than any other drunken noodles I've had. 

The crispy duck curry was by far my favorite dish. Red panang curry, a generous serving of duck breast with perfectly crisped skin, and some red bell pepper. Most flavorful dish on the table, with a little bit of heat. 

I loved the Thai lime drink--basically limeade, tart and sweet but not too sweet, with a tiny salt. 

The sticky rice was meh, which was sad because sticky rice is one of my favorite things. Would've ordered it with mango, but they didn't have any, so went with coconut milk ice cream instead. 

Maybe we ordered the wrong things? Maybe they were having an off night? I don't know. The same meal for a more reasonable price would've gotten four stars from me, but it was way too expensive for what it was. 

The service was great. Shout out to Ettel--he was absolutely amazing! He wasn't our server, but took our drink orders and cleared our table, and was SO friendly and attentive.

I've dined at LoS at least a couple times a year and every time it's been enjoyable. It's a must-go-to every time I visit LV. Overall, the food is great and service is attentive and friendly. No wonder this place is always packed. Reservations are recommended especially if you have a larger group. 

The Food:
I can't think of an item/entrée that I didn't like. The flavors are spot on and you can tell that they take pride in what they serve. The entrées are family style, so everyone in our party can enjoy the tastes. 

Here are some of my favorites (that i remember from the top of my head)
- Garlic Prawns
- Pad Thai
- Spicy Fried Rice
- Seafood soup
- Chicken satay (appetizer)
- Roasted duck curry

I know i've missed a few dishes but you can't really go wrong. A definite must-try if you love Thai food. Be sure to check out the seasonal items as well. 

Other notes:
The location is a bit hidden and sign (green at night) isn't flashy. You may also see a few people waiting outside. But when you walk in, you'll see that LoS proudly display articles and photos with celebs and people within the community. The restaurant is nicely lit and atmosphere can get a bit loud, but not annoying at all.

I've heard about the crazy long lines outside of this place and I've had it bookmarked for a while. I'm an avid Thai food eater so this place was definitely where I wanted to eat for my first non-partying weekend in Vegas. I went in on a rainy Friday evening, around 6:50pm, the weekend of the Pacquiao vs Bradley 3 boxing match. They quoted me for a wait time of 30mins but we actually got called to be seated in 3mins. They have an automated system where they text you when you're table is ready. 

The inside was nice and cozy. I really like the glass wine case that you see when you walk in. The lighting was dim but not too dark to set the ambiance just right. The place seemed clean although I don't know how much I trust carpet in a restaurant..

We ordered a Pad Thai, Pad See Ew, beef Penang curry, and a Thai tea. They brought out the 2 noodle dishes first and then the curry. I ordered beef penang but the waiter brought out chicken. A minor hiccup, I simply told the waiter I had ordered beef and so he had it changed for me. 

I judge a Thai restaurant by their Pad Thai and their Thai tea. I must say I was a little disappointed with the pad Thai. It was a little dry and lacking in flavor. The Thai tea was great though. The beef Penang curry was good. I got a 3 on their spicy-ness scale and it was perfect for me. The Pad See Ew dish was the best thing we ordered though. It was moist and flavorful. I would definitely order the Pad See Ew over the Pad Thai the next time I come here.

I've wanted to try this place since I saw it on Munchies. I'm so glad I did. Though it's location is far from where I live, I feel like it's worth the drive and wait to go there. Trust me, I waited a year because i thought it would be so expensive. The prices were exceptional.

We didn't have reservations but we were quickly seated. Our server was very attentive. I never had to ask a single time for my drink to be refilled. Most restaurants have trouble with that on a busy night.

Our appetizer was wonton bacon wrapped shrimp. I wanted to try it so bad that my husband and I took one each before I took a picture.

We ordered thier Tom yum catfish hotpot. We ordered it mild because I can't really take alot of spicy food. It was just the perfect amount of spicy.  

We also ordered pad Thai and penang curry duck. The serving for each dish was enough for 2 people to share. It's either that or we just really eat alot.

If I ate at Lotus of Siam 4 times over a 4 day trip to Vegas...does that qualify me as an addict? Or just a regular on Yelp?

Flying in Friday night from Newark, I search Yelp and online and find good reviews of Lotus of Siam, calling it one of the best Thai restaurants in the US. I'm a huge fan of Thai (like Somtum Der, Pam Real Thai and others in NYC) and decided to try it.

That first dinner was so good that next night, searching for healthier restaurants not far from the Strip, I decided it was easier to just go to Lotus of Siam again.

Over 4 visits (3x for dinner and once for lunch), I tried:

ENTREES
- Northern Larb. Think minced pork with chilis that explodes with flavor, whether you choose a spiciness level closer to 1 or 10. This was the only dish I ordered twice in my 4 visits. Be warned though, if you're not much for hot/spicy, choose a lower number.
- Nam Prik Ong (Red chili dip). While I saw this dish mentioned in reviews, I wasn't too impressed. It's tasty, just not as much so as the Northern Larb.
- Khao Soi. This was like a large bowl of flat egg noodles mixed with curry. Tasty but I preferred other dishes mixed with rice.
- Kang Hung Lay (beef stew). Paired with rice, this dish was good. Fairly flavorful.
- Isan sausages. This is Thai sausage sliced and served with a bunch of raw veggies (onions, Thai chili peppers, cabbage, etc). A good appetizer to share with friends (Though being hungry, I ordered this along with an entree for myself).
- Pad kraprow with pork belly and minced chicken. This is usually my go-to dish at Thai restaurants (generally preferring rice to noodles) but in this case I waited a few visits to try this. If you like minced meat with basil and chilis, you'll probably like this. 

DRINK
- A variety of different German Reislings. I haven't traditionally been into wine but admit I'm now sold on pairing them with Thai food.
- Also Thai iced tea once to see what it was like. Par for the course, not mind-blowingly different.

SUMMARY
I liked this Thai restaurant so much I ate there 4 times over a 4-day visit. If you like delicious Thai food paired with wine and sake, it's hard to go wrong here.

If I had to choose one place to eat at each time I'm in Vegas, it would have to be Lotus. Although it is off the strip, it's absolutely worth the trip. Every dish I've had here has not disappointed. I love the garlic prawns, crying tiger and chicken satay. I would suggest calling ahead to make a reservation or you'll have a long wait.

If you are deciding what great Thai place to go to this evening I would definitely choose 

*** Chada Thai & Wine ***
or
*** Thai Street Cafe ***
over Lotus anyday. I'd have to say I was disappointed with the quality, size portion, and pricing at Lotus. Specifially for the portion and quality, it's one of those places that's Overrated. 

Apps- we got the #14 Nam Kao Tod because everyone was raving about it on Yelp. I found it to be small in portion and very very salty. Also they doused it In way too many limes, that's all I could taste. 

Main Courses- my date and I chose to split the Roasted Duck Curry (4/5 stars - Chada has better duck dishes though)  & Shrimp Pad Thai (4/5 stars)- can't really mess up pad Thai. 

Dessert - mango sticky rice 5/5 stars  Yum

Overall it was a delicious place for dinner but for $80-100 I would chose somewhere else. 

Also - my date and I both had stomach aches for 2 hours after we both ate and fiery bowel movements lol . I'm asain and my date and I both love spicy foods but we've never had any unpleasantness leaving Thai or spicy places. So I'm not sure if it was the spice or the food, we only got a standard 6/10 which is pretty much mild. Didn't taste that spicy either, but we had cramps all night. Beware.
Im in love with this Hidden Vegas GEM living here I have to say its one of the best

In Vegas? 

Stop gambling your life away, and Go Here NOW!

I recommend the entire Northern menu.

In the middle of the backside of an empty run down strip mall is the best Thai food I have ever had. Open the door and you are transported to a large bustling restaurant, nice big bar, and comfortable seating. Great energy.  The staff are all super friendly and attentive. 

The menu is wide and deep with more than five types of Tom Yum you can order from, and a long list of Thai salads not off a traditional Americanized Thai menu.  

Definitely order from the northern menu. Khao Soi (it is awesome) or one of the Nam Prik dips. Crispy duck Penang is off the hook. The Penang is very creamy and rich. Soft shell crab with drunken noodles was good but nothing special. Would have been better if the soft shell wasn't battered and deep fried. 

Been to Vegas 10+ times and this is the first restaurant that will be a "must visit" every time I return.
Incredible food, but the location is a little dicey.

It is an amazing Thai restaurant if you order the Northern Thai specialties. Don't get me wrong the other menu items are still very good such as their pad thai, but their brilliance shines on the northern food. Definitely the go to place in Las Vegas for amazing Thai food!
It was a good place but not as great as people made it sound.
It's amazing.  Stick to the Northern menu.  That's what they do so well that you just won't find anywhere else.  Maybe Northern Thailand.

It's been, oh 5 years since I've step foot in Lotus of Siam. I had the lunch buffet and remember not being super impressed. So when my boss said we were going to Lotus of Siam for dinner, I was a bit confused. He said the food was amazing, and it turned out he was right. Unfortunately, the service was pretty terrible, so I won't be running back.

We had a "reservation" yet had to wait 10-15 minutes to get our table. With it being 110 degrees outside, that sucked. Once seated, it was another 20 minutes before we could order, and only because we pretty much tackled an employee to take our order. The ordering process was very rude, as we seemed rushed and weren't helped by any recommendations as we had asked for.

We were brought three different plates that weren't ours. We had ordered so much food we didn't know what was ours and what wasn't, and the staff kind of scolded us for beginning to eat a plate that was set on our table. Get your act together, guys!

As I said, the food was all pretty amazing. That's the only thing saving this from being a 2* review. Everything they put in front of us was delicious. I really don't remember a bad dish.

When all was said and done, we were left with a $50 per person bill, which seemed like a lot for the style of restaurant we were in.

It's pretty expensive.  We ordered garlic prawn & whole red snapper w/ basil sauce.  The shrimp plate is looking good, but closer look half of them are skin.  The red snapper is the smallest red snapper I've seen, and I don't think it was red snapper at all; base on its texture & size, it's more like tilapia.  We're still hungry after $70 meal (for 2 dishes).  I don't think it's worth the price for the environment & taste.  I'm sorry, I don't think I've ever come back again.

James, the technician, came in response to what we believed was a cracked shower pan in a second floor shower. Another plumber had looked at it and said he could fix the problem for "only 800.00." James, after examining it, stated that it was not a crack, but a surface mark near the drain, and therefore was fine to use. After we looked closer, he was right, and we really appreciated his honesty. If we have another problem, we will have the number and name on file.

Just above average. Certainly not worth the hype. I would maybe have given it one more star if it wasn't for the wait. I don't mind waiting for an exceptional restaurant, but slightly above average in quality and price makes it an overall loser in my book. My standards are high for Thai restaurants. Perhaps my expectations were too high but I would definitely not have gone to five stars even if there was no line.

Just had some lunch here after reading the reviews. A solid 3-star thai place for me. The best part was the very affordable pricing, I had a Thai Iced Coffee, and appetizer, and main soup for $25. 

The iced coffee was delicious as it always is, the appetizer was the crispy rice with sour pork cubes. This was eh. Just deep fried rice and the "pork cubes" are really just cut up ham that you could get down the street at the super market. 

I had the Northern style (no coconut milk) Tom Kum Kai (chicken soup) but I subbed the chicken for prawns. This was good, not amazing, not really good, just...good. 

I'd go again, but if you're into Thai food, don't expect anything as amazing as the other reviews would have you believe.

LOVE this place. The food is amazing! It's on the higher price, but if you know what to order, you leave satisfied and after all it is in Vegas, so you are there to spend some money. 

It was quick to get seated, check out for reservations if you go on busy hours and weekends. I went there on a Thursday, it was very busy but did not wait more than 10 minutes for my table. 

I ended up with an almost $50 pp bill but I ordered app, side and entree. So while I don't think it's the best value restaurant, for sure high traffic and good flavor I think it is worth it. I had some gambling surplus :) 

I'd be back every chance I get, but I like to try new ones too. Parking is the easiest as it sits at a strip mall on Sahara avenue somewhat close to SLS hotel.

Last night a group of us had dinner here and it was one of the biggest let-down dining experiences I have ever had. First of all it was over 
an hour wait to be seated. Then then after a long wait for our food it arrived cold. When we complained we were told that as a rule they serve their food at room temperature!
This was food that was pricey and the portions were small. The service was terrible as they did not even make an effort to accommodate our preferences. We came because it had good ratings and we wanted to try it out based on it's advertised "exquisite cuisine". At least the food tasted good even though we lost our appetite with the way it was served and the bad service! Never going back again!!

Let's go ahead and be honest here... Lotus of Siam is easily the best Thai restaurant in the states.

My dad introduced me to this restaurant during our last trip to Vegas. The restaurant had a line outside of it even before it opened- proof that they're doing something right.

A few of the things we ordered-

Issan style beef jerky (delicious, not like the stuff in the bag at the gas station, but REAL, spicy beef jerky)
Panang short ribs (spicy and perfect, the best Panang sauce I've ever had)
Sea bass over drunken noodles (my favorite)
Fried banana and mango with sticky rice (must try- I didn't try the coconut ice cream but it looked delicious).

Totally worth the wait!

Let's start by saying when there's a line before 5:30pm then you know something is good.  

What a GEM!  

My friends and I arrived there at 5:35pm and oh my good gawd there was a line and people were already sitting down inside.  When we got to the front we were told that the wait for a table will be an hour.  Being that I've heard a lot of great things about this restaurant we opt to wait.  We grabbed a drink at the back bar and sat in that back room.  (Wish they made that room into a dinning area instead of a waiting room)

Eventually after 30 minutes we were seated.  YAY!  
We already knew what we wanted so at that time I sat and looked at all the photos on the wall of celebrities who ate at Lotus of Siam.  

Food: 
Crispy duck with panang
NAM KAO TOD: (Crispy rice mixed with sour cubed pork sausages, cilantro, green onions, grounded dry chilis, ginger, peanuts and lime juice)
Thai Fried Rice
DRUNKEN NOODLE PRAWNS

FoodGasmn!  The food was full of bold flavors and delicious.  Definitely a place to visit whenever I'm in Vegas.

Located in Shopping Center and not facing Sahara so slow down before you get there.
Worth the 30-45 minute wait. 
One of the best Thai restaurants in Vegas if not the Southwest.
Long wait but the food was worth it. Fried bananas and coconut ice cream dessert...yes please

Lots of people told me I had to check this place out when I was in Vegas. Since I knew they had Northern Thai dishes that's the route I took. I had Khao Soi ( the best I've ever had) and a dish with pork and jack fruit that they recommended. I was not head over heals for the dish with the jack fruit ( you actually could barely tell there was jack fruit it blended in well, it just wasn't my favorite). If I could I'd give this place 4.5 stars ( it wasn't quite deserving of 5 in my mind). I was stuck in a little back room and felt a bit neglected. The server came around but I feel like I was forgotten about half the time. On the other hand I came with my luggage and they were very sweet and put it in their wine storage room ( they have a huge wine selection by the way). 
I'll be back next time I go to Vegas. Hopefully I won't be by myself so I can try more of the dishes. Also if anyone is wondering it was about a 12 dollar Uber from the middle of the strip.

Lotus of Siam got off on the wrong foot with their call confirming our reservation in which they threatened to give away our reservation if we were more than five minutes late.  I know it's a popular spot but calm down.

Admittedly the food was tasty. The larb and sea bass with Suki sauce had the right amount of heat.  Even the more basic pad see ew was well made.  But our night out lasted less than an hour as food was delivered too quickly to enjoy the meal overall.

There are a lot of Thai and Asian options in Las Vegas.  Choose another like Chada Thai for a better experience.

Lotus of Siam lived up to the hype. Went to the back of the menu and ordered from Northern Specialties. Got the curried egg noodle dish. Also the thai sausage. Sausage was a little dry, but still very tastey. Flavors are vibrant. The spice really hits you. Also got the basil fried rice which was excellent.

Lotus of Siam really is worth the drive across town. I love Thai food and this restaurant is great. The service is fabulous. We had a reservation and when we arrived there was a line waiting to get in. We got in and we were sat right away. Our order for drinks and food was taken as well. Everything was prepared to perfection. I will definitely be returning. They have a wonderful and attentive staff. Food is excellent.

Lotus of Siam was every bit as good as everyone had told us it was. It graces a bunch of "top 10 things to do in Vegas" lists, and the last few food shows about Vegas we'd watched (like Bourdain's Parts Unknown) have visited it.
We arrived about fifteen minutes before they opened for lunch and there was already a group of people waiting in line, and as we waited four more groups pulled up. We were seated right after they opened, and followed everyone's advice to order from the Northern specialties page - I got the Khao Soi with chicken, and he got the Northern Laab. 
The Khao Soi was amazing - nuanced layers of chile flavor and rich soup body of coconut and broth. I wish this were available from my local places, but then again, that's the whole point of Lotus of Siam - fantastically prepared dishes that we can't really get anywhere else.
The laab was good, a little strong for me but D liked it. He did find a small piece of clear plastic in the rice that needed to be picked out, but other than that it was a good dish.
Love this place never can decide with a wife menu but had a great time and loved the food

Loved going here! As a non resident, it was great to find a local place in such an odd old strip mall like location. The "strip mall" is now kind of a foodie haven with various cool restaurants dotted throughout the U-shaped building structure. Once inside Lotus of Siam is a homey packed space with two dining rooms, quick service and authentic Thai. We ordered as a group and ate family style so it's hard to recollect all the dishes I had, but I had no complaints, except it seemed a bit pricey for thai.
Loved this place! It was packed with a lot of fun people. Food was superb!  A lot of celebrities come here. Thats why it was recommended by our hotel valet. Delicious curry!  Mmmmmm!

Loving this restaurant!!!

I've been meaning to try this place, but always forgot to make RSVP early. This time, I called the day before, and got a late dinner reservation for next day. I was very nervous and afraid of the hype, but very pleased with the experience.

From yelpers' recommendations, I got Garlic prawn, Drunken noodle with sea bass, Crispy duck panang, Nam Kao Tod and Pad Thai. Everything was very good, and I can't wait to try other dishes in our next visit. For us, the must order dishes were garlic prawn, and sea bass. The curry sauce is amazing, but the duck was just okay.

I thought the dishes would be small, but it was plenty for the three of us. Our waiter even told us we had ordered too much, but ours eyes were bigger than our stomach :) 
Service was better than the average Asian restaurants, so it was a plus. Pricing is higher, yet reasonable for the quality.

Luckily we made advanced reservation. I was surprised how big the restaurant was. It had multiple big rooms all filled with customers. The service was attentive and polite. We ordered the Khao Soi, which is crispy duck over egg noodles and curry sauce, chicken larb, which is ground chicken tossed in a spicy, lime sauce, and crispy garlic prawns. The food was tasty, however, it was nothing exceptional for which we would come back. We also thought the food was overpriced- the Khao Soi and garlic prawns were each $27-28. The portion was average. The meal for two cost $77 before tips.

Make a reservation before coming! If you don't, I would recommend getting to the restaurant before open (around 5 pm) to start standing in line- especially if you're trying to go on a weekend. 

The crispy garlic prawns is definitely the highlight. Perfectly crispy and garlicky but consistently a little on the salty side for my taste. However, the flavor is so good that I can't complain. 

The crispy duck panang curry is also very good. You could adjust the spiciness level (up to 10) and warning- their spicy is SPICY!! 

I wouldn't get some of the dishes you could order at normal thai restaurants. We ordered pad see ew and pad kee mao to supplement our meal and neither were memorable (i would even argue that it was not that great). Their papaya salad though was a perfect combo of tangy and sweet!

Man this place is popular....is quite the understatement.  My wife and I got  there about 30 minutes prior to opening and long and behold....50 people ahead of us.  This is a brick and mortar restaurant not some weird food truck phenom.

This place is 100% legit and I have to say it will be on the itinerary every single time.  The spicy nam prik goong and the crispy shrimps and all the delicious dishes that are too many to name.   BUT get there early as there will always be a line.  Something else that kinda scared us while we were getting out of the cab was that the cabby wanted to know if we wanted him to wait?  Must be a messed up hood if the cabbies are freaked out.   Love the food though.  But don't leave stuff in your car!


Cheers and happy eats!
Man what a place, don't be fooled by the outside of the building or the area this is a gem in Las Vegas. Everything was great that we tried best Thai food I have ever eaten.
Mmmm the duck curry got me here.. I can't even remember what else I liked about this place, but everything I have ever ordered is amazing! Expect to wait, this place can get crazy!
Multiple choices but soooo yummy. Tom Kha soup and Prawns in a blanket for appetizers and delicious!
My Pad Se Ew was exceptional. All of the flavors were right on and our waiter was attentive. We will definitely be visiting again to explore the menu some more. Cheers!

My family and I came here for lunch because apparently dinner fills up with reservations, weeks in advance. I ordered the ginger shrimp which was very good and flavorful. I love spicy food and this was not spicy however I should have expected that. The food came out pretty quickly. The shrimp was very tender and served with peppers and onions. Overall the dish had great flavor! They have a huge menu with a large variety of Thai food to order from. They even have a Northern dish section which has very distinct flavors. My mom ordered the Khao Soi which is a curry dish with egg noodles and veggies. It was so full of flavor and one of the best Thai dishes I've ever tasted. The curry was so good that she ate it like a soup and finished the whole thing. It had just the right amount of spice so I would highly recommend it! The explosion of flavors and distinct/unique tastes really sets this Thai food apart from ordinary Thai food places. Not only that but the meat and fish were very good quality and that also really made this a much more exceptional and unordinary Thai restaurant. The meat and fish were just so tinder and fresh. The prices were also very reasonable, especially for the quality and quantity and being that they are in Vegas, they are one of the much cheaper restaurants.  Came here for lunch at about 2:15 (15 minutes before closing time). The waitress warned us that we may not get in because they stop giving out tables at 2:30 so obviously they would rather be done working by 3 than keep serving people. This is probably because they have so many customers that they it won't make a difference if they have one or two extra customers. However it was very apparent that they were ready to leave because the wait staff seemed pretty rushed to have us order and not exceptionally friendly towards us. Also, it was a little off the strip so the location was not very nice and the inside was just okay too. They could definitely use some renovations to make it nicer.

My family just drove in and we were looking forward to some good Thai food.  We ordered the drunken noodles with prawns and the chicken fried rice to share.  The prawns were good but the drunken noodles were sober and dry.  It was all clumped together with barely any sauce.  The fried rice was decent but the portion you get for $10+ is ridiculous.  Barely enough to share amongst my 5 and 4 yr old.  A place this pricey and so highly reviewed needs to stay consistent.  Not going to be back.

My friend wanted to go here, and so we ventured out at 9:30 on a Wednesday night to find it. Passed it at least twice because it's hidden behind a mostly-dark, what appears mostly-vacant strip mall thing. We turned into it and, there, amidst other mostly-dark and sketchy-looking places, was Lotus of Siam. We really weren't sure we had the right place. We went in, asked to be put on the list, told it would be 40-45 minutes (let me say again, 9:30 on a Wednesday night), and we gave them our number to text. After about 10-15 minutes of wandering around the dark and sketchy area, we got a text, and sat down to one of the best meals I've had, Thai or otherwise. 

We didn't have wine, but they have an amazing-looking glassed-in wine cellar. I ordered a red curry - smallish servings but AMAZINGLY good. My friend ordered a duck dish - I'm not a duck fan, but I would have eaten it all if he hadn't. Just simply amazingly good food. Go, don't be scared, you'll love it. I'd go back in an instant.

My husband and I are in Vegas after the Memorial weekend.  I've heard about this place from a friend back at home so we want to check it out.  It's definitely worth a try!  The location is off of the main tourist section of LV so not easy to find.  It looks sketchy from the outside but you'll be surprised once you enter on the setting and ambiance of the restaurant. The staff are very friendly and attentive.  The food is not the best Thai food I've had but definitely up there in rank.  We would absolutely go back!

My husband and I love Yelp because it never steers us wrong!!  This restaurant was delicious!!!  We got the potstickers appetizer, yum!  Then we followed it with the crispy duck in coconut milk, garlic prawn & pork belly!!  Man oh man was that an experience!  You will have an hours wait or so to get in, but believe me it's well worth it!!!  For just the duck alone was mouth-watering!:). The service was excellent!:) don't let the area of location throw you off!  It's amazing!  A definite must!

My mom and I were skeptical about this place because of its location. The place is super dark and sketchy looking outside. As we pulled up, we noticed all of the cars in the parking lot, but had no clue where all of these people could be. The outside of the restaurant was really dark and the place looked small...until we walked in....let me tell ya..THIS PLACE IS HUGE and now we know where all of the people went! The wait was about 45 minutes, so as we were waiting by the bar, we used Yelp to view other user's pictures and definitely had to try to Crispy Garlic Prawns (which is to die for)! We also ordered a bunch of other plates and shared it between 4 people. We ordered the panang yellow curry, tom yum, pad Thai, and the papaya salad. 
This place is pretty good! Definitely will come back soon. I Would recommend this place to any Thai food lover.

My wife and I enjoyed dinner here. We often go to a Thai restaurant near our home but my wife thought to go here for a change. The food was similar to our other restaurant with a slightly higher price point. Service was great. Everyone there ( and there was a lot) was friendly and quick to help. I'd recommend  this place for smaller parties  (upwards of 4 at most)

Next time you find yourself in the city Bugsy Siegel built do yourself a favor and leave bright lights of The Strip and head to Lotus of Siam for what will be the best Thai meal you'll ever have in the U.S.! 

My first piece of advise is, be ready to wait. It's a big place that works like a well greased engine but it's always packed.

Be adventures the menu is big with things that could sound scary to some but trust in your waiter (like I did) and you won't be disappointed.

My waiter recommend the three following dishes 

Nam Prik Ong - a dish made with a blend of spices, herbs and ground pork you can adjust the heat to your liking. Out of the three it was my least favorite because it was weird to eat without some sort of lettuce leaf to but it in. Still very good and I can see why it's one of Ming Tsai's favorite things to eat. 

The Nam Kao Tod- a crispy rice mixed with sour cubed pork sausage, cilantro, green onions, ground dry chilies  ginger peanuts and lime juice was my favorite dish of the night. I'd never had anything like it before and all the components come together perfectly in every bite. Tip: Watch out of the dry peppers ;-)  

For my main dish the waiter recommend the Khao Soi a Burmese egg noddles coconut curry dish that was absolutely perfect. Creamy but not buttery, spicy but not overriding. Add the red onions and lime and it will take the dish to another level.

So next time you're in Vegas go hit the jackpot at Lotus of Siam!

Normally I would not write a Yelp review unless I've frequented the place at least two times, but the food was so good that I just have to give it 5 stars. I've been to Thailand and understand that it can be difficult to replicated flavors because it's not always easy to get fresh kaffir leaves, Thai basil, fresh coconut, etc. But everything we ordered here reminded me of Thailand! However, I can't speak for the Northern dishes because I've never been there, but everything I tried was heavenly. Can't wait to come back here! 

By the way, what other reviewers said about how the area is sketchy is true. Please Uber or taxi to and from for your safety.
Not impressed by the food. Service was friendly but the food was not to par. Definitely has a Chinese fusion rather than authentic thai food.

Not much to look at but, jeez, great food!  Order the crispy rice and sour sausage to start, then the crispy duck in chu chee sauce, and garlic and pepper grilled shrimp.  

You'll probably need a reservation!

Not that this place needs my review, but I'm surprised I've never written one considering the number of times I've come. It's almost a tradition to come here for Thanksgiving day dinner.
Always make reservations. Always.
If you've heard of the dish in Utah, don't order it. It will just be something you've had before, but better. Order things that are Northern Thai specialities we don't see here. The best thing to do is put yourself into your server's hands. Tell him you want shellfish, or garlic, or duck, or ... Let him know the kind of spice level you tolerate. Then let him recommend dishes. I've never had a dish I didn't like the server recommended. Also, always get the Garlic Prawns. That's just a given. Also get the recommended fish dish. The sea bass they always have is a good starting point, if the server doesn't have anything better.
Nothing amazing. Nothing horrible. Just a quick place to grab some Thai food.

O...m.....g. This place is so bomb. Don't even eat the pad thai or other entrees. The Shrimp and Duck is what you should come here for. It is so addicting and amazing. I take the challenge to find something similar to this flavorful Shrimp in Orange county. There has to be one !!!

Of course, reading all the other reviews, this one will be similar. Lotus of Siam is amazing. For an appetizer, we had No. 14, some sort of fried rice with lime, cilantro, and ginger. Oh so delicious. I ordered the Chilean Sea Bass in Ginger. The fish was PERFECT. The fish was flaky and buttery and light and and and, just so wonderful. 

My boyfriend ordered the drunken noodle prawns. Also very delicious. We both preferred the sea bass tho. 

The level of spicyness was not as hot as we heard it to be. A level 5 spicy was barely hot for us, but that could be our tolerance. We were ok with it not being too spicy. 

My only complaint is it takes a long time to get through to someone on the phone to make reservations.

Once again - surprised at the quality of Asian choices once you get off The Strip.  This time Thai and Southeast Asian.  

But first - do not be alarmed when you actually find the place.  In a very shabby strip mall well off The Strip - a few crappy stores and eateries, a few boarded up places, a smattering of panhandlers and transients (trying real hard to be politically correct).  Look past all this and go in the front door - and prepare to be pleasantly amazed.

Very large restaurant - crowded, hell of a wine cellar (in a Thai place - must be a Vegas thing).  Bit of a wait but not intolerable.  Polite and knowledgeable staff - and willing to take the time to explain the enormous menus and really help with your selection.

Started off with deep fried tofu and beef larb - off to a very good start.  A variety of main courses - and just a ridiculous amount of offerings to choose from.  Finally settled on the Rad Na, Nua Nam Tok and Koi Soi - all prepared well, plenty to eat and enough to share.  A good sampling for future visits.  Strong but not too strong Thai Ice Tea to wash it all down.

Just remember - suck it up and make your way inside.  Well worth it
One of the best in town! They have dishes I never saw in other Thai restaurants

One of the best kept secrets in Las Vegas for authentic, spicy, flavorful Thai food.

I've been coming here for about 10 years now.  I love their Thai curries.  I used to love their lunch buffets but they stopped that about a year ago.  I don't know why because it was popular.

They lose one star because staff are consistently unfriendly & indifferent.  And, although the decor was updated a few years ago it still lacks ambience and privacy.

Timing is everything.  If you want to be seated on a Friday or Saturday night make sure you have a booking first otherwise you'll be waiting outside for over an hour and their tiny waiting area only has a couple of seats.
One of the best places for Thai food in Las Vegas! Noodle dishes and fried rice are top notch, and don't forget the Thai iced tea. Wonderful!

One of the best thai food I've ever had!...and also the most unique variation of it! There were so many options on the menu that I have never seen on other thai menus before. The Garlic Prawns lived up to the Yelp hype! Super crispy and oh so delicious! I never really liked eating shrimp shells that much, even when they were fried in Chinese cooking, but my oh my...this was totally different. It was so crunchy that it felt like I was eating potato chips (which is exactly how they described it) SO GOOD!! I wish I didn't save this place till the last night we were here to try it, or I would have been here a couple more times before our trip was over. This place will be my first stop on our next Vegas trip!

Only giving it 3 stars because the Food is good but the menu was too much. Lousy review I know but the duck curry northern style was delicious but then again Chada Street and Chada have the same style of cooking. Sorry.
Overall an enjoyable meal. We lined up about 30 min prior to opening and got the first diner seating.
Place is great.  Had to wait about an hour but the food was well worth it.  Soups are great.  Will definitely be back. Nice break from the overpriced hotels on the strip.  Outstanding.
Poor location and not open for lunch. Server got our order wrong and became rude when we corrected her. Food is over rated from other reviews. Maybe it has gone down hill since previous ratings.

Prefer Weera Thai which is a cute boutique Thai Restaurant with incredible food!
Weera Thai Restaurant
www.weerathai.com
3839 W Sahara Ave Ste 9, Las Vegas, NV 89102

Price update! Crazy increases! It is starting to become to expensive to eat here!

Garlic Prawns - from $24.95 to $27.95
Drunken Noodle Sea Bass - from $29.95 to $30.95
Panang Crispy Duck - from $24.95 to $27.95

New food I tried,

Pad Thai Chicken - $11.95 - The pad thai had a very strong deep tamarind sauce. The noodles were over cooked and mushy. Chicken was basic.

Thai Fried Rice Beef - $10.95 - Good rice dish. Nothing that blew my mind. 

Tom Kah Kai - $14.95 - Very complex soup. You get the sweet coconut battling with the sour lime flavor. You get a ton of chicken and mushrooms. Good amount to share, we had 6 people, I do not think I could have this alone as a meal.

Storypoint Cabernet Sauvignon - $30 a bottle

Still the best overall meal I have had in Vegas. Prices are getting to be ridiculous though.
Probably one of The best Thai restaurants in the country let alone Vegas.  Awesome wine list. Don't let the ugly shopping center detour you from eating at this restaurant.
Probably one of the best authentic Thai cuisine here in Vegas. Most times this place is packed, so you better call first to check if you can get a reservation. But its totally worth the wait!

Probably the best Northern Thai food you'll ever have outside of Thailand. We always get the garlic prawns that are crispy like potato chips and seasoned to garlicky perfection. Crab fried rice Paris well with those garlic prawns. Curries are also good, but beware the difference in spiciness: mild is medium, medium is hot, and hot is nuclear! Our last dish is the sweet, sour, spicy deep fried whole catfish. This is big enough for 4 to share! Definitely make reservations ahead of time to avoid the 1-2 hour wait for dinner. Once you're seated, they're quick and friendly. A one of a kind food experience that you MUST NOT MISS when you go to Vegas!

Pros: food here is phenomenal. I especially love the papaya salad (the sauce is out this world good)

The pad Thai is another winner, best Thai I have ever had.

Drunken noodle is also quite good (we had two other times we were here)

The green curry was smooth, not the best I have ever had but when paired with pad Thai and papaya salad it really sits in the back as the other two dishes are so powerful in flavor that the green curry just couldn't really take.  I would suggest getting the curry with a fish dish or something milder in flavor as to not get overshadow. 

The fried bananas dessert is amazing, you get basically for rolls (egg roll size) of banana with minced coconut wrapped in egg roll wrapper and deep fried for $8.50 and a scoop of coconut ice cream (not heavy or too sweet- nice and light) $4 = $12.50 dessert good for 4 people (maybe another order of ice cream) drizzled with honey and powder sugar.

For more suggestions for Vegas, Seattle, Florida, Hawaii and more.. Check out our blog: http://uihleinstravels.blogspot.com

Purchased 2015 Toyota Camry today from Nino Quality Motors. I must say the service we received today was outstanding. Matthew Service Manager/ Sales was great! Getting the car financed was easy and hassle free. I left the dealership with my new car feeling great about the service I received and purchasing a new vehicle on my own.
Really great food! Tried several dishes and no complaints... Spicy chicken wings, crab fried rice, garlic fried prawns, crispy duck with curry, mango sticky rice, papaya salad, and more.
Really great thai food! Try the pad won sen, pad se ew, or fried rice. Will definitely be returning
Reduced portions and the soup was watered down. This place used to be good. I don't know what happened. Told staff that we were unhappy but they didn't care :/

Review #666, written 06/06/16--because Lotus of Siam is devilishly good '(^^)'

In Asian literature, lotuses serve as a motif to symbolize inner beauty, because lotuses em emerge as elegant flowers amidst mundane lily pads in muddy waters. Lotus of Siam epitomizes this as an unpretentious restaurant serving Thai food so earth-shattering, it is as if a pack of elephants has trampled through your prior memories of pad Thai and tom yum.

Lotus of Siam was unearthed when a friend heard about it on an Anthony Bourdain show, and it was placed on the Vegas food list. Although the wait is notorious, we got there a little after 9pm and it was only a 10-minute wait, during which we perused the extensive menu (and it still took quite some time to decide once seated; the pages of Thai delicacies were endless!). The catch for the last seating is that the kitchen was taking last orders, so there was no chance to add anything. We decided to err on the side of ordering too much, and it was the best decision we made on the entire Vegas trip.

(+++) GARLIC PRAWNS (deep fried prawns with shells, almost like potato chips, sautéed with our special garlic sauce, topped with ground black pepper) Almost like potato chips. Love that description! The hype cannot be more real, and you likely won't be able to eat shrimp the same way again. The shrimp itself was fresh and succulent, and the highlight was the shell which was deliciously umami with a kick from the pepper and garlic. I devoured it even though I usually detest shrimp shells (hurray, finally I get my glucosamine). 

(+++) TOM KAH KAI (Bangkok Style; a distinctive soup of sliced chicken with coconut milk, straw mushrooms, galanga, lemon grass and a touch of lime juice) The spices and seasonings render a tantalizing complexity, bold and adventurous like an adventure to Thai street food, yet simultaneously unique and meticulous like a long-standing family recipe. I especially liked the touch of coconut milk, making it indulgent but not too creamy. Probably one of the more under-rated dishes as the garlic prawns steal the spotlight. As a bonus, this is served in a pot with an open flame, which looks exotic and neat in pictures (but the shape made it difficult to scoop the soup towards the end... when we were all craving more sopu)

(++) KHAO SOI (typical Burmese influenced dish, served with egg noodles in a curry base with a touch of coconut cream, garnished with sliced red onions, lime and pickled vegetables) We decided to get the beef version since the famous duck khao soi was quite a lot pricier. Like the rest of the dishes, the flavors were untamed with rich curry paired with coconut cream, contrasted by lime and pickled vegetables. The noodles were soft and mild, quiescent in juxtaposition with the fiery broth, and the wonton crisps added a playful garnish. Beef was okay, nothing special (thankfully so since I'm running out of my repertoire of food description words)

(++) PAD THAI (stir-fried thin rice noodles with eggs, green onions, bean sprouts and chopped peanuts on the side) Homey and more familiar, though still noticeably different from your typical pad Thai. Their version was not greasy and very well balanced, at the intersection of aromatic, spicy, and savory. We took the rest to-go and enjoyed heavenly leftovers two days later as our last meal in Vegas (even after our palates had been spoiled by Bacchanal).

It totaled $81 for 3 people, which is considerably more expensive than your typical Thai joint but a completely different level. The Northern Thai style is distinctive, made even more so by the chef's style. According to the website, she utilizes what has been passed down in generations. Lotus of Siam has no neon lights or Corinthian columns and is unimpressively located in a strip mall, but the food speaks for itself--flawless in technique, exotic in flavor profile, and interpretative in embedding the culinary tradition of the chef's roots.

Saw this place from Anthony bourdain's tv
Show. Place was packed on a Thursday afternoon. Got seated right away, avoided the buffet, went straight for garlic prawns and the back menu. Husband at a spicy curry with extra rice and I decided to go for the drunken shift shell crab. DELISH! Thai ice tea was amazing too. Now I see why this place has good reviews, authentic thai food made with amazing spices. Portions were large, and service was nothing to complain about. Just thought it was in a weird strip mall location. Def worth a shot if you're in Vegas and like thai food.

Service is exceptional here.  Some of the best in the area.  I had the chicken shrimp salad which was a little spicy.  My daughter had Northern red curry with chicken and vegetables on a spicy level 5.  She liked it, but I had a taste and it was too spicy for me.  Looking forward to more visits at this fine establishment.

Service was excellent.  Polite and gave good recommendations.

Food listed in order of preference:
Crispy shrimp
Sea bass
Duck with Penang curry
Crab fried rice
Chinese broccoli 
Pad seew

Service was great. They have many people on staff to make sure you are taken care of. They also know how to give you space when you are eating. Prepare to wait in line, but they do take your number and text you when your table is ready. Atmosphere is nice  and great selection of wine. 

The food was great. My favorite would have to be the crispy duck panang curry. Probably the best curry dish I have ever had. Even reheating it the next day was amazing. We wanted to immediately go back. The garlic prawns were pretty good. Not sure if I would order again though and lastly the Tom yum soup was good.
Simply awesome , great Thai food, there northern if you aren't into coconut , lots of wine to chose from , happy folks feeding the happy
Simply, the best thai food i've ever had in my life. Everything was outstanding!!!! I would love to go back when i visit las vegas.

Skip the strip, get a ride to this sketchy hole in the wall. That reveals a world class thai restaurant. Definitely the best Thai outside of the Land. Try the Prawns with the flesh and the shell fried together.

So overrated. Just because Anthony Bourdain liked this place,  doesn't mean the food is the best in the world. So expensive for thai dishes which were unremarkable and bland. The portions are small.  And the prices are big.  The only dish that was worth remembering was their popular egg noodles tossed in curry.  It was different, hence why I still remember it.  Other than that, everything else was unmemorable. I feel like this place is a tourist trap...and we definitely took the bait on this one :/

So, I wasn't so sure about this place when we walked up--it looks tiny and run-down from the outside but is quite big inside and oh so good! 

Highly recommend it.  Everything we had was amazing--soup, beef short ribs, pad Thai, duck. So, so good!!
Some of the best thai food in the country, and certainly the best in Las Vegas.

Some of the things are really good. Curries are delicious and so are pad thai. However, I wouldn't recommend the stuffed chicken wings, too oily and the flavors are really heavy. Overall, I would recommend coming here.

Sometimes gems are hidden in unsavory places. This restaurant is located in a horribly crime ridden part of Las Vegas, and set within a rundown strip mall; that being said once you walk inside you're pleasantly surprised by how clean and nicely decorated it is. I've dined here on several occasions and it is always very busy and packed with customers. During my last visit I ordered a garlic green chili prawns, and Braised Short Rib with Panang Curry. Both dishes were incredibly delicious, with the perfect amount of spice. I still dream about the Panang Curry, probably the best I've ever had.

THE FOOD HERE IS DELICIOUS. You must have a reservation and do not be late because you will lose your spot.  If you do not have a reservation the line to get in is ridiculously long and you might not get a table. The staff is extremely attentive and the prices are very reasonable.

Take away the hype and rave reviews, and you will see that Lotus of Siam delivers solid Thai food.

For years, I had heard only great things about Lotus of Siam.  I have had my fair share of Thai food so I did not understand how one place could be so highly regarded.  While I could honestly say I was not blown away by anything I tried, I did enjoy the flavors and the service leaving me with a great dining experience.  Plus, their menu is pretty extensive so if I am in Vegas again, I am ready to make another trip to try some of their other items.

Here are some of the things that I tried on my first trip:

Nam Kao Tod: A crispy rice dish that sizzles with heat and flavor.  Each kernel of rice was almost fried to a crisp in an oil with a mixture of peppers and spices.  They provide several slices of cabbage and cucumber which help provide a nice counterbalance to the rice.  

Garlic Prawns: Given the high regard for these, here I was a little underwhelmed.  When the dish arrives, you will see the piece of meat hanging from the shell, all of which had been fried to a nice crisp.  While it smells absolutely like something you would come to expect from a dish called garlic prawns, the meat itself was a little lacking in that garlic flavor.  The true flavor actually came from the shell itself which was not necessarily as enjoyable to bite into.  

Roasted Duck Curry: A balance of spicy and sweet with generous pieces of duck make this a recommend.  Sure, in terms of flavor, it is what you would come to expect from your usual curries.  However, the actually chunks that were in the curry were impressive - fresh and vibrant. 

In terms of service, they were really great.  The servers were very attentive to our needs and would do things to make sure everything was okay.  The parking lot is huge so no worries about that but you may have to worry about the wait.  It is usually recommended to make reservations which is possible online.  If you are unable to secure a reservation online, you can put your name on the waitlist online as well.  Make sure to arrive on time or you risk losing your spot in line!

Overall, Lotus of Siam does have good Thai food that is definitely worth checking out!
Taxi driver told us about it and it was pure bliss. Perfection. A total treat and so glad we went. We had the wings and duck curry and a few Thai iced teas. Glad I went for sure.

The Lotus is going into my Vegas rotation from here on out. Despite visiting LV multiple times a year, I had never tried this well known Thai establishment. I was very impressed with the food and service. Based on Anthony Bourdain's recommendations on his TV show, I skipped right past the first dozen pages or so and went directly to the "Northern Specialty" pages. My party ordered the Khoa Soi, Red Chili Dip, and the Northern Larb. The waiter asked us how spicy we preferred on a scale of 1-10. Now I pride myself on enjoying very spicy food, but the #7 level of spicy really made me sweat. My table also ordered a sticky rice for every person at the table. DEFINITELY GET THE STICKY RICE. I wish I'd saved more room that day and ordered more at LoS, because the food was fantastic. In fact, I may need to push up my next trip to LV in order to get back to LoS ASAP!

The Lotus of Siam is hard to find as it's in a plaza that's indiscriminate and no clear signs on the street side. It was worth the scavenger hunt as the food was delicious. I ordered the Garlic Prawns, Drunken Noodles, and Coconut/Sticky Rice Dessert. The Garlic Prawns were fantastically garlic ridden and crispy/crunchy. The fry was perfect and the prawn meat itself was juicy. The Drunken Noodles while small in portion, had a great flavor and "dragon's breath" flavor. The noodles themselves were cooked perfectly with just the right amount of chewiness. Lastly, to round out my meal I had their dessert: coconut/sticky rice. The coconut flavored ice cream tasted fresh and the steaming sticky rice gave the perfect contrast to the ice cream. Overall, a great Thai food restaurant and next time I'm in Las Vegas, I will definitely be hitting this place up again.

The best Khao Soi since our travels to northern Thailand. The servers are friendly and helpful, this place is always busy and even the greeters always have a smile.  We've always made reservations a day before and have never had to wait more than 5 minutes.  If we don't make reservations, they wait can get long.
