The area is less than desirable and we're always greeted by people asking for money in the parking lot.  But once inside, it's an amazing place for Thai food.
The best Pad Thai I've had thus far! The portion is fantastic, the #7 spice level was on point and the entire dish was VERY flavorful. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!
The best Thai resto I have ever been to. All the dishes we ordered were awesome esp the garlic prawns which are to die for. I wanna go back already! Too bad we have to drive 5hrs to get here.
The best!!! Food is absolutely delicious!! Garlic prawns are to die for.. excellent service and definitely worth the wait. Go!!
The crispy duck curry was amazing!!!!!! Enough said. The service was also on point, very attentive and super nice. Will be coming back whenever I go to Vegas.
The food is absolutely fantastic. Duck Panang was just outstanding and the BBQ shrimp had some of the most vibrant thai flavors I've ever had.  Worth the wait!
The food is amazing, order of the Northern Thai menu

The food is good, very good. Is it outstanding? No, but its very good. The problem here is that the owner-manager is very greedy. They cater to mostly tourists and so, sadly,  it became a tourist trap. They dont offer you a lunch menu if you are a tourist and you will have to pay full dinner menu prices plus they are not friendly at all. The owner manager has a huge chip in his shoulder and believes that he is so above the customers that he wont even answer questions.   He is un-polite and rude. So - go if you want but dont expect much anymore. What a shame.

The food is really good at this restaurant in a run down shopping mall in a bad neighborhood about a mile from the good hotels in Las Vegas. No ambiance but there was a long line to get in.  You will need a reservation!

The food is very good without a doubt but very expensive when considering the portions. I did find that it had some Thai food that I've been looking for for a very long time and that no one else made so that was awesome. The garlic shrimp was great but the prices really are a bit much for what you are getting. We also ordered the crab drunken noodles and it was good but not as good as their garlic shrimp dish. This place is literally printing money.

The food was ok. The waiters suck and food was pricey.  I politely asked for a few things (water and another side of rice) yet it did not come until the I had asked a third time. Of course when requesting my check, it did not come. I had to go to the desk.
The food was really tasty. Try from the northern menu. Portions are medium sized. Lunch service may take a long time but it's worth it. Don't come here in a rush. Parking is very easy.

The fried shrimp and the duck curry were both yummylicious!  I usually don't go off the strip for food in Vegas but I definitely will go back when I'm in town.

I can eat a plate of fried shrimp and that duck curry all to myself (and I'm not even a duck fan).  Portions are unfortunately not that big and it is not cheap, especially for a Thai restaurant, but oh man the taste!
The highest rated Thai restaurant on Zagat.  This restaurant lives up to that reputation.

The menu is very diverse and gives an overwhelming number of options, each one more enticing than the last. The food tastes fresh and is always flavorful. Tonight I had crispy rice with sausage massaman curry, pork belly with basil, and to kah khi soup. Everything tasted amazing. This is a hard place to get a reservation for and the quality of their food shows why

The place looks like a dump friends m the outside, the walls are covered with pics of celebs that have dined here.  What your coming for is the food, so don't be surprised if you get get and have a 20 min wait for one of the 35 tables.

The portions of food are really large, curry taste very well, but the meat taste a little bit dry, and not very tasty when eat inside of meat. Pork has some fat which I don't really like, and some ducks aren't very crispy. I noticed this restaurant won the best of city in 2006,2007, but I feel not very satisfying considering the fame of this restaurant.

The reason that I did not give them 5 stars is because I believe that Kung Fu on Valley View is a better and slightly less expensive restaurant.  But Lotus of Siam is very good.  Yelp wants the attire.  I believe that anything from full formal to basic shirt and pants would be just fine.  I would not go there in cut offs.

The sauces alone would keep me coming back to Lotus of Siam.  I dined with 2 other people and we ordered about 6 or 7 different dishes to try everything, consisting of: the Papaya salad, the Mushroom salad, Pad See Ew, Larb, a Fish dish, and a few other small dishes.  All were delicious and none tasted the same, all uniquely flavored and seasoned.  

My main complaint would be how long the meal lasted.  This may be a Thai cuisine type of complaint, but the food came out so quickly that the meal only lasted about 45 minutes.  When dining out at a nicer place, I like to spend time to savor the meal and conversate.  Lotus of Siam cooks everything to perfection, but very quickly.  Beware if you're looking to spend the night out at Lotus, if so, it will be a very short night.

Pro tip: make a reservation.  They are very strict about showing up on time, but we were seated immediately, while we saw at least 4 parties waiting in line behind us.  Overall, a delicious and great meal

The service is good but I wish they would open another spot towards the other side of town because it's a long trek to get to our fave Thai place. We ordered the $45 snapper panang and it was worth it AF!

There just is no better place in Vegas to get AUTHENTIC Thai food.  Close friend took my family a few years ago who happens to be from Thailand and wanted us to experience the difference between other places we've tried and Lotus of Siam.  Needless to say, we've become loyal customers.  There is often a wait for a table if going for dinner, so it's best to make reservations.  Lunch is rarely busy, so if you can go mid week, it's probably a great time to try.  You'll soon make reservations for dinner if you do!  The wait staff is not only knowledgeable, but also extremely efficient and helpful to those of us that don't know what to order.  This place does it RIGHT!

There was a lot of hype created prior to coming here from my friends. Honestly, the location was a hole in the wall. From the outside, it looked pretty ghetto. However, the restaurant inside looked a lot better. There were plenty of pictures of past celebrities that has been through the restaurant.

The service was on point and attentive , nothing to complain about there.

I'm not a big fan of Thai food, but this place lived quite up to the hype. We started with a squid salad and some soup that I thought were okay and a bit spicy for someone who doesn't eat spice ... Nothing special there. We ordered catfish, pad Thai, garlic prawn, and the duck dish. Out of all the dishes, the garlic prawn was my favorite and the duck would be next. 

Overall, if you like Thai food or want to try Thai food then I would definitely recommend this spot!

There's nothing bad to say about lotus of Siam. The food is absolutely delicious. It's extremely busy, so if you're planning on going make sure you make reservations 3 days ahead of time. Best Thai food in all of Vegas.

They are best known for their garlic prawns so be sure to order it! They separate the shell but somehow leave it attached, then they deep fry the prawns to a golden brown, making it plump, succulent, yet crispy.  The idea is to make it so crispy you can even eat the shell.  Delicious! We also had the drunken noodles (like pad see ew) topped with your choice of duck, soft shell crab or sea bass (which was how we had it). Also good.  The crispy duck over noodles in a coconut curry was also a hit.  The least popular dish was the short ribs in the same, exact curry sauce as the duck...we could've skipped that one entirely. We enjoyed the meal a lot but I had to knock it down by 1 star because every dish we ordered was close to $30 which is way more than the average price of a similar dish in other restaurants within the same class/range. Yelp only has this marked as $$ which I think is misleading. They should be at     $$$.  If you are willing to spend the money then by all means, dine here!

They open at 5:30.  No answering service or machine to leave a msg. or reservation.  So the phone stays busy until forever.  Going somewhere else where they can take a reservation or embrace some kind of technology.

Ok.  With so many stars I tried and got through my 5th try.  We had 5 dishes.  Panang Curry with duck was the best Thai dish I've ever eaten.   And I love Thai.

They say this may be the best Thai food in the U.S. And they are not mistaken. This place is amazing!  From the decor to the service to the FOOD!  We had several things that we shared and there was not one thing we were not salivating over after we were done. It will be one of those places that I crave. Even if you are not a THAI food fan, there are things here that you will love!  This is a must if you are in Vegas!

They're much busier during dinner than lunch. We tried coming here a couple times when we had family in town, but weren't able to secure reservations. So, we decided to come during lunch and were able to get a table immediately. It was Friday and still pretty busy, but as long as you don't have to wait, that's great.

My main focus at Lotus is their Northern Thai specialties. Besides these dishes, there are a lot of other Thai specialties that you don't typically find at other Thai restaurants in the valley. 

Nam Kao Tod ($8.95): Crispy rice mixed with sour cubed pork sausages, cilantro, green onions, grounded dry chili, ginger, peanuts and lime juice. Tasty salad mixture with great texture from the crispy rice. Love all the herbs and flavors.

Sai Oua ($11.95): Northern Thai-style spicy pork sausage. Served with ginger, red onion, chilies, and Napa cabbage. One of my all-time favorite sausages. I love the lemongrass especially. The sausage is great with all the fixings, too.

Nam Prik Ong ($11.95): Northern Thai red chili dip composed of ground pork, tomato, and spices; served with assorted vegetables and fried pork rinds. This dip will remind you of a meat sauce (you could totally create a pasta with it). It has a good depth of flavor and it's not heavy.

Thum Ka Noon ($10.95): Pounded and shredded young jackfruit salad with ground pork, tomato, and northern Thai spices and seasoning. Another delicious Northern Thai specialty. I enjoyed the flavors of this salad more than the Nam Kao Tod and Nam Prik Ong. Goes well with rice.

Crispy Duck Panang ($27.95): Crispy duck topped with Thai style red cream curry sauce with cognac. The duck is juicy and the skin is fantastically crispy. The panang is really great, too and definitely good with any choice of meat, but the crispy duck is the way to go!

Everything is delicious and takes me back to my vacation in Chiang Mai. I'm definitely back for more specialties!

This establishment was highly recommended to me by a friend to try during my visit in Vegas. We were able to skip the long wait by making a reservation so make sure to do that! Unless you are willing to wait a hour. We were seated at a nice table in their second section and was promptly served by a waiter. This waiter was clearly busy was still coming at perfect times during our dine in experience. We got the garlic prawns and drunken noodles with crispy duck. The stuffed chicken was amazing though! Definitely recommended that! They were both delicious however a bit overpriced. Maybe if they up the furniture and the front door upon walking in with the waiting room I would be a bit more at ease paying for this $$$ restaurant. This being a hole in a wall clearly had potential for greatness. The owner was very kind and overall food and service was great. 4/5 due to  it being a bit overpriced.

This is a great restaurant. Lotus of Siam has been called the "best Thai restaurant in North America", and I think it's warranted.  I love the Duck Curry.  But be warned: if you say you want your food prepared "spicy", they make the food VERY spicy. Even if you think you can handle spicy food, you may want to order "medium"--which is still very hot.  The wait is usually quite long, so make a reservation if you can.

This is a nice restaurant, hidden gem in a dated shopping plaza. Don't be deterred by the appearance of the parking lot. The food was all great, and fairly reasonably priced. Something to be noted is that spicy actually means spicy here. I usually like my food spicy, so I tend to order very spicy at other restaurants but was forewarned before coming and was glad I ordered medium spicy so that my food was still enjoyable. We had yellow curry, pad see ewe, laht nah, pork stew, beef salad and spicy mint leaf chicken. Everything was wonderful! Service was excellent. I actually thought I had left my purse there, and when I went back, they went above and beyond to be helpful, even checked surveillance cameras for me. The staff was amazing showing integrity in the way they do customer service! I will definitely be back!

This is a tough one, but its a solid 3.2 Stars (note I rate Din Tai Fung as 3.5 for reference).  3.2 = Solid, happy to come back.

They do take reservations and it is a must unless you want to wait a long while.

This place is called a "Las Vegas Classic."  So hyped.  And as always, it is always hard to meet the hype and it fails a tad here at Lotus of Siam.  Why?  Mainly because the dishes seemed rushed out and you can taste a lack of that sweet care from the chef.  Understandable though because they need to turn tables as fast as possible due to such high demand.

So many famous people have come here, yes, its one of those places as you enter you see all the pictures on the wall of who's who that's has dined here.  The wine selection is stellar as you see it the moment you hit the dining room.  The Service is great, the hostesses are pleasant.  Now to the food.

Papaya Salad - Solid.  The spice associated with the salad was mouthwatering.  This is a dish to order always as it starts it all off perfectly.  It is clean, light, fresh, prepares you for the rest of dinner.

Khao Soy (Crispy Duck, Egg Noodle) - Now this dish is quite stellar.  It is the Northern Thai variant of Khao Soy.  The duck is crispy, but not like the garlic shrimp, more like a crispy, breaded type.  It is succulent, tender, just perfect.  Egg Noodles are perfect and the yellow coconut curry goes all perfectly together.  This is one of those dishes I can have 2-3x a week and I look forward to most when coming here.

Crispy Garlic Shrimp - The hypness hits a roadblock here.  The most famous dish here.  You expect it to be jaw dropping, mouth watering.  It isn't.  The skin is perfectly done to a crisp (you eat it), and the shrimp are of a good size (see picture).  For what most everyone raves about here, I will say it is good, it is tasty, but the star of the restaurant?  Only for people who are novels to it.  Would I order it again?  Yes.  But I would tell my table its one of the entrees that are good here, not the, "OMG WE HAVE TO ORDER THISSSSSS."

Panang -  Decent.  Nothing to write home about.

Green Curry - Forgettable.  Wait, we had green curry?

Sea Bass -  Totally overpriced and small portion.  Skip this.  Nuff said.  This dish is almost a whole Star doc worthy.

Fried Banana with Coconut Ice Cream Dessert - Delicious.  Small chunks of banana fried in an egg roll style.  The delicate thin crispiness was very well appreciated by my mouth.  The coconut ice cream was light and heavenly.  Must Order Dish.

Vibe - Great.  The whole place is hummin along, happy, eatin, drinkin, laughing.  It is like all my Thai friends.  

The menu here is huge.  North and South.  Most of the good dishes seem to come from Northern menu.  We enjoyed it here but like I said, the dishes seemed rushed, but for understandable reasons.  Glad to have tried it.  Come back on next Vegas trip?  Probably not (mainly because Vegas has so many options).  

But damn that Khao Soy callin my name......

This is a wanna be fancy restaurant when it's in a junky ghetto plaza and then they didn't change the carpet when it carpet is a 1970s carpet. They put in a wine rack and lots of wine selection but don't change the carpet. They need to do the whole shebang. 

I had lunch special chicken curry. It was good and it has grape in it. I thought that was unique but not fancy. Like I said they is a wanna be fancy.
This is hands down the best Thai Restaurant I've ever eaten at!!! The seafood drunken noodles are to die for, the bar has definitely been raised after eating here!
This is the best Thai restaurant I have been to. The Garlic Prawns is a must! Tried a few dishes & everything is amazing! I recommend this to all the foodies out there!
This is the best place ever!! I will always recommend this place to my friends

This is truly one of the best meals I've ever had.

I'm a chef. I came here with 5 friends and we ordered 14 dishes and dessert. Everything was solid. Not a single misstep. The restaurant was full and food came out way faster than expected. This place is addicting. I wish I had one of these at home. It baffles me that Lotus of Siam has 4 stars on Yelp. Shows how much bullshit the rating system is. Also everyone who posted a pic and reviewed this place only posted pad Thai. What a bunch of fucking horse shit. This place has so many authentic northern Thai dishes. Every singl one, crazy delicious. Fuck you Yelp

This is usually one if the restaurants that I bring Family and Friends from out of town. It's kind of a "secret" restaurant. Don't let the exterior fool you. The inside is very clean and really "elegant" looking. The portions are kind of on the small side, but still very satisfying. I would of have given 5 stars but the portion sizes kind of upset me. When we go out to eat, we are celebrating and usually don't want to worry about portion sizes. Other than that, enjoy!

This is worth a visit.  It is in a seriously strange group of buildings though.  Must get a reservation and DO NOT be late!  If you are early you can try out some of the other establishments, but don't get anything on you.  I will leave it up to you to find out what goes down in that town.
This place is F'ing awesome awesome awesome awesome awesome awesome awesome awesome!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

This place is amazing! It's hard to get a reservation, especially since they don't have call waiting and only take calls between certain hours. It's off the strip, but so worth the trip. They actually have a really impressive wine list too. Everytime I'm in Vegas, I go here!

This place is busy, not because of the location either.  Located in a challenged commercial center, Lotus was the only place hopping.  Waited 20 minutes to be seated.  The menu is extensive and amazing.  Tried new food that I can't pronounce but savored.  The wine selection - that'll blow your socks off.  Never been to Thai food and have the selection of wines like the offer - its pages and pages.  Sad that I've lived here for 30 years and never made it here.  Can't wait to go back.
This place is great and everyone knows it. Huge menu, big nice place. Come early to beat the dinner rush.
This place is on several TV shows as fantastic Thai food.  And it really is.  I wish the portion sizes were bigger given the price.  But man Oh man,  it is so so so good.

This place is tucked away in a non descript strip mall off of Sahara.  We got there right when lunch service was ending but they still seated us.  Food was very good but the serving size was on the small side.  Looked like they had a really good wine selection too.

This place looks a bit sketchy from the outside and is slightly tricky to find, but keep looking and don't let the outside appearance scare you.  Once you start chowing you will be hooked.  I can't wait to go back.

I told the waiter what I was interested in and he guided me to select something off the menu and it was awesome and spicy.  It was on a bed of cabbage with boiled sea bass and the spicy sauce from one of the salmon dishes.  I had it for an entree but would have preferred to share as an appetizer.

This place used to be awesome. Met our friends from out of town at this place and was shocked how the quality has gone DOWN. The portion sizes are pitiful now. Food still tastes okay but I never thought it was that amazing compared to any other Thai restaurants in town. 

I was also taken aback when we made our reservation and they said that if we were more than 5 minutes late, they would cancel it! FIVE MINUTES!?!?! The standard in restaurant industry is 15. We had a large party as well and people were arriving separately. I guess they don't want to encourage locals to come here. 

I think it's time to find a new Thai restaurant to recommend to my friends who are visiting Vegas.

This place was way over hyped. Pad se-ew was mainly flavorless noodle. It contained very little chicken or broccoli. I also order Tom Yum noodle soup. The Tom yum had a variety of veggies that I haven't seen in the fish prior. The change of piece was different but I did enjoy it. Bit dishes were under salted. I have said it in every other review of a Thai restaurant but this place still can't compare to to Lucki Thai on the south side.

This place will have you swinging! No, I'm not referring to the swingers club that shares the parking lot, instead the "off the chains" food. Arrive early or attempt to get reservation if you want to visit Lotus of Siam. From the outside it's unassuming and quiet but once inside it's bustling with excited foodie patrons. The menu is large, offering numerous dishes from multiple regions of Thailand. Do yourself a favor and order from the Northern or Chef Specials sections, you will not be disappointed. 

Our party of 4 tried:

Koong Sarong - Very good, not greasy at all. Good dish for the less adventurous people in your party.
Nam Kao Top - (Spicy Level 4) While very limey, it's balanced much better when eaten with the cabbage.
Garlic Prawns - My favorite dish of the night. I was not a huge fan of eating the shell but I tried it and enjoyed one. The shell was much more tender than I thought it would be but a little on the salty side. The actual prawn meat was delicious, perfectly cooked with a slight crisp on the outside.
Crispy Duck with Panang - (Level 3) While I'm not a huge fan of duck, I had heard a lot about this dish and had to try it. The duck was cooked perfectly, crispy skin and moist on the inside. The meat was not overly fatty like I'm used to eating and the curry sauce was different (no coconut milk) but a great addition to the overall flavor.
Nua Nam Tok - (Spice Level 4) Very similar to the flavors of the Nam Kao Top, good but not great.

We noticed many people ordering the soups, especially the Fish Soup but it was over 105 degrees that day and soup was the furthest thing from what I wanted. It looked wonderful and will be my order when I go back in the winter.

Lotus is perfect for taking visiting friends from out of town who want to experience Vegas food off the strip. The food is good, the service was incredibly good, way better than I expected. If you're lucky you can start up a conversation with the James Beard winning Chef Saipin Chutima who was spotted multiple times walking through the dining area.

This is a must visit for anybody who lives in Vegas.

This restaurant doesn't look like much on the outside, but inside it's lavish. They even showcase their cold wine room in glass.

The food, based on northern Thai, was superb! We had the pad woon sen and their original dish kang ka noon made with Jack fruit, $10.95 each. Both were delectable and a good size. Total price was $23.68 but worth it since it's fresh. 

The service was extremely friendly and patient with our order, since they have a large menu! As Thai connoisseurs from LA, since we frequent Thai Town often, we recommend!

This restaurant is...bizarre.  The exterior looks like a foot massage parlor. It's in very close proximity to SEVERAL foot massage parlors, actually. After driving here with your Zagat review in hand, you'll double-check and triple - check whether you're at the right place.
But step inside, and your anxiety is replaced with welcome  relief. The floor-to-ceiling wine bottles behind the glass wall near the door assures you that not only are you safe, but that you'll probably leave with a full stomach and maybe a buzz. The decor is plain but comfortable.
The food, however, is hit or miss. We ordered the chicken satay and agreed that it was the worst both of us have ever had (& coming from different cities, we've sampled our share of Thai food). The chicken was a semi-soft, almost artificial consistency and the seasoned exterior was somewhat slimy.  The flavor itself was average. Insert *blechh!*-faced emoji here...
Our entrees were better, moving up to a solid, "acceptable". We ate them, but have had better. Mine was pad prik khing and hers was a curry shrimp dish.
Lastly, the dessert, coconut ice cream with sticky rice, was presented plainly (see pic), but really very good. As full as I was at that time, I didn't leave a grain of rice in that sadly empty little bowl.
Bottom line? 
Probably not worth the Uber trip cost, despite the fair prices. Stay on the strip.

This review probably would have been higher if I didn't have to wait Two hours to sit and eat!!! You will need to reserve a table a few days before to have a better experience. I know what you're thinking, who in their right mind would wait that long to eat... 

Me! I've heard great things about this place and recently read an article that Lotus of Siam was one of the top 10 Thai Restaurants in the USA! So I had to try.. 

We got the usual order, Pad Thai, Chicken Curry and Basil Fried Rice. All three were really good but not worth the wait. I should have tried their more exotic options on the menu like the crispy duck curry... maybe next time.

This truly is a hidden treasure!!!  We are so glad that Yelp helped us discover it.  The place looks sketchy from the outside, but once you walk in the aromas are tantalizing.  We really enjoyed our crispy duck and catfish entrees, which were recommended by our great server.  The service was impeccable.  We look forward to a return visit!

This was beyond good! Friends of us (from Vegas) suggested this restaurant. Off Strip. In - for us - the middle of nowhere. A desolate piece of commercial space. We had to search for right adress because it's on not on the road side.

The Lotus of Siam is so popular that's reservations only. If you're not there on time (5 minutes prior to your reservation) they give away your table. Outside the're lines. And we know why.

We're a party of six with one real Thai Lady. Just in the USA for less than six months. Even she liked and approved the meals.

We had different dishes to share. The dishes that most impressed were the crispy duck, the pineapple rice and the Tom Kah Kai. All together we order two hot pot's of soup, the garlic shrimps and seven main courses. With a few alchoholic consumptions the total bill ran up tot $250 for six people. Not much for such a nice meal. We'll definitly be back.

Thought my friends were exaggerating. But they were right! This is the best Thai food I ever had!  Garlic shrimp is to die for! Not too salty just perfect! The duck in panang curry sauce. So yummy. Can't wait to come back and try other dishes! I hear it's usually really busy but we can on a Monday afternoon and their was no wait.

Tons of choices, all authentic, fresh, and delicious! Party of 5 with main dishes, appetizers and drinks less than a Ben Franklin. Great service and relaxing intimate atmosphere. Off the strip by 10 min and worth every effort. Second visit here to make sure it was no fluke the first time. Wasnt disappointed. Will go back soon!!
Too long a wait and far too expensive

Took a group of my coworkers here and every one of us was completely satisfied. Food was authentic and delicious, flavorful, good portions. Whether you like mild or spicy food, are carnivorous or vegetarian, you'll find something here for you. For 9 people, the food came out of the kitchen extraordinarily fast. I got the yellow curry and s Thai iced tea - perfect. For my colleagues I ordered the chicken satay, fried rolls, and spring rolls appetizers and we made very quick work of them. 

Staff was friendly and attentive. They can be difficult to get ahold of by phone, probably because of high call volume. They're popular for a reason. Interior was nice and clean (which makes up for the slightly shady-looking exterior... Its in a run down shopping center) they have an extensive wine list, too. I will be back!

Touted as one of the best Thai restaurants in Vegas, I was very excited to try their food. Well, the food was just about average. My friend and I had their Pineapple fried rice, a curry dish, and fried prawn dish. Nothing exceptional, but about average. I've had better Thai food in Baltimore.
Usually, Thai places are a hit and miss for me. So far everything we ordered were really delicious. I have no complaints. The service was fast too.

Very good Thai food in a very dull setting. Overall, I really enjoyed the food, but I feel this place  is a bit overhyped, perhaps due to lack of good Thai in Vegas overall? If you have good Thai food where you live, don't go out of your way to eat here unless you're really in the mood, as there was nothing here terribly out of the ordinary. If I were in Vegas, with a serious hankering for Thai, I would go back, but don't go here expecting an otherworldly food experience, unless of course, you've never had goo Thai to begin with.  The curries we ordered, and the jack fruit salad were our favorites, we weren't quite as impressed with the noodle dishes.
Very good food, but a little slow on service and too much ice on my drink. Had to pay twice for what I consider "sips".

Very unassuming place in a very shady looking strip mall. If you are anything like us and you drove by and didn't know its reputation you would probably take a pass. But this place is the real deal, believe the hype! 

Food is absolutely amazing. I will say that service is not the best. They rush you and are a bit rude but with food like this I can deal. Don't come here expecting to be treated like a princess, experiment with the menu and do some research. You won't regret it. 

Soooooo good!!

Visited this place a few years back. So fantastic that we recommended to everyone visiting Vegas. Visited Vegas again in Dec 2015. Was looking forward to going to this place than anywhere this time. First, the place had a 1.5 hr wait for lunch. Understood, need to wait sometimes for good things to come. Next, when we got the table, the service was slow. When the food came, the main entrees came along with soup and appetizers. The food quality was mediocre at best and proportions small. What a let down for travelling across the country!! This place gets good business as they are recommended in travel books and also by their  previous  reputation. This place is done for us. Next time, I will go to other Thai restaurants in the same strip. Maybe, they believe in food quality and service.

Was so looking forward to eating here. With all the accolades was expecting authentic delicious food. I should of known better when seeing all the celebrity pictures on the wall. 
I've lived in Thailand, learned how to cook from grandmothers and professionals cooks. The food here is watered down sweet interpretation of Thai food. Great job in marketing poor job on taste!

We came here after a long drive through Death Valley National Park on the recommendations of two different friends. We were so excited to have a meal here, and while the food was okay, we felt a little disappointed.

First, we got seated quickly on a busy Sunday evening which was good. However, once seated, it took a while to get our orders placed and to get our food. This was pretty understandable, it's Easter weekend and things get busy fast - no big complaints. We ordered the garlic shrimp and the crispy duck on drunken noodles.

While both dishes were tasty, it was a little too salty all around. The garlic shrimp felt like it had just been reheated (a few of the shrimp were a little cold and not warmed through all the way) and the drunken noodles were congealed in bunches. Overall, the food was tasty, but nothing I'd recommend going out of the way for.

We came here because we were stopping through LV and my dad recently hopped onto the Anthony Bourdain hypetrain. Therefore, whatever AB says is good, we try. 
If you want to come and you're from out of town, definitely reserve a week or at least a few days prior. You will not regret it. Service was great though we still waited 20 minutes to get a table set up. Not a big deal, since it was 7 o'clock and clearly the dinner rush. 

We ordered Nam Kao Tod, Khao Soi, Mango and Sticky Rice, Red Pork Curry, and the Young Jackfruit Salad. People urged us to order from the Northern Thai Menu and avoid ordering stuff like Pad Thai. 
I didn't really know what to expect because I had never had these dishes before, but the Nam Kao Tod and the Jackfruit definitely stood out to me. I was also really hungry and we ordered such a vast variety of stuff I think I forgot how to appropriately savor my food and kind of put everything into my face hole. Oops. The Khao Soi is delicious too, it's kind of like a red coconut curry with noodles in it. It didn't wow me, but it was still very good. 

I kind of wish I did get typical Thai fare like Pad Thai/Rad Na or whatever and compare it to the stuff I usually get in San Diego/Portland, but I'm glad we explored N. Thai cuisine! 

Thanks AB.

We came here from LA that has arguably has the best Thai in the country. This place is amazing and rivals some of my favorite places in LA. 

 It's in a strip mall but the interior is welcoming. It is a nice place to beat The Strip's craziness. I will
come here for a local Vegas perspective. 

GARLIC PRAWNS!!! To die!
We can't come to Vegas without coming here.  The food is always good and perfect for the spicy food lover.  Many dishes can be modified if spice isn't your thing.

We decided to give it a try even though we love china town. The Garlic prawns were great as an appetizer $26, I had the beef short ribs in red curry and my wife had the sea bass on papaya salad. There was only Apple on her papaya salad. I was still good though. We didn't feel this restaurant matched it's pricing or the hype. $110 for lunch, no liquor, no appetizers. If they marked everything down 50% we would probably go back.
 Try it if you like but for half price you can get great or better food in China town including 2 full body massages for less money!!

We hit there after the lunch rush. You would never guess from the front of the building that this is such a large restaurant. Coming in, you pass a lot of signed 8 x 10 glossies, Wine Spectator awards, and other testaments to the quality of the food. Unfortunately, I wasn't impressed with the service. We were seated at a table in a very large room that seemed to only have two waiters working the entire section. After 10 minutes of not being acknowledged (you know -- the not-making-eye-contact trick), I had to wave my arms to get some water and attention. By the reviews, this is obviously a very good restaurant. As for the food, the yellow curried chicken that I had was dry. My dining companion even said that it looked dry. The chicken looked like it had been boiled, shredded, and sprinkled with a curry sauce. There were a couple of what could only be described as chicken rinds on the plate. I get it. I probably came at the wrong time and ordered the wrong food. My bad. Would I come at dinner time and wait for hours for a table? I don't know.

We knew that this trip, we needed to try Lotus. 
We tried for dinner on a Thursday night and wait was 1.5 hours, reservations for dinner were booked a week out :( the host suggested we come back when they open at 11. Lunch is first come first serve.
Flash forward to Friday morning, we show up about 11:05 and there were about 4 tables already sat and a steady stream of tables after us.
I got the drunken noodle prawn off the chefs recommendation , the FI got a street vendor special that was on the northern specialty menu and we go the #14 appetizer that our waiter suggested. 
No joke, best Thai food we've had. The originality the menu had, the last 4 pages...that's what you come here for.
Slap yourself if you get Pad Thai....
Food has major flavor....like an explosion of spice and heat and layer upon layer of it. Oh man....yep. that good.
We love this place! Whenever my husband and I talk about Vegas we think of lotus of Siam. And they have a clever wait app/system.

We made reservation to this place a month prior and was able to score a table for 3 at 6:30pm on a saturday night. Good thing we were able to do that otherwise the wait is 2 hours on the shady side of Vegas where there's nothing else to do around.

Location is odd as it's in a very empty looking strip mall. 

The doors for dinner open at 5:30 and when we arrived there was a line out the door trying to get in. We were seated within 2 mins of checking in. 

The interior reminds me of a 80s oriental style restaurant, but I came here for the food after reading rave reviews by Jonathan Gold and seeing a special on Parts Unknown (Vegas).

The place was already packed inside, a lot of large groups (family style type service). 
The wall had a lot of photos of well known celebrities and celebrity chefs.Also had a wall of numerous awards.

We order a bowl of soup to share and a couple of dishes (Green curry chicken and pineapple fried rice). All three dishes had the right balance in taste. all very excellent compared to some of the best Thai places I've been to.

Price is very reasonable. 

Service was very attentive even though the place was busy. 

Would definitely come back and try some of their more well known dishes of Northern Thailand but would def make a reservation in advance.
We went there again. Arrived at 6 pm. No line! Great food at great price. The best Rioja that I had drink in the States. Right temp, excellent! $25.00. Amazing.

We were directed to this place by a friend of ours who ate there a few weeks ago. We're really glad we tried it. No it's not in the fancy area of Las Vegas but don't let that dissuade you. Their food is really good and the service is even better. They also have an unbelievable wine selection.

We've been to this place a few times and quality has quickly declined. The menu makes very little sense, portions were tiny and entrees were cold. For very expensive Thai food, you should keep looking. We will not be back.
Went there 3 times,so dissapointed,My food is over cooked.T thai food restaurant at upper jones and flamingo much better.

Went to the restaurant on a high recommendation of a friend.  I was sooo disappointed.  First, there was a long wait of almost an hour for a Tuesday night.  A look around told me I was really in for it.  Seemed like a tourist place.  Ordered a porched Chilean sea bass on a salad.  The sea bass was totally overcooked, and the salad mainly consist of julian apples, onions, etc.  Totally bad.  Ordered a pork curry, which is more like a curry soup.  We complained that the sea bass was totally dry, and the answer I got was: "It is supposedly cooked like that"!  And the Chilean cost $30.00.  I will never go back to that place again!
What can I say?  This place is so amazing.  Everything I've tried is fantastic.  Like spicy?  Ask for #11.  And a fire extinguisher for your tongue.

What can be said that hasn't already been said about Lotus of Siam? Amazing Thai food, plenty of seating, and great service. A restaurant as famous as Lotus of Siam doesn't need my paltry review to tempt you. Just go. You won't be disappointed!

When we arrived we had to wait over forty minutes to get a table. We ordered three different main courses to share. The food all arrived cold. We asked them to remake the food and all they did was microwave it and bring it back to us. The Penang curry had about half as much chicken as any standard Thai restaurant and the chicken was very tough. The rice that came with the curry was smaller than a single ice cream scoop, so not enough for even one person. The crispy duck with drunken noodles was not crispy, but actually squishy. The Pad Thai was flavored well, but had almost no chicken in it. I think we were able to count three or four tiny pieces of chicken. Overall, I was not impressed. The duck was nearly $30 and there wasn't even enough food for one person. We left hungry and decided not to risk ordering a dessert. I know this place has high reviews, but all I can think is that people who review it highly haven't had much Thai food. Most Thai restaurants provide better food for better prices than this restaurant.
While we ate here, I did not think it lived up to the hype...  Service or quality.  I probably wouldnt go back if someone else didnt recommend it.
Worth the wait. Incredible menu with a great wine list as well. We came in with a group, shared our plates, and received great service. Easily the best Thai food I have ever had.
Wow! Garlic shrimp is to die for! Our whole meal was amazing. Wife and I are making this a must stop every time we go to Vegas! Thanks for a great meal and great staff!

Wow, this place lived up to the hype. I ordered beef pad see ew to go and it was hands-down the best I have ever had. Not overly greasy and the noodles tasted very fresh-almost like they make their own from scratch. It was awesome.

Wow.  This was definitely worth the trip off: the strip.  Located on Sahara Ave in a part of town I would not otherwise have known to visit but for hearing great things about this place from various sources, including a fellow diner at Kabuto's.  

We got here at 8:45pm and was seated in 15 minutes.  Three dishes were ordered.

Drunken Noodle with Soft Shell Crab.  A good balance of sweet, sour, spicy, and salt, along with the fragrant basil.  The noodles were not overcooked, and the dish was well balanced. 

Crispy Duck Khao Soi.  The components of this dish by themselves wee not that remarkable.  Noodles that could be purchased at the 99 store (as I've done in the past), along with duck that has been crispy fried, and the curry.  However, blended together this dish was different, fun, and tasty. 

Garlic Prawn - A generous portion, crispy, lightly battered, infused with garlic.  

This has moved to the top of the list of Thai restaurants that I enjoy.

Yes it's a hole in the wall in Las Vegas but it is definitely a must. Even the locals know to go here. 

The must-haves:

Crispy Duck in Panang - OMG!!! Died and went to heaven. 
Garlic Prawns - large portion big enough to share.

We also had the green papaya salad but I didn't care for the preparation. I'm used to it being served with less fish sauce and thinly sliced shrimp. This version was a bit saturated in sauce. 

The location is somewhat hard to find in a strip mall, and the front looks unassuming. Once you enter the restaurant you're surprised as it's much nicer inside. You can tell it's famous by all the pictures of celebrities on the wall. 

I will definitely be back.

Yes, it is as good as its many awards, honors, and praises suggest. Order from the "Northern" part of the menu, which is towards the back pages of it.

I went with a group of 8 and nobody was disappointed. I had the Khao Soi which was so hearty and flavorful. With spicy level 6, it just had a nice kick without being hot. Perhaps Northern Thai is a little more relaxed than other places I have been with they spicy level. Our table tried everything from En Tuan soup (beef tendon with a deep rich broth and a huge basil taste), to Kang Hung Lay (Pork "stew" curry). 

What the group liked the most was the lightness of the dishes. The focus on herbs, spices and not coconut cream really allowed us to fill up without feeling weighed down.

My only regret is not getting the Nam Prik Ong, but that will happen next time!
You can't go wrong with Lotus of Siam. Wonderful selection and consistently solid. Make sure to have a reservation on weekend evenings, though.

Yum! yum! yum! yum!

I read the review and decided to try it. the lives up tt the reviews.  it is off the strip , just few light away. i got a pick up , wasn't sure of the neighbourhood
Yum. Loved everything. So good and very reasonable, price wise! Will eat here again every time I'm in Vegas. The garlic prawns and crispy duck Penang are my favorite! Great wine list too.

"Big things poppin' and little things stoppin" - TI

This place is wonderful.  Thank you anthony bourdain and jet tila for introducing this place to the world.  It is off the strip so a bit harder to get to but the food is poppin with flavor.   

*****papaya salad - AAammazing spicy but amazing best i ever had
**** garlic prawns - poppin with flavor
** soft shell drunken noodle - it was ok

Stick with the dishes at the back of the menu
authentic Thai place and very decent food. a bit of overpriced and kind of over hyped by all the other reviews.

believe the hype!!! thank you, that is all.

jk... but seriously, this place is realllllly good.  YOU MUST GET THE GARLIC PRAWNS AND CRISPY DUCK WITH PANANG.  We had other dishes - papaya salad, green chili dip, and a soup noodle i can't remember the name of and a couple thai teas & coffees.  Everything was what thai food is suppose to be - sweet, spicy, salty and sour.   Uhhhg SO GOOD!  We went here with my family for lunch and wanted to go back for dinner in the same day.

if you expect to eat here, make sure you come with a lot of patience.  This is the worst experience I have ever had in a restaurant and I have been in restaurants all over the world. 
Let's start off with the wait; over an hour to be seated. Add an additional hour to get your food and finally when you do get your food, it's cold, but the waiter tells you, "we serve all our food at room temperature"...are you kidding me?
The portions are small but what's more is the horrible attitude of the wait staff. 
With all the amazing restaurants to eat in Vegas, save yourself a trip.

it's true: you need to make reservations or be ready to wait a looooong time. try making them a week in advance if possible.

as far as the food is concerned, we stuck mostly with the northern thai menu since that's the stuff you can't get elsewhere. if you just want some pad thai go elsewhere, this place will be wasted on you.

the garlic prawns were beyond awesome, though if i go again i'll probably try something else. there are so many options! the crispy duck with chili and basil leaves was amazing. it would be hard not to get that again. i've never had anything like the pounded and shredded jackfruit but it was so good i'd order that again in a heartbeat. we got some fried rice for the kids. it was pretty good and is a nice option if you have someone less adventurous in your group. but again, you don't go to lotus of siam for fried rice. 

next time i'm in vegas i'll definitely be back, and maybe more than once.
nam prik noom, kang hung lay,? thum ka noon - jack fruit salad, northern larb, khao soi,  only order the northern thai.

the hype is real! haha...after years of hearing about this place, i finally got to try it during a recent trip to vegas. we stopped here for lunch on the way into town on Friday around 1pm and we only had to wait about 10 minutes for a party of 3 so not bad at all. the menu is pretty overwhelming since there is so much to selection and even after scouring yelp reviews, we still didnt know what to get haha...so we left the choice up to our trusty server. we asked him for the most popular dishes and without hesitation had his top 3 choices for us (but since we were hungry, we asked for his top 4 picks instead haha).

we ordered:
garlic prawns - so much great garlic flavor, freshly fried but with a light better. such a nice crisp to it and you cant even tell that it's fried with the shell still on it
drunken noodles with sea bass - my favorite dish of my lunch! the sea bass was fried with a light batter that almost reminded me of like an agedashi tofu dish. it was so delicious though and paired with the fat noodles - the best!
beef dish w/peanut sauce - cant remember the name of this dish but it was strips of steak with mixed veggies over this amazing peanut sauce that we were pretty much just dipping in everything haha
crispy duck in red curry - another amazing dish. luckily we had ordered this only at a spice level 2 out of 10 and it had the right amount of kick to it where we could still appreciate the flavor of the curry without having our mouths on fire haha.
fried banana for dessert - even this simple dessert at most restaurants came out way above average haha. banana was fried in more of an egg roll wrapper and freshly fried with a great crisp/crunch to it. (seriously whatever they're doing here to fry their food is amazing haha)

totally amazing lunch and was a great start to our weekend in vegas! the restaurant is pretty pricey but definitely worth it!
very good restaurang
season2

A solid 3.5 stars for the food and 4/5 for service. 

From the Outside this place looks super ghetto, sketchy and dead. But inside is a nice casual ambience with two sides of a dining room. 

I definitely think this place is overhyped, although It is better than other Thai places in Vegas. We ordered a grip load of food between the 4 of us. 

Raw shrimp- 5/5. Best raw shrimp compared to my area in Orange County . The chili sauce and house made satay chili oil together was a mouth orgasm. Yum. 

Seafood Tom Yum- 3.5/5 I think I like my soup more with a spicier and tangy kick to it. This soup was just okay to me. 

Garlic Prawn Shrimp- 3.5/5 it's good, don't get me wrong. It's got a good taste and nice crisp to it. But it's nothing mind blowing because I've had something similar to it before. 

Spicy Spaghetti- 3.0/5 not what I imagined .. I thought it was going to have tomato/marinara sauce but it was some spicy chili sauce. 

Kao Soi- 4.5-5 crispy duck curry with egg noodle was great. The curry was too much coconut for my taste but that's only because I'm sensitive to coconut, otherwise this is a great noodle dish! 

Beef jerky- 4.5/5 such a random pick my friend ordered but it's a solid appetizer just to pick at. It's surprisingly good and addicting!

We had other items but not worth mentioning. Overall... I probably wouldn't make a visit if I was in Vegas again.
All the food here is good. But do I think its the best thai food I have ever eaten? No. Overrated.

Amazing Thai food, recognized by a lot of famous people. 
Lotus of Siam made the best pad thai I've had my entire life. The flavors were incredible, and the noodles were perfect. I can't go back to another Thai restaurant and expect the same from them anymore. 
The only thing is, they do get very busy (because they're well known), but trust me. IT IS SO WORTH THE WAIT!!
You know I'll be coming back. It's a shame how far I live from them!
Amazing amazing amazing. Huge wine selection. Just pick anything and you won't be disappointed. :-)
Amazing food! Best Thai teas in the area!  Worth the wait.  Line out the door when they open for dinner.  Service is good as well.

Been here many times, great food, line is long, plan to come here from LA to celebrate my wife BD with 14 friends, called last week to make reservation for Saturday,  they will not accept reservation for Saturday night. We agreed for Sunday night instead, they required minimum,we agreed, they said will send us an email to fill out information require to deposit, been waiting and calling, as of today get no email from them.
We called another Thai Restaurant on the same street, beautifully set it up for us for Saturday and they also have a pastries chef to do a beautiful cake for my wife and this venue is so clean and beautiful.
If you happen to have the same situation look around and you will find this restaurant and try out ,you will love the place, the pastries, the food and the most important thing is their services.
Adios Lotus of Siam.

Every one said that this is the best Thai food in Vegas. Even a guy sitting next to me when We were eating pho at somewhere else. Indeed, this is the best Thai food as for as I know, not only in Vegas. Recommend crispy duck, squid salad and pineapple fire rice.
Food was really good. Location is a bit sketchy but well worth it. Reservations are recommended.
Great spices, good staff

I have a painful experience I would like to share but first, let me get my order out of the way. I had ordered the red curry and the nam prik ong. It was quite well actually. For my birthday, I'd thought to treat my family to a place I've heard extensive publicity about. All of the reviews and pictures seemed to give it proper accolades so it was a must to eat there. We only waited 15 minutes, they sat us down, and we looked through the menu. We ordered our dinner, talked amongst each other about what we did during the day, and we waited. Once the food was out, the aroma made us happy and we began to eat. I thought the nam prik ong was supposed to arrive first like how I asked but I can eat it after my red curry. We ate slowly and still talked amongst each other. It was going well until we seen the servers standing by us, asking if we were done with our meals. Obviously if you stop eating to chat, the assumption of you being done seems questionable. But these welcoming men turned into vultures, constantly asking if we were finished. Their smiling demeanor turned into angst that made everyone uncomfortable. I took my time to finish my meal while they where practically begging us to ask for the check. I finished my red curry but I was still waiting for my nam prik ong. The server who took my order asked if he could clean the table while I surfed the web for places to go after. He asked politely if I can scoot over so they could rearrange the tables too. My family is waiting outside and I'm waiting for my other half that I ordered. I finally ask the man about it and he seemed hazed as if I was the one who decided to order at that very last minute. He even insisted on pulling out my chair so I could leave but I told him directly again about my order. I can see the sweat on his forehead as he wrote it down again. While I waited again, I can see everyone else was having a different experience. I saw the beautiful menu throughout the restaurant from what people had ordered. And I saw the money hungry people who run the place. I never want to feel like there's a price on my head again. I never ever want the servers to make it obvious that they're "losing money" because of our warmth as a family to chat amongst each other. I ate the red chili dip and left. My question is, how much did they pay you Anthony Bourdain and Action Bronson? How much did they pay you to say those kind words? That this is one of the greatest places to eat in Las Vegas. I hate this place. I will never eat there again.

I'm not a fan of the area, first of all but I had heard really good things about this place so I tried it. It was good. Busy with average service. I found most of the food pretty good (4 stars) but the higher price and smaller portions make this only 3 stars for me. One of my favorite dishes when I eat Thai food is the Beef Salad. Although theirs was very good, it was nothing like I expected, and not what I wanted.

I've been completely been spoiled when it comes to Thai food thanks to home cooking and spectacular places in NYC and LA. Lotus though, isn't too bad.

Getting here may terrify some of you, especially at night. Like almost everything off the strip, Lotus resides in a strip mall. This one is particularly sparse and shady and is populated by folks who will solicit you for money.

Once you walk in through the doors, wow! Shiny! Especially that liquor and wine room! The walls are lined with photos of mama chef with various celebs. But, I'm here for the food, so let's have it.

Chicken larb, moo yang, rice and singha. I thought these would be a good indicator of the food here. The larb was good (although not spicy for a "Medium Thai" request). The moo yang was also good, with all the right aromas, flavors, and sauces. Did it blow me away? No. If I were in Vegas, would I come back? Yes.

Until the next.

I've been to Vegas countless times and I can't believe I haven't eaten here! It was so bomb. 

I can't remember all the dishes we got, but we tried to go for the non-traditional Thai dishes. We had the soft shell crab noodle dish and a curry one and crispy shrimp. We also ordered a bamboo rice which was a bit sticky but necessary to order. 

The wait can be crazy, especially on a weekend night, but we called ahead and asked if we could put our name down. She told us she wouldn't be able to take our name down over the phone but she did direct us to the website where we could join the wait list. That was the best idea ever. We stayed at our hotel for a few minutes, made our way down and by the time we got to the restaurant 20 minutes later, we were seated within a minute. Another family that had walked in right after us were quoted one hour. So that's the secret. Put yourself on the waitlist online. You'll thank me!

If you are ever in Las Vegas, you have to try this place. We came here with 12 people and everyone enjoyed every appetizer and main course we got. The drinks were great and desserts were even better! And the best part of this was it was really cheap! When you pull into the driveway, it looks like a strip mall. But when you come inside, it's nicer than your best 5 star restaurants! Don't come to Vegas and not try this place! Make sure you ask for Adam! He made our night complete and fun!

If you are visiting Vegas, you absolutely must experience this historic staple in our Valley. The food is fantastic and seemingly authentic. I think they can upgrade fixtures, cutlery, decor but the food more than compensates for the outdated look ;)

Lotus of Siam is a hidden gem in LV! The plaza seems pretty empty and run down; however, the restaurant gets pretty packed. We stopped by at lunch time on a Monday, and the restaurant quickly filled up. We ordered the crispy garlic prawns, crispy duck panang curry, and drunken noodle with soft shelled crab. If you can handle spicy food, definitely tell your server a number greater than 5 for the level of spiciness. I would recommend that you come with a large party so that you can order multiple dishes and dine "family-style."

Lotus of Siam was one of the best (and affordable!) meals I had in Vegas. It was so good that it put me in a four hour food coma that left me missing all the activities on my last night in Sin City -- no regrets.

I highly recommend reservations since the line was hopping before it was even open. We were lucky enough to snag a last minute reservation and got to skip the long line of hot and hungry patrons outside. The decor here is warm and homey -- like every family owned Thai restaurant you would fine in your favorite suburban strip mall in Anywhere, America. Lotus of Siam specializes in Isan food which is pretty similar to the Laotian/Cambodian food I've had in the past meaning it was extra, extra delicious!

My best friend and I shared:
+ Garlic Prawns: The prawns are cut to look like the shell has molted off the flesh and then deep fried. Disgusting yes, but also very yummy and crunchy! As the menu said -- it's like potato chips! This hearty portion was on almost every table in the joint and for good reason too.
+ Panang Crispy Duck: Lotus of Siam does the deep fried game very well and this duck did not disappoint. I'm usually wary of duck curries because they can be very gamey but that was not the case at all -- this was recommended to us by our server since the bbq hen was not available and ended up being one of our favorite things on the menu!
+ Khao Soi - Burmese Egg Noodles in curry sauce. A unique dish that I have not seen on any other Thai menu near my house so we had to get this! It's super runny but totally worth the mess.
+ Nam Kao Tod: Crispy Rice Salad very similar to a Laotian dish I'm obsessed with. It was spicy and crunchy and full of different herbs and flavors! I recommend asking for extra lettuce to scoop this up since the cabbage they gave us was quite small and do not do the job right.

I would skip eggrolls or dumplings -- they are bland and not worth the space in your tummy.

I'll definitely be hitting this place up the next time I'm in Vegas. Thanks Chrissy Teigen (and everybody else in the world) for the recommendation!

My dearly departed friend Mark Maher recommended this place!  It's truly the most authentic Thai outside of Thailand I've ever had.  I will make sure to visit every time we are in Vegas.
Try the back portion of the menu!
Our favorite Las Vegas restaurant!  World-class Thai food. Try the Nua Sao Renu (charbroiled beef with tamarind sauce).  This is the best Thai food we've had, ever.

Place blows me away every time..
I love to see a cidre from Brittany amazing pairing w spicy...
Ironically, I put a review on chada street yelp saying he should get a cidre. THat was before I knew lotus had a cidre. 

Stay northern and order things you never would otherwise and you will eat amazing food.. Expect terrible and rude service that's how u know you are in a good Thai spot. Love it!!!

Pretty much the best Thai food in the US. Definitely go for their Northern dishes, including stuff from both the Mae Hong and Isaan regions. I never leave here dissatisfied, and the only problem is that it's so tasty that you have to book well in advance, so be forewarned!

Quality is really good. Khoa Soi is something I would eat again for sure. Crispy Duck with drunken noodles wasn't a favorite. Want to try the garlic prawns and curry next time. 
I wish this place was more intimate but the food is really good.

So beyond flavorful!! Ordered pad Thai, some sort of beef with lime, cilantro, and who knows what else in it but it was flavorful! Chicken satay for appetizer. Thai tea. I wish I would have taken pictures! Service was great!!

The Nam Kao Tod completely blew us away. Absolutely worth the Uber trip to this spooky strip mall. (Hint: if you have to wait for a table, go to the Cornish Pasty Co. very nearby for some great beers.)

Everything else was fantastic, especially the Crispy Garlic Prawns. The chef's specials and the northern Thai parts of the menus are the places to go for entrees.

So how amazing was the their famous Nam Kao Tod? So insanely good that we couldn't get it out of our heads, and went back three days later and each got an order of our own as an appetizer. Unforgettable.

The food was delicious only when it was served hot. I ordered the drunken noodle with crispy duck but it was not served hot. the noodle was soggy and it looked like it was a left over from yesterday.... when complained, our server took it and brought us back a warmer food, which was much better. overall food was ok, not great enough  to rate 5 stars.

The food was excellent. Highly recommend the drunken noodles and the garlic shrimp was superb! The wait time is around 30 minutes for party of four but we got lucky and got in 10 minutes. 
The seafood noodle soup was okay.  I would not get it again. 
Pang curry was alright but I would try the northern curries next time.

The food was no better than something one would cook at home.  I would say average.  The wait time was not great either given the quality of the food.  It felt like a fast food Thai cantine.  The bar only offered bottled options,  there were no cocktails or anything that would require effort to pepare.

This is a must stop for me whenever I am in Las Vegas.  The food is out of this world delicious.  The wine selection is fantastic as well. 

My favorite is the panang curry with shrimp served over white rice.  The pad Thai is the best I've had in the United States or Europe.  The coconut curry soup is also fantastic and a great way to start dinner.  We tried the Thai spaghetti this time around and it was very tasty and delicious.  

Aside from having won a ridiculous amount of awards,  the restaurant has also picked up a few James Beards which says a great deal about this place.  I will continue to come back to this place and recommend it to anyone that is in Vegas! :)

This is a very very good Thai restaurant even my husband who says he doesn't like Thai food  said the food was delicious I go to Vegas once a month and have been wanting to try this place for years and finally got everybody in the car and just took them without asking where you guys want to go it was really good everything we ordered and the wonton soup was delicious. The food critics were right for once this is a great place prices are decent and fair very good food the only complaint I have is it is in an ugly part of town in a weird mall with a giant parking lot in the middle. The neighborhood is bad the cops were driving through the parking lot when we arrived and also when we exited an hour later they just must tour it every hour on the hour so if the cops are always there maybe it's not that unsafe for tourists anyways

This is the best Thai food I've ever had. Highly highly recommend their soft shell crab drunken noodles and crispy duck panang. Came to Vegas for the weekend from California, and I'm so so grateful my boyfriend was adamant about trying this place.

Thoroughly enjoyed my meal here, in fact I was here twice in a 24 hour period. All the dishes were fantastic-and to think that Thai food couldn't get any better!Customer service can be a bit more accommodating but the food well makes up for it. The interior really didn't match with the exterior and that was a surprise (you'll know what I mean). My recommendations: Pad Thai, Garlic Fried Shrimp, and the Crispy duck in Panang curry! Everything was so incredibly flavorful and mouthwatering. Expect to spend at least $50 for a party of two! I'd prefer this over a typical Vegas buffet ANYDAY!

WOW WOW WOW All I can say is wow. I've had authentic Thai food before in Thailand but to be honest, this kicks it right of the the waters. If you read a lot of reviews you know about their Garlic Prawns. ORDER TWO PLATES! Especially if you are sharing with others because this will go out fast! Another favorite is the Peking Duck curry. More of Duck in curry sauce than curry but this dish gave me heart eyes. Skip out on the basic dishes such as pad see ew because you can get that anywhere. Also the walls of celebrities made me feel like this was a definite good choice.

We went on a Friday night around 8:30 PM local time. Yes, it was packed due to the rave and popularity of this place. They need to give a big thanks to Anthony Bourdain for it!! Any ways, we got there and with no reservations they told us at least an hour and half wait. You give them your phone number and they text you when you table is ready. We decided to go out and stop by the convenience store to pick up items we needed and with a surprise we got texted within about 30 minutes. I am giving this place a 5 because food was very good and I have been Bangkok before and food is comparable to it. Just as good or even better than some places in Thailand. Service was also wonderful, you don't expect much service at Asian restaurants but this was an exception. Probably first Asian restaurant I have been too where they had a host/hostess, bus boy, and waiter/waitress. I would love to come back again just to try other items.

Food - 5/5   Very delicious and comparable to Thai food in Thailand. We had the crispy duck with Panang. Duck was extra crispy and that curry sauce was to die for!!! Also, had the Drunken noodle with Sea Bass. This was exceptional as well but I thought kind of pricey. Didn't get as much of the fish I was expecting. I wanted to the try the Garlic shrimp that everybody raves about here but since we only had two people we didn't order it. Maybe next time.

Service - 5/5   Best service I had in an Asian restaurant.  

Tip - Make sure you make a reservation if you go on a weekend or else you will be waiting for a long time especially if you have more than two people.
Worth the hour wait. You will not be disappointed. Everything tasted phenomenal! The one tiny draw back is that it doesn't have a full bar.

his place is amazing! I was introduced to Lotus of Siam while viewing the Anthony Bourdain show "Parts Unknown." Coincidentally my wife and I were traveling to Las Vegas just a few weeks after viewing the episode. Anthony's recommendations are alway on point, so we decided to eat at the restaurant during our visit. We were not disappointed, the food is excellent! They have a extensive menu and wine list. My wife went with the tradition Thai meal, and ordered from the Northern Thai menu. Either way you can't go wrong. The servers work diligently and are extremely knowledgeable when it pertains to the entree recommendations based on the customer's preferences. The restaurant is modest in size, and possesses a really nice ambience. Make your reservations the day before you plan on dining, the don't do same day RSVPs.
season2

The Commercial Center Mall is not the most obvious choice for Las Vegas' best Thai restaurant, but you will find it here nontheless.

Jonathan Gold of Gourmet magazine called Lotus of Siam the "best Thai restaurant in North America."

I wouldn't go that far, but it is very good!

This Vegas Thai place can be tricky to find. It is off the strip hidden away in a strip mall and can't be seen from the street. But, finding this place is worth it. It has been called "The Best Thai Food in America". 

It isn't a fancy place, but the service is friendly and the food is great!  We had a vegetarian version of the crispy rice appetizer followed by a spicey fried whole fish. Wow! We picked that fish clean.  We will definitely be visiting Lotus of Siam again on our next Vegas trip.

This is the best Thai restaurant outside of Thailand! If you don't know Thai food, your server will ask your preferences - tastes and level of spiciness - and make great recommendations, including reasonably priced and perfectly suited wines. If you love Thai food, you will find all your favorite dishes and always something new to try. You cannot go wrong here. Dinner is the thing to do, as lunch is a typical buffet thing. It's east of the Strip on Sahara in a weird kind of industrial complex - drive it or cab it, don't walk - but once you're in the restaurant, you will be in another world, a world of exquisite taste and service. Truly a fine dining experience.

yum yum

thai iced coffee

fried tofu starter

and lots of the basics

try the lunch buffet

but be prepared to wait in a long line
season1

An oasis of real food amongst the buffet lines and crap overpriced food on the strip.  Everything we had was delicious, but the pounded young jackfruit was a standout.  Located in a dive strip mall off the strip, but worth the cab ride.  The Northern Larb is also great, much more flavorful than the generic larb in your average thai restaurant.
Awesome. Awesome. Awesome.  And I don't even like thai food.
Had some really interesting dishes that were pretty good, and I really regret that we didn't order more mango w/ sticky rice for dessert. Gosh that was good. More later.

I had the lunch buffet. It was decent. Nothing to rave about. I have a hard time imagining how it could rate as best Thai food in the US. Maybe ordering from the menu leads to better results. But I think Pin Kaow is better.

I was delirious from no sleep, no rest, work calling endlessly, tendonitis flaring up in my ankle and a wedgie from my thong.  Stupid underwear....why is my boss calling me again?  What time is our flight?  Fuck these shoes are cutting into my skin!!!!  I should have talked to that hot guy at the pool....too bad I looked like the Pillsbury Dough Boy.

After four days in Vegas I was plumb tired and exhausted from laughing and drinking and walking endlessly through the desert of Sin.  I was swimming in my disillusioned mind of crazy thoughts.  You know the feeling right?  The one where you are so loopy with exhaustion that you have no other emotions but "wha????".  You answer every question with that blank stupid grin of numbness.  

Then we came to Lotus.  The food was great and replenishing.  It was fresh and flavorful and it gave me the mental pick me up I needed to gamble once again the same $20 dollars I've been losing and winning at the penny slots all weekend.

Lotus was very good.  When you pull into the Commercial Center Mall, make a right and then it is almost immediately on your right.  You can't tell from the outside or decor (besides the dozens of photographs) that this place is so well loved.  I got the non-spicy vegetable soup, one companion got the spicy vegetable soup, and one got the spicy shrimp soup.  Mr. Shrimp Soup was gobbling up the soup, which he declared great, when he spit out a very spicy Thai pepper he had been chewing on.  It took half the meal for the burn to subside.  The spring roils were decent.  I got vegetarian chop suey which was yummy and the veggies are very fresh.  They don't serve fresh coconut juice.  The only real disappointing was the fried bananas, which were laden with an overpowering amount of coconut.
Right up there for best Thai food in America.  In stead of hitting up the latest NY-chef, 1-weekend-a-month restaurant casino restaurant, catch a cab and hit the strip mall.
season2

I was somewhere near Barstow on the edge of the desert when the spices began to take hold.  I remember saying something like "No matter how much sausage makeup and red onion perfume you put on this nam kao tod, Mr. iPod, it's still as tasty as a butch Rosie O'Donnell..."  And then suddenly there was a terrible roar all around, and the sky was full of what looked to be huge bats, small planets, or Rosie O'Donnell, all swooping and screeching at me like they were on a diet.  A voice was ironically screaming, "Oooh shush / keep it down down / voices carry."    

Then it was quiet again.  My iPod looked at me all illuminated and poured out frosty New Wave hits over my belly to facilitate the digestion process.  "What the hell are you yelling about?" it muttered, glancing at my doggie bag, wondering why it smelled like dog poo. "Never mind," I said.  "Everything's rosy.  It's your turn to pick a place to eat."  

And it was.  I was done picking Vegas restaurants.  Whatever bastard over at Gourmet named The Lotus of Siam "Best Thai Food in North America" must have gotten the Bangkok Special in the back because my food was as muddled as a clean-and-sober Courtney Love.  The only thing that made things worse was the lingering stench of krab meat.  (There is nothing in the world more helpless and irresponsible and depraved than a man in the depths of a krab binge.  Except, perhaps, being the drunken bastard that created this Drunken Noodle plate. Rubbery calamari, unripe papaya, and faux seafood aside, I'd name my child Shiloh Pitt before I'd take a Piloh Shitt at this place again.)

I went in with rocket-high expectations of the food here since it's reputed to be "the best Thai food in N.America."   While the food was really good, I don't know that it necessarily lived up to its reputation, at least the night we were there.

Per the friendly waiter's recommendations, we had their "signature" deep-fried sour sausage appetizer, which was a unique starter.  It looks like deep-fried rice, actually, when it comes out, but apparently yes folks, that IS sausage.    Very strong flavors of sourness (from the lime juice?), hot chilis (spiciness can be to your requested level) and lots of other complex flavors all put into a very tasty combination.   

We moved onto their spicy beef, drunken seafood noodles, spicy seafood salad, and tom kah kai soup.

Spicy beef = 5 stars.   GREAT flavors, down to the lime juice - infused bed of cabbage that the beef is sitting on.

Drunken seafood noodles = 4 stars.  Good, but not life-changing.  Nice combination of lots of seafood (imitation crab, squid, shrimp, and ooh even a mussel was thrown in there!)

Spicy shrimp salad = 3.5 stars.  You can request the spiciness to the level of your comfort, and we asked for "medium."   We found the dish to be flavorful, but a bit too salty and a bit too spicy for our tastes.  I felt overwhelmed by the dish after a couple bites and couldn't really eat much more.

Tom kha kai soup = 4.5 stars.  VERY well-balanced, complex, fresh flavors.

No room for dessert, though I was very tempted to get coconut ice cream just to put out the fire in my mouth and mellow out all the strong flavors I'd just ingested.

Definitely a good place to go if you like Thai food and/or strong / spicy flavors, but I don't know that it's the "best Thai food in N. America."

One of my must visit places in Vegas for Thai food.

My favorite dish:  Thai Beef Jerky.  Yum Yum Yum!  (5 Stars just for this!)  Most of the thai restaurants I've tried do not make it the way Lotus does.

+ 1 STAR for the selection of German Riesling (white wines).  Try their 3 glass tasting sampler!  Awesome!

---

UPDATE 10/01/07:  I came to Lotus for Lunch with Jim C. and my wife, as they are here for a work related conference and I was just here for the food!  I had the $8.99 lunch buffet and boy was this disappointing.  If I had never eaten anything a la carte from Lotus of Siam, I would NEVER have returned based on the food quality and taste of the items in the buffet.  The Thai Red Curry Chicken was too watery and had no flavor except for being spicy.  The Pad Thai was boring, too sweet and lacked limes and peanuts.  The only star in the buffet bunch was the Beef Noodle soup. 

Please don't judge Lotus of Siam based on their buffet.  Order from the MENU!!!

This place gives new meaning to the saying, "Don't judge a book by its cover."  Stuck in a rundown shopping center next a wig shop, I didn't know what to expect from what I've heard to be "The Best Thai Food in North America."  

My co-worker swears by this place and gave me a list of menu items to order: Chicken satay, steamed sea bass (not on the menu), shrimp garlic, and mango with sticky rice for dessert.  My boyfriend and I ordered some crab fried rice just in case the recommendations turned out to be "too Thai" haha.  Turns out we enjoyed the crab fried rice the most.  Everything else was good too but nothing I would rave about.

The staff were accomodating and sweet.  The atmosphere was homey and inviting.  The only thing stopping me from giving this review 4 stars is all the hype.  Then again, I'm not a Thai food aficionado.

Updated 2/23/07:
We went last week for the lunch buffet -- what a tremendous disappointment! Their website says the buffet is served until 2:30, but when we arrived at 1:45, we noticed a sign in the window (dated 2003!) saying lunch ends at 2. The buffet was totally picked over, they didn't restock any of the interesting items, half of the trays were full of either non-thai food (tempura? egg-drop soup?) or filler (shrimp chips, fried wonton skins). One curry, one stir fry, one thai soup... and all of it lukewarm. The only salad was iceberg and miso dressing. Nobody every asked us if we wanted drinks, we had to beg for water refills.
