Avoid the lunch buffet at all costs.

Original (four star) Review 11/06:
All the reviews below that call this place "the best Thai restaurant in the country" are, frankly, doing this place a disservice. It's a creditable Thai restaurant, and they certainly serve some of the best Thai food I've had since San Francisco's Thep Phanom took its nosedive into mediocrity. Every dish we tried was tasty and properly balanced, the service was attentive and welcoming, and the menu's impressive in its diversity. And, of course, there's an undeniable pleasure of finding such a gem amid the underbelly of Old Vegas seediness.

But unless you've spent your life eating ketchup-y pad thai, Lotus of Siam is not going to change the way you think about Thai food. But that's not the point, nor should it be. If you go expecting a palate-altering experience at a trek-worthy temple of gastronomy, you'll certainly come away disappointed. Go, instead, hungry for a well-made, casual dinner in an atmosphere that couldn't be less "Vegas" if it tried.

Very good and authentic tasting Thai restaurant.  I don't know if I'd call it the BEST Thai restaurant but it is certainly up there.  Try to call ahead and make reservations or you'd have to wait but it's worth it.  My next trip to Vegas will defiantly include a trip back to Lotus of Siam.

Went to Lotus of Siam because numerous magazine articles proclaimed it " the best Thai food in America". Well, maybe it's the best Thai barf in America. What a gross, greasy pile of crap was served to us. And not cheap despite it's location in some out of the way strip mall. Plus, good luck to get a cab to take you back to your hotel.

Red 8 at the Wynn is outstanding for Thai. Go there instead.

Wonderful wine list (lots of german whites, a perfect foil for spicy Thai cuisine), great service, pleasant atmosphere. Northern specialties available, as well as Ameri-Thai standbys. Not the best Thai restaurant in North America, but very good and a nice antidote to the overpriced, overwrought casino restaurants.

by far the BEST thai food i've ever had. it brings shame to any thai bbq and sanamluang locations. the food screams authenticity and different flavors associated with thai cooking - yes, there is more than lemon grass, coconut milk, and curry powder! there are levels of spiciness and the owner is a connoisseur of german white wines. he can match any dish with the right wine. how superb! just make sure you know what you are asking for when you ask for "spicy". dinner is the best deal. for lunch, there is a buffet, however, it rids of the entire atmosphere. (if you want a buffet in vegas, eat at the rio!) there are tons and tons of items to try- all the more reason to come back. i think we ordered about 7-8 dishes and paid a little over 100, including tax and tip. we were only a party of 3! now that is good dining!

the location and the setting isnt what you would expect of the restuarant. it's off the strip (which is a good and bad thing), located in a plaza. just dont judge a book by its cover. come hungry and talk to the owner if he's there. he's a really nice guy!
season1

Best Thai food around!!
i love their thai tea and their noodles...
great prices too!!

Growing up on Southeast Asian cusine, I was very excited to go to this place after all the rave reviews, and articles written about it (posted all over in their waiting room).
I have to confess that we came here a few times over the last couple years, which I am embarrassed to say...but in my defense, we have a Thai food lover in our midst and didn't know where else to go to satisfy her Thai food crave...
But after the last time I was there...I swore not to come back.
I have two comments about this place 1) OVER-RATED and 2) OVER PRICED. And of course it qualifies as the worst Thai restaurant I've ever been to. 
Don't know what's wrong with those white people writing rave reviews about this place in those magazines. They are either snobs who pretended to know what they're talking; or she probably fed them the magic mushroom during their reviews.
You don't need to like Thai food to know that it's not good.
Don't go there and save yourself some money to take your friends and family to an authentic place that doesn't rip you off because it can.

I am SO glad to see I'm not the only person who didn't have an orgasm going to this place.  I was starting to think there was something wrong with me.  

My client is a very well-known food critic, and knowing how much I love Thai food, he kept telling me that I needed to go to Lotus of Siam on my next Vegas trip.  "The absolute best Thai in America," he insisted.

So I trust him.  He knows his ethnic food.  And on my next trip to Vegas, I made a point of going to Lotus of Siam.  And not only was it not the best Thai food in America, it wasn't even the best Thai food in Las Vegas.  Everything I ordered was way below standard from what I've had in this country and in Thailand.  Granted, I'm vegan, so my food was sans fish sauce, but still, I've had damn good vegan Thai in New York, Chicago, LA, and Chiang Mai.  This stuff didn't even come close.  My dining partner went so far as to say his food was "disgusting." I wouldn't go that far, but I was really not impressed.  

We ordered appetizers, entrees, and we even ordered the famed  sticky rice with mango that several of the food critics glowed about in their articles that wallpaper the entrance (you have plenty of time to read them all while you wait for your table-- the place is packed).  Even that  wasn't good, and they didn't have to alter any of the ingredients for me to eat it.

When I came back to LA, I told my client about my experience.  He was shocked.  "You're the only person I've ever met who didn't have a life-changing experience there," he mused.  

I  don't know.  Maybe it was the chef's day off.   Maybe they hate vegans.  Maybe my taste buds were off.   But last time I was in Vegas, I went to the almost-empty Thai place across the shopping center from Lotus and had a much better meal.  I guess there's just no accounting for taste.

If you don't order the crispy rice salad, then don't bother eating here.  The relatively few poor reviews can probably be explained away by the simple fact that they missed the best things on the menu, and this one is the best of the best.

If you have eaten at one of the Thai Nakorns in Southern California, then you are spoiled like me. I guess I went to Lotus of Siam expecting something magnificent, to only be disappointed by a dinner of mediocrity. 

Having heard about Lotus of Siam and read the numerous glowing reviews on the internet, I had thought that we were going to be experiencing an orgasmic meal of mammoth proportions. Some of the reviews had proclaimed that Lotus of Siam was the best Thai restaurant on the West Coast. But I beg to differ. 

The food was mildly good. The restaurant itself was very bland, shoved away in a bleak strip mall in the dark corners of Las Vegas. Walking up to the restaurant, we had high expectations, but those were soured when we entered. The walls were overflowing with numerous accolades and yellowing newspaper clippings declaring the success and importance of the restaurant. OK so that was a good sign. Contrary to the restaurant's proclamation that there were no open seats, the supposed "packed" restaurant was dotted with a few parties and looked quite spare.

So we sat down in a booth towards the back of the restaurant, near the kitchen and ordered a few bottles of sake. After being provided with our small bottles of sake and menus, we began ordering. A lady came by our table, the owner I guess, and tried to push a fried fish on us stating that we would like it. In fact, most of the night the servers tried telling us what we would like and not like suspecting us to be "virgin" Thai food eaters. 

The food came out in a somewhat fast progression, coupled with more bottles of sake. By that time we were feeling a wee bit of the sake, but the food kept us in reality as it did not conjure orgasmic feelings. In fact the food itself was quite unsettling, with very little flavor. By that time the owner had tried pushing the fried fish on us four times, we still did not budge. 

Leaving Lotus of Siam, we realized how spoiled we had become. Thai Nakorn was still the champion and Lotus proved to be an unworthy opponent.

Lotus of Siam has a reputation as an excellent Thai restaurant.  It deserves its reputation.  A few brief observations:
* Reviewers warn against the buffet, which is standard Chinese.  From what I saw, I'll second that view.  Order interesting Thai food from the menu.  Be sure to ask for the Northern menu, which has many good choices as well.
* I had Nam Kao Tod (minced sour sausage mixed with green onion, fresh chili, ginger, peanut, and lots of crispy rice); charbroiled catfish; sticky rice with mango.  It was a lot of food, and everything was very good.
* The food tends to be very, very hot.  Fortunately, you get to specify how spicy you want things.  Your waiter will ask you how hot you want your food on a scale of 1-10, where 10 is the hottest.  I ordered level 3 to be safe, and it was still pretty hot.
* The address is on Sahara Avenue.  However, that's the BACK of the restaurant.  Don't run away in horror; instead, drive around to the other side.  It turns out to be a shopping mall, with the entrance to Lotus of Siam.  Once you get inside, you won't be much more impressed with the decor.  Don't worry - it's a good restaurant!

Nothing fancy about the restaurant but the food and the service was good. 
Actually, it was a little spicy for me. I wish I would have asked for mild. I was breaking a sweat and my mouth was burning, however very good and great ingredients.
The 89' Riesling that I had with my meal was excellent. (brought to the restaurant.) 
Would definitely go back for more!

Ok so I love Thai food. This place was also voted Best of Las Vegas a few times in the past few years. There are 2 things certain here. One. It's a popular place. Two. It's Thai food. Real Thai food. I like they have specials off the menu. I enjoy a lot of different things here from the Pad Thai, the red curry with numba 10 spicy. Their mint beef is pretty good too.  Mmmmm.....Their Thai Iced tea is not overly sweet. The staff is friendly and the cost is average. It's a very nice atmosphere. Overall, it's more of an "upscale style" thai restaurant. Don't eat during lunch at Buffet. You will be disappointed. Have dinner!
The only reason I go to Vegas. Let the cute elderly waitress/owner order for you and you can't go wrong. There is a spicy fried squid dish not on the menu that keeps me coming back for more

This is a skanky little place, no decor, bad area but this is where the locals eat, and it's open all sorts of late hours as I recall.  Some of the best Thai food you will ever have in your life. Nuff said!

This place has got more accolades and awards from reputable sources( Zagat, Gourmet, etc.),  than Mel Gibson has hate mail and I am happy to say that they are well deserved.

Although they have some safe and Chinese inspired dishes, which I think they should cut from the menu, their specialty is Northern Thai and the surrounding regions. Dishes can be small but that can be an excuse for your party to try more things. You won't regret it.

Don't confuse this place with some of those Thai places that try to be gourmet but stray too far from authenticity. This is real deal, gourmet Thai cuisine. Take it from me or not but I am Thai and have been to Thailand many times and I think I agree with the writer from Gourmet Magazine that this is "The best Thai food in North America". I 'll even go as far as saying it is better than most restaurants in Thailand.

The service id good, plating is nice and decor is pretty crappy but it doesn't really matter when the food is this good.

Price $20-30 per person for dinner. 

It's located in a dodgy strip-mall consisting of massage parlors and shady looking bars, restaurants and all the riff -raff they attract but I'll gladly dodge a few bullets to eat here again.

I give Lotus of Siam 5 stars based on the taste and quality of it's food. I usually reserve this for ultra elegant, flawless in all ways, destination restaurants. I will make the exception because this place is truly in a league of it's own because of how far the taste and quality exceeds that of any other Thai restaurant I have been to in the United States.

i really didn't know there was going to be so many haters on this review. but honestly this is the best thai food in the US. been here twice and both times were a mind-blowing experience. 

imagine 7 guys coming to lotus and sharing 5 dishes. funniest site imaginable. we tore apart our plates man. we shared the whole fried catfish, bbq pork, bbq beef, pad see yew, duck curry, and plenty and plenty of steamed rice. honestly i didnt know that such a lowly fish, such as catfish, can be cooked in a manner that really puts it up there with the more celebrated fishes (salmon, tuna, halibut, bass, snapper, etc.). the bbq pork was crispy yet moist. the pad see yew was pad see yew. we ordered it for a stomach filler. ahah. the duck curry with little grapes and pineapples were perfect. the thing that really blew my mind was the bbq beef. little slices of beef topped off with a lime fish sauce. o man. my tongue has never tasted those flavors before. it was like i landed on another planet. this is why i gave it five stars. this restaurant changed the way i perceive thai food in america. thank you lotus of siam. o and their mangoes were out of this world.
season2

Best Thai food in North America?? Although it was good, I can't say it was remarkably different than a lot of other Thai restaurants. My "Northern Thai curry" was actually too hot for me to eat comfortably (I had to order some plain rice to get the tofu down), although the menu really had no warning about that. My dining companion ordered his sea bass 7 out of 10 for hot. The waiter didn't ask me how hot I wanted my food, but it was clearly much spicier than the 7. I eat Thai food pretty regularly and haven't had this experience before. But that I kept eating anyway is a sign of how good it was. The people next to us got 6 pounds of deep fried lobster that looked pretty dramatic.

First off: There is no way in hell this is the best Thai food in the USA. Actually, I suspect, but don't know, that this is not the best Thai food in Vegas. I ate there a few times with my wife (we are both vegans). There were lots of vegetarian options, but it was very hit and miss. Some food was actually pretty good, and some very boring. Probably the worse was the "Thai salad": Note to staff, just putting peanut sauce on iceberg lettuce does not make it Thai.  

The staff were very friendly, but you really get a sense that you have to fit the rhythms of the restaurant. We went in at 9pm one night (kitchen closes at 9.30pm - at least during weekdays) and the last half of our meal was punctuated with the sounds of the vacuum cleaner (this also happened on another occasion when we in the last part of lunch). Really it is difficult to have a peaceful meal and enjoy your food when people are making a huge noise while you are trying to eat. Also the lighting is really harsh at night. Much calmer for lunch than dinner. Spicing is on a 1:10 scale and be aware that 10 is v. hot.

It is a big relief to be off the Strip though so we went back and the food was OK if not too great. It's about $12-$15 cab ride from the Strip.  Prices are reasonable.

Bottom line: nice place for a quiet lunch, but don't go with huge expectations.

I have to disagree with most reviews.  Lotus of Siam is a cult restaurant that definitely offers unique tastes but is not the best Thai in the country and may not even be the Thai in the Commercial Center.

By the way, although the Commercial Center is still an iffy place at night, a local business group has been trying to turn this around.

Some reviewers must be judging this by their uniqueness.  I can understand if someone is jaded, they will find this an adventure but quite frankly its not that great.  Their duck curry is too sweet and their spicy sausage dish is way too acidic.  It appears to have flecks of ham in it instead of sausage but only the taste not description matters.

I think that their abililty to pair wines with the food must account for some of their esteem by some food critics.  They do have a good selection and the husband of the chef is not bad at wine recommendations.  One of my friends in New York who was knocked on her heels by Michelin's star for Devi told me this is sometimes a factor.  

However, there are at least 2 Thai restaurants in Vegas that I am sure most would find superior to LOS:  Pin Kaow and Archi with Komol not far behind.  Komol is in the same seedy center as LOS.  

This review is not based on their buffet which is not as bad as most reviews but a definite step below their regular menu.  I have eaten there 3 times, exhortations from visitors driven and have always been underwhelmed.  

Yes, their flavorings are unique but is it good?  Is it as good as some of the other Thais in Las Vegas.  I'm sorry but no it is not.

I went here with a local who searches out off-the-strip experiences. Unlike many other reviewers, the strip mall milieu was unsurprising. Hey man, some of the best local eateries are tucked between a massage parlor and a wig shop. 

I'm not the biggest Thai food fan,  but I know what I like, and I LOVED this. Everything tasted incredible. We ordered the sum thom salad, which was generously vinegary, and a steaming bowl of tom khai coconut soup, level 7, which was a deeply revelatory experience to everyone at the table. Two of my party even declared pre-soup that they hate coconut-based concoctions, but after trying one spoonful they were ladling it out right fast. We found level 7 to be satisfyingly spicy without being bland. For an entree I ordered the pork panang curry, level 7. Delicious. Not the best in the world, and the pork was a little bland, but it was oddly comforting food. I would have preferred it a little spicier, but I suspect they think white ladies are lying when they ask for hot and spicy food. Girl I am not lying: I like my spicy! For drinks we ordered a flight of Riesling, which perfectly complemented the food. This is a must purchase for any spicy meal. 

Lotus of Siam you are delicious. You left me content and full-bellied. I will be back!

I've only been here once.  I came here for dinner and enjoyed the dishes we ordered.  I absolutely loved their crab fried rice.  I am a fiend for crab fried rice.  I love the crab fried rice at OSHA Thai cafe on Geary Blvd in S.F. and ever since then, I have been ordering crab fried rice in every Thai restaurant that has the dish on their menu.  I hadn't found one that came close to OSHA's until Lotus of Siam.  It's better than OSHA!  Wow!  I never thought I'd be saying that.  Anyway, also had their papaya salad which was good, but we made the mistake of asking for 6 on their scale of 1-10 for spiciness.  The waiter said 4 was what most people ordered.  Well, I thought. I could handle spicy more than most people... well, I was dead wrong.  It was damn spicy!  So if you go here and they ask you for the scale... order 4!  Otherwise it's way too spicy.  I don't know if it was able to take less spicy this time because of the heat in Vegas... not sure if that had something to do with it.  But it was damn spicy.  Their deep fried pompano fish was pretty tasty as well.  Their sticky rice with mango was also very tasty.  The mango was very good.  

So I give it 4 stars because of their decor.  They could do so much more with the place.  It was very plain and ordinary.  I guess I've become used to Thai restaurants having more of a Thai decor and having more of a warm feeling while dining in the restaurants.

So this place is known for having the best Thai food in the country, possibly.  Of course, with reviews like that, I tried not to expect TOO much when I first ate there, so I wouldn't be disappointed.  I mean, how could it be the best Thai food in the country?  The place is located in Commercial Center, the weirdest, sleaziest strip mall in Vegas, right by the Green Door sex club and the wig shop.  

But... the food is FABULOUS.  It might be the best Thai in Vegas.  In the country?  Who knows.  Try the Drunken Noodles- they are oh so good.  Be sure to make a reservation because you may not get in otherwise.  Service also excellent.

Some of my restaurant friends really love this place and would give it 5 stars. Though I do like this place and would recommend it, I still favor some of the Thai restaurants I've been to in San Francisco for a combination food and atmosphere.

With that being said, service here has always been good. The wine list is appropriate for the fare and the food in general is quite good. I had the lobster special once and was a little disappointed. Not that it wasn't good... but it just didn't stand out to me.

All of the currys here are very good. Try the roasted duck curry with pineapple if you're undecided.

The beef jerky, NUA DAD DEAW, is a little too dry but the try the satay as an appetizer.

You can't really go wrong here. It's just not romantic enough or divey enough to give me the rounded 5 star food and atmosphere rating.

The Lotus is a hidden gem that some locals introduced us to - really, really yummy Thai food. It's location is refreshingly non flashy, the staff very friendly and the fact that it was completely booked on a Monday evening should tell you something. 

With a group of around a dozen people we just scratched the $200 mark - and that included starters, entrees and a healthy amount of beer. Escape the casino madness, people!
The crispy rice salad with chinese sausage, mint and lime is by far the best thing I have ever tasted.  I always order 2 portions.  If you HAVE to go to Vegas, (God forbid) you should check it out.

This CANNOT be the best Thai food in America!  I have had far superior Thai food.  Not to say it's bad.  It's just... well, good.  That's what my three star review says.  If this was my neighborhood Thai restaurant, I wouldn't hesitate being a regular.  But I certainly wouldn't fly across the country to come eat here like I would... say, for Arun's in Chicago. 
After my first visit here a couple of months ago, I hesitated in writing a not-so stellar review.  I was puzzled at what the other people were tasting that I wasn't.  The other reason why I was reluctant to write one was 'coz I felt it would be an unfair write-up after only trying mostly their Northern Thai dishes.  Yes, we enjoyed the nam kao tod - minced sour sausage appetizer a lot but everything else paled in comparison to what I expected.  The northern larb was far inferior to the regular larb, and the much acclaimed kung ka noon which is a spicy young jack fruit curry was far from yummy - almost a dish that requires an acquired taste.  

I resisted from writing a two star review then... so today, we returned to order a bunch of food that weren't just what other moronic non-Thai- food-eating-'experts' claimed excellent, but ordered what we normally enjoy.  I feel that following food critics reviews on ethnic food may be a little tricky.  But having gone to Thailand a gazilion times since I was 3, went to cooking school there and grew up around the region, I know what Thai food (in the Bangkok area) should taste like.

Today we ordered the vegetarian egg rolls, tod mun plar (fish cakes), and yum woon seng (seafood glass noodle 'salad') for appetizers; crispy mussel omelette, chicken green curry and pad thai for entree.  Yes, two noodle dishes.  I love my noodles :)  My favorite dish at this meal was the mussel omelette.  It was close to what it should taste like and I enjoyed the nice crunch.  This dish is enjoyed both in Thailand and some other parts of South East Asia (though oysters are often used - minus the crispy part).  The green curry, I felt, lack flavor and spice even though we asked for very spicy (7 out of 10 for spice).  DO NOT order the pad thai here.  It is NOT what pad thai should taste nor look like.  We make much better pad thai at home lol!  

It was a good meal.  I walked out pretty contented with my Thai food craving.  Service was pleasant and friendly as was our first time dining here.   I just couldn't figure out what the lady was saying 80% of the time so I just agreed and smiled :D

This is an awesome place for Thai food in Vegas. Took my team for dinner after a long few days of work/conference and we all loved it. Go here for good food, great service and a relaxed setting. This is not your fancy joint with exquisite cutlery etc. This is a place for simply awesome food. We had their Beer, Sake, Chicken Satay, Panang Curry, Pad Thai, Soup and a couple of other dishes. The food was great. The waiter asked us how hot we wanted and it was perfect. The services was good too. If you are in Vegas, and looking for a Thai place - you must try this.

This place was on food TV so I thought I'd give it a try while we were out in Vegas. It's a real hole in the wall in a strip mall but it gets better once you're seated. The service is pretty fast and friendly. 

I would compare this place to President Thai in San Gabriel and Star of Siam in Long Beach in terms of flavor and service. It's really good, but I dunno if I would agree that it's the best in America, you know? I don't think the portions here are as big as they are in So Cal either, but it's nice to have such Thai food in an area of up-scale restaurants and buffets up the wazoo. It's a nice spot if you wanna change things up or wanna save some money for the tables by dining off the strip.

I think I give it an extra star because if it wasn't for food TV and Lotus of Siam, I never would have known there was a Leatherby's there! God I miss Leatherby's..

True to many previous reviews, this restaurant has the best Thai food I have ever had.  We ordered the crispy beef, roasted duck curry and drunken noodles, and all were excellent.  We are a sucker for authentic food and this was above and beyond - not only was it authentic, but very tasteful and highly "gourmet"

Well, I'm Thai born and raised with a family that runs resturants in the DC and Bangkok area and this is by far the best food outside of Thailand.  I can't say it's the best in the country because I haven't eaten everywhere but out of San Francisco, DC, LA and NYC, this is top 3 on my list.  They serve northern and eastern regional cuisine as well as your more usual pad thai, pad see eew (what my chinese friends call chowfun :-).   You'd be making a mistake if you only come here for the buffet.  Order something from the menu, try something from the regional list cuz this might be the only place you'll every come across it.

Warning:  You should order "down" in spiciness.  If you're use to eating medium at a 5 (with 10 being barely eatible by a Thai person), then you should get a 3.  A 5 here is NOT medium and you can always have them increase the spiciness if it's too mild but you can't go the other way.

What can I say? You either love this place, or you hate it. I fall solidly on the love end of the spectrum. I give it 5 stars on food quality, but the ambiance and atmosphere are most definitely lacking. Maybe it was the strip mall it's in. Maybe it was the crowded tables and disjointed service (four separate waiters? spilling water all over the place? 15 minutes for a thai iced tea?). Maybe it was our cab driver telling us that as recently as a few months ago, he would shoot up in the parking lot, as this was a well-known drug hang out, and he would not drive to this part of town after dark (that's a whole other story).

So if you're looking for some bomb ass thai food (and yes, it just might be the best in the country) and are willing to deal with some superficial shortcomings, this place is worth the trek from the strip.

meh.


at the behest of my girlfriend's stepfather, we ate there one wednesday night.  apparently this was one of the places we needed to visit according to his limitied radii's around the convention center.  he recommended the sour sausage rice.

i lived in southeast asia for years, i ate in bangkok, phuket, i got splattered with frog blood at a market in chiang mai.  on reading all the rave reviews (especially from Gourmet-which has never really let me down) i was ready for a little gastronomic pre cum to dribble down my leg..

not so, not even a squirt.

the sour sausage rice was good, sour, crispy, not much sausage.  too spicy for my girlfriend, and i was definately reminded of it the next morning on the elger..  but i'd never had that before, i was optimistically impressed-she was fading fast.

it took two tries for my singha, while waiting we checked out the clientele....hippies. sort of, not the VW bus, no jobber, dead head folks-the VPR, pious prius, art teacher beady, kaftan wearing types.  i began to see why this place was reviewed so positively and with so much frequency.

i resisted getting a traditional curry, and opted for the 'house special' or something.  big mistake.  it was coconut milk free, pretty tasteless,  and overall not good.  i could tell it was a totally traditional northern thai dish, but it was devoid of flavor, notably salt.

i was gonna make my feelings heard, but i was in my chef pants and rubber shoes and really didnt feel like being vocal at this point.

i just dropped my review down to a 2 star, much better could be done at home after a quick trip to the ranch99 market and about 10 minutes on the internet.



skip it.

thought i'd add that the duck curry special (not the regular one on the menu) is CUM INSPIRING. the duck is crispy and exploding with flavor.  best duck i've ever had (and i'm not even really into duck). the rest of the food was super good.

true story:

lotus of siam recommended by fellow yelper jim c.

curries ranging from level 1 to 10 in spiciness.

someone orders level 5, another orders level 10.

i can't handle spicy food, but i brave this one and try the level 5 with a big spoonful of rice. 2 seconds of chewing and my mouth is doused with gasoline and set on fire. 15 seconds later, i get an instant nose bleed.

thank god i didn't try the level 10.

i'm sure everything else tasted lovely, it's just that my incinerated taste buds failed to work after the curry.
season1

Ate here a few months ago, just forgot to write a review. 
This place is the real deal. Went with a group of my brother's friends.

Ethnically we were pretty diverse, the Indian group had an opportunity to order what ever they wanted off the main menu but in veterinarian so they weren't shafted with a 15 dollar plate with 2 bucks worth of food. 

The white guys had strong reactions to the food so that's a good sign the place didn't skimp on authentic taste just to win flavor.

This was a few months ago so i cant critique the food like i do in other reviews but i do remember this:

WINE DRINKERS BEWARE, They measure their wine in small glasses and then pour it into the wine glass. We sat near the back and from my position i watched wine drinkers get shafted countless times.

Can I just say...WOW?! This place is amazing!!! After reading the mostly awesome reviews of Lotus, I was eager to try it. I went with about 5 other girls for a bday dinner. We made reservations for dinner, so there was no waiting or anything like that.

Food: The food is delicious. While I do appreciate my go-to, hole-in-the-wall Thai place, "King and I", down the street, I think that the quality of Lotus' food is much higher. Some of the dishes we had (we had a lot, so I don't remember the names of all of them), but red curry with duck, panang curry with tofu and chicken, drunken noodles with sea bass, papaya salad, glass noodles with chicken, crispy rice, and a couple other dishes I can't remember. All of them were delicious. My personal faves were the drunken noodles and panang curry. We also had dessert...mango with sweet sticky rice, and fried bananas with ice cream....yummm! We also had two bottles of wine. It was a LOT of food, and we only ended up paying about $45 bucks each between 6 girls...a pretty good deal, considering how much we ordered, and we were stuffed at the end.

Service: The waiter was very attentive. Plenty of refills without asking. 

Decor: Nothing fancy, but it has a nice ambiance, moreso than your typical hole-in-the-wall.

Location: It's kind of in a sketchy part of neighborhood, Sahara Ave and  Commercial Ctr. There are some other restaurants around, like a Korean bbq restaurant. 

If you're looking for fantastic Thai food in the Vegas area, check this place out, you won't be disappointed. I'd come here more often if I didn't live on the opposite side of town!

Crazy good Thai food.  Just be advised that some of the dishes are spicy.  The Som Thum (green papaya salad) turned me into a red, sweaty, hiccuping, runny-nosed mess.  We also had the Khao Soi with beef and the green chicken curry, which were both great (and less spicy).  The neighborhood is a little dodgy, but the food is worth the trip.  Be sure to make reservations.

Definently worth a stop off the strip to get this very delicious Thai food.  I mean good food at reasonable prices, unheard of in Las Vegas nowadays.  We enjoyed everything that we ordered (Mussamun Chicken Curry, Pad Thai, Pad Prik Khing, and Panang Curry).  We also had a few of the appetizers (one of them has crispy rice in it and it had really great texture and was spicy and a little sour and salty all in one!)  I will be back next time I'm in Vegas!

Everyone who frequents restaurants has what I like to call a "benchmark" dish.  At an Italian spot it might be Pizza Margherita or Veal Parmigiana, For French food it might be Moules Frites or the Torchon of Foie Gras.  It's the dish that, if prepared properly, signals that the cuisine is up to par.  When trying to ascertain whether the full range of offerings is worth exploring it must first be determined that the kitchen can get the basics right.

My benchmark dish for any Thai restaurant is Tom Kha Kai, a magical combination of chicken, chicken broth, coconut cream, galanga, fish sauce, mushrooms, lime juice, and chili oil.  Ingredients may vary from spot to spot, as they often will, but the overall composition is pretty consistent.  The rub, as I have experienced it, is in getting the balance right.  Some places have too much coconut cream, others offer just a hint of chili oil (or omit it completely.)  I've had it with all kinds of mushrooms, and sometimes with huge chunks of galanga, and sometimes with none at all.  For one as obsessed as I, it grows a little tiresome.

I have had Tom Kha Kai at countless restaurants in the Southland, and am still looking for one that is as perfectly put together as what they serve at Lotus of Siam, the celebrated industrial park oddity way off the strip in Las Vegas.  Everything is in perfect balance and when I that first spoonful slides down my gullet I almost tear up a little.  Seriously.  It's just that feeling one encounters when something is SO right.. there's a magic to it.

The rest of the menu can be a little hit-or-miss, as others have noted.  But there is so much on the menu that is off-the-charts terrific that it hardly seems to merit de-starring.

So five stars for the crispy duck with spicy mint leaves.  Five stars for the Nam Kao Todd, crispy rice with minced sour sausage.  Five stars for the spicy beef salad.  So what if the Panag curry is a little lifeless?  There is certainly no shortage of items on this menu that make my head spin with delight.

And no, the decor is nothing to write home about.  I couldn't care less because the service is always so friendly and accommodating.  My blinders go on at Lotus and when I have an array of tasty treats in front of me I can't even SEE the decor.  Love really is blind, I guess.

And eleventy-billion stars for the wine list.  Jeez LOUISE the wine list.  Nothing, NOTHING goes better with spicy Thai cuisine than a cold bottle of Reisling and Lotus of Siam has scads of them.  Rare and highly rated selections at rock-bottom prices.  Donhoff.  J.J. Prum.  Zind-Humbrecht.  All the heavy hitters are represented, and there are plenty of Goldkapsels at near-release prices. Achtung! A perfect match for every dish can be found here along with a staff that can guide you through the polysyllabic minefield that one encounters with all things Germanic.

Stay away from the buffet.  Make a point of ordering some Northern dishes.  ABSOLUTELY order a bowl of the Tom Kha.  When visiting at night be sure to make a reservation and DEFINITELY arrange with your cab driver to pick you up after your meal because the parking lot gets a little bit sketchy after dark.  But for me, no trip to Vegas is complete without a visit to Lotus.  It's a can't-miss.

Get off the strip.
Get in a cab.
Go to Lotus of Siam.  Expect to have really bad customer service when you first arrive. They won't even acknowledge you until they are ready to see you as a customer. Once that happens.... the switch gets turned and you are their best friend.... the service is good, the food is great. Gourmet magazine said it was the best Thai in North America. That's a pretty high bar to set for a restaurant in one of the sleaziest neighborhoods in NV. The cab driver told us  how dangerous the area is... remincing about who was shot where... ah... the good times... 
Anyway...Seriously... Worth a trip to Las Vegas just for this place. Yum.

Granted, I've only been to two Thai restaurants in my life.  Compared to the other restaurant I went to, this is, in fact, not the best Thai food in the United States, nor even in Las Vegas.  Going by taste alone, I enjoyed my dinner, but having ordered the exact same thing elsewhere, it did not match up.  It should not matter what menu I order from, if something is served on the menu from a restaurant touted as the best in the United States, I shouldn't have to limit myself to a particular item or set of items to taste this quality.

The location, as others have mentioned, is absolutely horrible.  Off the strip on Sahara, it's hidden away in an area that makes me feel uncomfortable every time I go there.  The interior was nothing special and did not stand out to me...seemed quite unauthentic, way to strip-mallish, but alas I've never been to Thailand, I would not know what is truly authentic.  We happened to sit nearby a group who met with the owners, who both seemed nice but Bill was quite dressed down for whatever he was doing that evening (sweatshirt and sweatpants...not quite what I was expecting).  Like I've mentioned in other reviews, appearance and first impressions mean a lot when you eat out...much of the reason why many never come back.

To have to put so much into going here (reservations a week in advance or waiting a few hours if you come unannounced, I was expecting more.  The reviews here were for the most part spot on, but to each their own I suppose.  I came with high expectations and left wishing I'd never came.
I always make it a point to stop by here on my Vegas trips. Such awesome Thai food, although the service has usually sucked. Pineapple fried rice is awesomeness!

I came here with some high expectations, since this restaurant is claimed to be the best Thai food in the world! I'm not sure about that. I found that it was strange to have a restaurant so acclaimed at a really ghetto Asian plaza, mostly dominated by Korean businesses. I'm still very surprised that famous Food Network Chefs came to this restaurant and featured it. With all that publicity, you would think that they would move to a bigger place. I found it to be a bit crowded.

My friends and I decided to go here after class for their buffet. The price for it was 8.99. It's pretty good quality of Thai food. I wasn't blown away, but what do you expect of a buffet style restaurant? My favorite dish had to be the soup Tom Kha, the vegetarian coconut milk soup. Otherwise, there was nothing special about the other dishes. 

Maybe dinner would be a lot better. Next time I will try their whole catfish dish or any other dish that was featured by Gourmet magazine...

I don't claim to know if this is the best Thai restaurant in the U.S. (the kids these days seem to like Jitlada in Hollywood), but this was a notch above the best places I've been to in the Bay Area. Having failed to make a dinner reservation, we got there around 2pm on a Friday and hurried to place our orders before the kitchen closed. Nam kao tod (crispy rice with minced sausage) had very bright flavour. Chicken wings were fried immaculately. Khao soi noodles had an intense coconut milk sauce. Panang pompano and especially hoh mok catfish were the best Thai fish dishes I've had by some margin. I even thought our veggie friend Dave's pad thai was tasty, and I have no love for pad thai.

Next time we'll order it spicier: this time we asked for something like "spicy by American standards", apparently Bay Area spice standards are hotter than in most of the U.S. Otherwise, grand.

I found this restaurant on yelp, and when I read that this was 'the best Thai restaurant in the country" I had to stop by on my recent trip to Vegas.  My bf and I were pretty excited to check this place out and took a $15 cab ride to this whole in the wall for lunch.  Between the two of us, we had 

1) Koong Sarong (deep fried prawns wrapped in bacon and rice paper)

2) Nam Kao Tod (Minced sour sausage mixed with green onion, fresh chili, ginger, peanuts, crispy rice and lime juice)

3) Yellow Curry Chicken

4)  Pad Sw-Ew Chicken (Stir-fried flat rice noodle with egg and Chinese broccoli with black soy sauce).

Of the 4 dishes, my favorites were probably the yellow curry and the prawns.  As for the other two dishes, I kinda had high expectations for them because they're one of my favorite Thai dishes.  Unfortunately, my expectations weren't met.  The food here is good, just not good enough to be considered 'the best' based on what i've ordered.  Pad sw-ew is like a thai staple for me, just like pad thai for some other people, and it didn't surpass my standards  for this dish.  I'd have to say that King of Thai in San Francisco is still my favorite.

I have a cousin from San Francisco who comes out to Vegas JUST TO EAT HERE. Every time I tell him I'm off to Vegas, he tells me to go eat here, and I don't and this time, I listened. We went. We devoured. We were VERY satisfied.

The food is amazing. Best Thai ever.  I don't get it, the mixture of flavors is unbelievable. Slightly more expensive than we expected it to be - probably because I didn't take a look at the prices (oops).  Never the less, it was so worth it.  AWESOME dishes: Drunken chilean sea bass, some appetizer with rice crispies (kom kao tod or something), def get a combo of the coconut ice cream, sticky rice and mango for dessert, crab fried rice, and the garlic charbroiled beef. It's in a random strip mall and a little out of the way but the restaurant has a nice list of taxi companies for you to call when you're heading back to the LV strip.

I have been to Thailand several times and have eaten Thai food in 5 star restaurants as well as street cart in Bangkok so when I was told this was the best Thai in the US I was really looking forward to trying it.

I asked the server what the best dish was, I don't remember the name but it was a spicy noodle dish with beef,  and I asked for it to be very spicy.  I ordered a half bottle of an Alsace Riesling and my meal came promptly.

The food was very good and the service was outstanding.   

After wards I checked out the Green Door across the parking lot...not quite Patpong, a little less  sleazy....yep Patpong is worse :)

I remember visiting Lotus of Siam in my pre-Yelp days.  I read all the (Zagat) hype, heard all the praise, and, on more than one occasion, mentioned the reviews of it being the "Best Thai in North America."

All in all, it ended up being a huge letdown and I was embarrassed at bringing a large party of 8 to this restaurant and making reservations one month in advance.  

1) Location - Lotus of Siam is located in the middle of a strip mall and it isn't an easy location for most cabs to find.  The neighborhood is questionable and in the evenings is probably not the safest locale.

2) Decor - reflective of its strip mall location, the interior is nothing special.  There are, however, typical Thai touches (flowers and statues) and plenty of newspaper articles touting it's reputation as a great Thai restaurant.

3) Food - While many reviews talk about the amazing flavors and the incredible tastes, I found everything to be absolutely average.  Given the high expectations, I was obviously disappointed, but even without those expectations, I'd be hard pressed to even call the food good.  All the dishes chosen were "signature" dishes recommended by our waiter and each failed to impress.

With every bite I took, I just wondered how the heck the Gourmet magazine food review could be so off and what kool-aid all the reviewers were drinking.  Even now, I can think of a dozen Thai restaurants better than Lotus of Siam and probably only one or two that I've considered worse.  

In the end, as I waited 45 minutes for a cab to pick up our group from the seedy strip mall location, I figured it all must be a tourist trap.  One  stellar review must have spawned the rest or maybe, none of the people who were gushing over Lotus had ever been to a Thai restaurant.  

For the Las Vegas that is home  to the $4.99 Steak and Egg breakfast and the 24 hour buffet, Lotus of Siam may be a revolutionary restaurant.  But for North America??  Lotus of Siam falls amazingly flat.

In trips to Vegas, I've been fortunate enough to do the sixteen-course degustation at Joel Robuchon, dinners at places such as Picasso, Alex, Nobu, L'Atelier, Wing Lei, SW, etc.

Yet, the most delicious meal I've ever had in Vegas was at Lotus of Siam.

First thing to know: this is really three restaurants in one.

#1, there's a lunch buffet where rubes come in and pay $7.50 to eat potstickers and egg rolls.  Pretend this doesn't exist.

#2, there's a normal Thai menu with stuff like phad thai and panang curry.  While this stuff is good, it's not unlike what you might eat at a good Thai restaurant in Seattle or San Francisco or New York.

#3, there's a section of the menu with Northern Thai dishes and Chef's Special dishes.  This is the heart of the menu and what makes foodies cry with delight.  If you're coming all the way here (and it's a long walk from the middle of the strip), you must order off of these sections of the menu.

We've been here several times.  Most recently, we had the dry sausage, a green curry dip, and finally the special Beef Stew with peppercorn sauce (option A I think.)

While all of these are highly recommended, the beef stew was one of the most delicious things I've ever had.  The meat was absolutely fork tender, flavored with aromatic and perfectly balanced Thai spices--the right mix of sweet and spicy and pungent.  Just amazing.  Totally beyond the flavors and textures you expect.

They grow a lot of their own herbs and spices because they're not available outside of Thailand.  As a result, you'll taste flavors and combinations you've probably not had before.

Again, order off of the Northern Thai or Chef's menus.  And prepare to be amazed.

Is that Thai sausage in your pocket, or are you just happy to see me? Oh! I'm so hoping it's Thai sausage. 

For my older brothers 45th birthday we came here with 15 friends who all met up at the Venetian. We had a couple of drinks at the hotel and made our way here. Happy and feeling dandy. And then it began.... course after course after course of some of the best Thai food I have ever savored.

We had several different salads. The banana blossom one was, are there words? No. I don't think there are. There wasn't a bad one in the bunch. Some were requested hot. And we got Thai hot. Which is blow  the top of your head off good.

We moved on to several soups which were amazing as well. I especially liked the shrimp with bok choy? I think it was bok choy. We drank enough wine to make me forget too much. (Damn you Mona! Take notes - but would I have been able to read them later?) Then came more.

Noodles. Beef, chicken, seafood, rice, curry and it just kept coming. It was a feast. And not a loser in the lot. 

By the time a fried banana desert came around, I was hailing a cab and hauling my butt back to the hotel. Enough. 

I plan on taking a large group of our clients here on our next Las Vegas outing. There's this one guy... who hates hot and spicy. I intend to kill him through food. Really, he has it coming. Meow.

Its not far from the strip, and its location (in a seedy strip mall!)  is confusing, given that it is considered one of the best Thai restaurants in the US. Make sure to make a reservation well in advance, as I tried to do a walk in, and was told I would have to wait an hour, and as I glanced at their appointment book, I notied that they had many many reservations for up to a week in advance. Note that they do not take reservations for lunch. 

There were tons and tons of non-Asians here, (more non-Asian than Asian), so you can be sure that if you bring non-Asian friends here that chances are they will love the food as much as you do and that the food is appealing to them as well 

due to scheduling conflicts, I wasn't able to dine here for dinner, but lunch, which offers the option between ordering from the menu and the buffet. My party was starved so we opted for the buffet. It was great - they had pad thai, friend rice, two different soups, egg rolls, fried banana, fruit, salad, some other thing sI don't quite remember - it was a pretty small buffet though. I really enjoyed it. My In laws enjoyed it immensely as well. Next time I'm in Vegas, I'm definetely visiting them for dinner!

Lotus of Siam has gotten rave reviews, but some don't understand the hype.  I made reservations on Friday for Tuesday, 5:30 pm (June 24th) for two people. When we arrived the place was just opening and it immediately filled with with a few patrons but was by no means crowded.  

The decor is absolutely fine- I thought it would be seedy after reading some of the descriptions, but I found nothing to complain about. It was clean, the chandeliers were sparkly, the carpet didn't look disgusting or anything. The place is small and intimate, yet not crowded-feeling. It wasn't even noisy.

Our server gave us plenty of time to peruse the menu. We both tried the Tom Ka Khai, which was a delicious coconut cream soup with chicken and lovely flavors. We judged it a bit tart and salty.  My friend thought it was more tart and salty than usual, but it was my first time having it. We both enjoyed it.

For dinner I had the mussaman and thoroughly enjoyed it. She had a seafood dish that she also loved (I liked it but not as much as she did).  My meal cost about $10 while hers was twice as much.  For dessert we shared  mango and sticky rice, which we both loved. That mango was absolutely heavenly and the rice was not overly sweet.

Service was nice even though we waited a long time for someone to show up after they presented us with the menu.  We lingered for about 10 minutes chatting after dessert, which prompted a woman to come out twice to clear our table. She was all smiles, though, and we left because the place is pretty tiny and we didn't want to cause people to wait. There were perhaps two parties in the waiting room when we left, but there were at least two free tables (besides ours).

I'd come back again, but I'm not sure it's the "best Thai restaurant in the country."  I took photos of our meals, which I added to the others for this restaurant. They are cell-phone quality but I tried to make them look decent.  Our plates really did look lovely when served.

Lotus of Siam recommends folks make reservations for dinner, and I couldn't agree more. The place gets a healthy crowd, so reserve as soon as you decide to go. Dress is casual, though I saw a table of women ready to go clubbing all glammed up.

Their unassuming interior won't "wow" you (but you may notice the strong smell of Thai spices permeating the dining room). While you may not be shocked by the decor, the food WILL grab your attention. All of our appetizers and entrees were tasty and of a consistent quality. If we requested our dishes to be spicy, they came out spicy.

Shared many dishes (which explains why I don't have much detail for some of them) and dined family style:
- koong sarong (prawn in a blanket; $11) - wish we had more!
- moo dad deaw (deep fried marinated pork jerky; $8) - yum
- mussels - spicy and scrumptious
- salad with ginger, ground beef ($8) - I think it was the tod mun plar
- sour soup (served in its own cooker) (probably more than $10)
- calamari salad (not bad!)
- green curry (tasty, not overtly spicy)
- something that looked like an omelette
- a noodle dish that was drunken noodle-esque

Lotus of Siam was recommended by many folks, local and otherwise. They aren't the best Thai restaurant in the US, as claimed, but it sure comes close. If you can live with average service (our first waitress seemed a little curt, but the rest were fine) and focus on their outstanding food, you'll find yourself a winner!

My 2nd favorite restaurant in Las Vegas after "Himalayan Cuisine". The lunch buffet is ok but dinner here is superb. I like smaller friendlier atmospheres and a relaxed ambiance with fantastic food at reasonable prices without the pretense thats usually displayed at a lot of sub par casino restaurants. I really like the house special flat noodles with crawfish. Their wine list is fantastic and much more reasonably priced than other places that boast great wine lists. Alas, the beer is limited to the standard weak Asian lagers and domestics, but if its fantastic beers I want I just go to the Himalayan Cuisine instead. The sommelier here is a very affable man and after chatting him up I was able to twist his arm and offer him a little taster of the Bergstrom Pinot Noir I had one night. All in all, fantastic Thai food that deserves its well-reviewed reputation, great wine list, friendly wait-staff that doesn't stand on ceremony, bland beer selection and decent but not necessarily fantastic lunch buffet.

Not a particularly magical place as it's got bad 80's diner decor. As the food goes, it's pretty good...but overrated. The ricekrispy-sausage bit thing for an appetizer, a northern thai dish with jackfruit and dried sliced fish, and then the sea-bass, steamed with red chili. A lime juice and a singha beer. Sea-bass was the best dish, somewhat pricey at $23, but served on a bed of wilted cabbage, which was kind of disappointing as it said "vegetables". The driced sliced fish was at the recommendation of the waiter, but it's flavor overwhelmed.  Free rice, which is cool. I'd come again and try some other things, as the menu is extensive.

Put the buffet plate down... step away from the counter and move off the strip for a bit.  OK so it's not that far off the strip and yes if you drive down Sahara you'll see the restaurant front and you may just pass by and say forget it.  That was my SO's reaction as we drove by, but trust me stop find parking in this run down strip mall, brave the characters outside, look straight ahead and go in the restaurant.  

We ordered two dishes, I just wished we were with a bigger party so that we could have tried more dishes.  I ordered the braised short ribs... love me tender, tender meat!!!  And the SO ordered the pork stew northern curry.  Both were lovely the Pork stew had a good bite, a bit spicier that I would like but I still enjoyed it.  It was a bit odd that the waiter didn't ask how hot we wanted it but to me that's sometimes a good sing of a great restaurant.  I like it we a chef prepares a dish how it should be enjoyed no matter who's taste bud is eating it.  The best part of the pork stew dish was that the pork pieces had just a bit of fat yup pork fat in it.  I know it's bad for you and also know that a lot of people hate the texture/taste of it, but what can I say, I'm filipino and we just love that stuff.  
We also ordered the sticky rice and mango... big mistake as this push us over the top and almost exploded as I made my way out of the restaurant.  I don't know if it was just the fact that I was too full but the desert did not really impress me too much.  Pretty standard sticky rice/mango one can find in other good Thai place.
I would give this place 5 stars if not for the location.  Great food nice space inside very reasonable prices.  A must when you want really good food and not willing to pay the price associated with a "celebrity chef's" name plastered on a restaurant.  So pass the buffet line and go straight to LOS.

Sawasdee Krup,
I HEART Lotus of Siam and you should too! Please don't write me a long and nasty e-mail if you don't and you got turned away at the door because you didn't make a reservation....dummy!  The place is popular and for good reason. The restaurant sits in this seedy location way off the strip. Don't let the run-down strip mall scare you away. It surely didn't scare off the likes of Oprah and President Clinton....THANK YOU VERY MUCH. It does seem odd that a restaurant with such fanfare is in this  hidden corner of 
Vegas, but I think thats part of the attraction. 

The food is truly gourment and the service is quick, not the warmest, but with food this good I'd suffer through an open-hand slap to the face for some more Tom Kah soup. Fresh & Spicy, like Padma on Top Chef!

NOTE: Take the time and call ahead for a reservation. I saw a lot of sad faces waiting in the lobby as we strolled in the door and right to our table D-list celebrity style.....Oh Yeah!

Since there are already 90 reviews of this place let me keep this brief.  I generally don't like Thai food.  But I was in Vegas on business and by myself and wanted to stay off the Strip.  The YELP raves convinced me to give Lotus a try.

Bottom line -- its amazing.  Go.  Even if you hate Thai food, go.  The flavors are remarkable.   I had a soup, an appetizer, and a main dish and they were all spectacular.  And if you're into wine, the list looked amazing.

And BTW, their web site recommends reserving a day in advance, which I thought was a joke for an ethnic restaurant in a strip mall, but the place was thronged on Wednesday night.  I was lucky to be seated in 20 minutes.  You might want to call ahead.

The entrance to this hole-in-the-wall restaurant is lined with reviews, review after review from food critics I've actually heard of, crowning it the Best Thai Food in Las Vegas, in the West, in the Country, in the World, in the Universe.  We had dinner and I was a bit disappointed, though it was okay.

Then I went back and had the lunch buffet, which was universally panned and despised by Yelpers.  I actually thought it was really good and by far the best meal for under $10 that I had in Vegas.

Behold the Awesome Power of Raised/Lowered Expectations!

Dinner: The nam-kao-tod (crispy rice) was a very interesting blend of flavors and I'd have it again.  The kang-ka-noon (spicy young jack fruit curry) was unremarkable, and the catfish was just okay.  Service was up and down; the wait staff were friendly when they were there, but sometimes they seemed to forget about us.

Lunch Buffet: The banana rolls were delicious and were really what won me over.  The garlic pepper chicken and the curry puffs were also good.  Staples such as pad thai were also present.

This is a solid Thai place. The service is OK but the menu and the food easily make up for it. Lotus of Siam has the biggest Thai menu i have ever seen and great descriptions of each dish for those who aren't Thai experts. Overall I really enjoyed the food (Panang Curry and Hot and Sour Veggie Soup) and recommend for anyone looking for great Thai

This rating is actually a 3 1/2 stars but only because we only had the lunch buffet.  From most of the reviews it sounds like the menu is the way to go.  Don't get me wrong, the buffet was fine.  It had a decent mix of things, but because of the chow mien, fried rice and egg rolls, and a few other dishes, it felt like any of the other good chinese buffets I've been to.  There was a curry dish or two that I have never tried before but I think I missed out not ordering off of the menu.  

If the popularity of this place is doubted, just show up at 11:20 to see the people waiting out front for it to open.  It's located in a weird strip mall location.  You can't tell from the road that it is actually more of a business complex than a strip mall.  There is a huge parking lot area surrounded on three sides by buildings.

As for price, it about $19 for two without drinks.

Tonight we were trying to find someplace new, thai food in particular,  and stumbled across the many reviews. Curious, we decided to give it a try.

First of, you wouldn't expect to find a great place for food in the run-down "mini-mall" that it is located in. One advice, go there during "lit hours" if you are by yourself.  Luckily, it's still light out after 7pm.  

We walked in at 7pm on a Thursday night without reservations and the place was pretty full.  At first the guy told us it would be at least a 30 minute wait but then said that he could seat us if we didn't take more than 1 hour. Since it was just the 2 of us, we said of course! I would recommend reservation esp if you have a big party.  It looks like they had a separate section for a bigger party (maybe 20+) but the biggest table I saw sat 12 people comfortably.  

The food was excellent!  We skipped the appetizer and went straight for the meal. We had the green papaya salad, drunken seafood noodles, and red curry with chicken.  We asked for everything mild and It was "just right, a little sweat and tears" spicy.  It came with a side of jasmine rice but we had 1 order of sticky rice esp for the curry! Yum!  The portions weren't huge but between the both of us, we ate pretty much everything.  Now, we could've been done without desert but the table next to us ordered a whole bunch and we couldn't resist!  So, we had shared 2 of them: fresh sliced mango with sticky rice topped with a light cream sauce AND coconut ice cream. Oooooh, so yummy!  Yes, we finished that without a problem.

The service was good.  We had a bunch of people helping us and our water glass was never empty.  Thank goodness with all the spicy-ness!  The one thing I thought was strange was that after we got our food, no one came by to ask us how things were until we were almost done eating everything. Then again, maybe that's probably why huh? They probably didn't want to interrupt the "shoveling" of food! Ha! 

We will definitely go again.  I'm curious about their lunch buffet that was being advertised as $8.95.  Our meal described above (including desert) was all under $50!  Thanks for all of your reviews. We just found a new great place for Thai!!!!

We were able to get reservations for 7:30 on Saturday only a week or two before. The koi soy (beef tartare) was excellent, as was the the mashed jackfruit dish (very surprising!) and papaya salad (which is very spicy but quite authentic. The khao soi was all right but not amazing. The whole fried catfish with basil was great, and the northern larb was pretty good but again not exceptional. The wine list is truly something, and there are plenty of other drinks as well. Service is very good and friendly and the prices are not bad, especially for vegas.

When a place advertises itself as "The Best _____________ restaurant in the US" I was understandably skeptical.  But my skepticism evaporated with the first bites of the NAM KAO TOD   (Minced sour sausage mixed with green onion, fresh chili, ginger, peanuts, crispy rice and lime juice.)  The flavours, and textures, of this appetizer and everything else I tried (the "chicken wings" are unlike anything you've had anywhere: deep fried until crispy then sauteed with chili, garlic, and topped with crispy mint leaves.)  Try the Sea Bass as well.

Who cares about decor, strip mall location, etc?  You are here to eat!

Wow, people are really hard on this restaurant as if they were authentic thai chefs themselves...just kidding! I've recently become a really big fan of thai food, although I've been a HUGE fan of pad thai for quite some years now.

After seeing that the Lotus of Siam was on the food network, I knew I had to give it a try. I've been there about 4 or 5 times now and have been satisfied every time.  I mean, it wasn't THE best thai I've had, but I can see why everyone's raving about it.  Next time, try to be a little brave and order a little something from each category and try it out...you won't be sorry.

I started talking to the waitress and she said that the reason why the food was so fresh is that they make a trip to LA TWICE a week to get fresh ingredients for their dishes. TWICE A WEEK! If that's not passion, I don't know what is.

"Have you been to Lotus of Siam yet?" is a frequent question I got after moving to Las Vegas over a year ago.  And finally, the answer is yes.

Showing up there on a Sunday night around 6:45 pm without reservations is a daring move, especially with a party of four.  Sure, my wait was about 30-45 minutes, but trust me, I tried to make reservations.  I was calling all evening before they opened and got a busy signal!

When we finally got seated right smack in the middle, I had plenty of time to read a few reviews, check out their many newspaper/magazine features, and observe my fellow diners.

It took awhile before the waiter took our order, meanwhile I was in search of a wine list.  (I had read about their incredible beverage menu, but was disappointed when none was given to me.)  When I did ask for wine menu, it's more like a wine book!  I think they should have automatically offered us the beverage menu.

Our menu:   

* Stuffed Chicken Wings $8.95 (Chicken wings stuffed with ground pork, deep fried, and served with sweet and sour sauce.)  This came with two chicken wings that were sliced for sharing.  Tasty and full of flavor, a bit disappointing though with the small portion.

* Mee Krob $7.95 (Crispy noodle mixed with sweet and sour sauce, chicken and shrimp.)  I wasn't sure what to expect with this dish, but what a nice surprise.  The crispy noodles had a nice freshness to it and very good.  Would definitely order it again!

* Tom Klong Pla-Krob, Hot Pot $15.95 (This unique soup was influenced by mixed Thai-Cambodian culture which combined pieces of "smoked sheet fish" with the Thai-Cambodian style soup, seasoned with tamarind sauce, fresh herb, spices, chili.)  This soup comes out beautifully presented and has a huge wow factor.  There's so much spice and flavor in this soup and has your mouth humming from all the heat.

* Pork Panang $9.95 (The color and flavor of fresh & dried chili makes this curry a unique dish.  Cooked with coconut milk, Thai basil and chili.)  I was craving some kind of Thai curry with a coconut milk base and the pork was surprisingly tender.  The sauce went fabulous with my rice.

* Sai Oua (Northern Style Sausage) $8.95 (If you like Louisiana style hot sausage, you have got to try this one.  Stuffed with ground pork, fresh and dried her and spice, this mild/medium spicy sausage is indeed very tasty.)  A bit dry and disappointing for us all. It lacked the spice and flavor we had hoped for.

* Crispy Duck with Chu-Chee $19.95 (Topped with Thai red curry base sauce.)  The three guys I was dining with absolutely LOVED this dish and were practically fighting over it!  It tasted so good for them that they ordered another one!  There's a chunky portion of duck fat sitting under the skin, which is what I think makes it taste so good. The curry sauce is fabulous complement to this dish.
 
* Crispy Mussel Omelet $8.95 (Fried Thai mussel omelet to crispy on top of sauteed bean spout and green onion and served with spicy sweet sauce.)  It's more like a deep-fried dish, which surprised us all.      It has a weird texture because of the dryness of the deep-frying and the mushiness of the mussels and egg base.

* Crispy Duck with Chili Mint Leaves $19.95 (Topped with homemade fresh chili and Thai basil.)  The duck was good again, but the guys preferred the Chu-Chee sauce instead.  I liked the Thai basil myself.  

Entrees come with steamed rice, but you can get sticky rice for $1.50/pp.  

Service - Our water glasses were never refilled and the woman clearing our dishes made it very clear to us that she wanted us to leave.  She not only said it under her breath, but again later on while I was using the restroom.  We weren't done with our beverages yet and I felt rushed to leave.  However, the waiters were nicer, asking us if we wanted dessert before giving us our bill.  (We were stuffed with a few leftovers not worth taking.)

Overall, Lotus of Siam has a VERY extensive menu.  There's such a huge variety that it'll make you want to come back so you can try other things.  The waiter never asked us about our spice level, and we told him about a 6-7.  The only thing spicy was the soup, everything else fell short on spiciness.  Definitely go with a bigger group so you can order more dishes.  With so many accolades, they could do a lot better on service.  It gives you a casual feel with the paper napkins and buffet set up in the middle.  For the most part, the food is very good and tasty.  You'll probably find us back here so we can check out their other stuff.  I'll definitely make reservations though!

(You can check out photos of our dinner in the business profile section!)

i have been coming here for the last 8 years or so.  i first heard of LOS in a gourmet magazine article and had to try what the craze among all the food critics was all about.  from the first time i ate there till the um-teenth time, it never disappoints.

i always stop by for lunch when i'm in las vegas.  i've enjoyed almost everything i've tried here...don't forget to try some of the northern thai items...the northern style larb and pork stew is especially good.  then finish the meal off with coconut ice cream and the coconut sticky rice with fresh mangos.

N.B. if you go for lunch, do not get the buffet.  you've been warned ;-)

if you want to find a good, cheap meal in vegas, skip all the crappy and crowded buffets with enormous lines and head on over to lotus of siam. in fact, if you want just a downright awesome meal irregardless of price, go to lotus of siam. this place beats any of the michelin-stared restaurants on the strip. why? because it's damn good and damn authentic. and you can get away from the cluttered strip for a second which is always a welcome change of pace.

our experience here was nothing but spectacular. our waitress knew just want to recommend. the wine list is good and when i asked her to recommend a good reisling, she picked just the right one for me. not too sweet, not too dry. just perfect. then when it came time to order, we told her what we wanted and she offered up modifications based on the various sauces of the entrees we ordered. she wanted to ensure we didn't get the same sauces and that we picked the best meat/fish with the dish. thusly we ended up with a very comprehensive meal.

roasted duck curry
drunken noodles with chicken
charbroiled prawns
pad sw ew with seabass
poached salmon with chiles

my favorite of the lot was the roasted duck curry but all were amazing. i have boasted that my favorite thai food ever is thai tom in seattle (check out the reviews of that place if you care to understand the comparison), but this place MAY have surpassed thai toms. it's neck and neck for sure. 

i cannot rave enough about this place and i highly suggest that anyone going to vegas goes to lotus of siam. it's a quick cab ride from the strip and you won't be disappointed. just make sure you are a bit adventurous and don't order the pineapple fried rice or pad thai. you'll be missing out on the good stuff!

perhaps i had high high expectations. It's hard not to when Jonathon Gold and all these other food critics are wetting their pants over this place.

Went there and we weren't quite sure of what to order so we got one staple to compare with other thai places (Pad See Euw) and a curry dish and a crispy rice appetizer. I regret not getting the more exotic dishes, cuz I think maybe that's why people come here but anyway,

all in all, it was mighty tasty and for three people, the bill came out to $37.

if i lived in vegas, this would be my go-to Thai place. Would i drive all they way there for this? hell no but it would definitely be a stop when I'm there and have a car.

see my pics
season2

10 bucks for a horrible buffet in a grimy strip mall.  The irony is that the owner (according to articles on the wall) is responsible for Renu Korn in Norwalk, Ca, the best Thai place I've ever been to...

A 3.5stars! We followed Yelp's review and stopped by around 3pm to have late lunch. you could tell it's a popular place by the crowd of people there even it was late afternoon. We had Papaya Salad and Garlic Prawn following the recommendations from their staff. The prawn were so crispy and fresh, you will love to lick the plate up!!! as I did...LOL. We ordered our papaya salad at  medium spicy but it was too much for us and they just replaced our plate with a new one(no spicy at all one). That was so sweet!! The only thing we would like them to improve might be their price. I have eaten in Pasadena's Saladang and Saladang served nice food with great atmosphere and reasonable price. Lotus doesn't have nice interior decoration but charged more than Saladang. It would be the only reason keeping me from visiting this place again.  Otherwise everything works so well here. If you have family or a big party who don't care the atmosphere that much, this place is a good choice.

Before going to Las Vegas, i've followed some review on Yelp and it helped. My family and I are original Thai, we were expected to eat real Thai foods, and this restaurant was so awesome, Wines are great as well.

Came here for the lunch buffet, and was very pleased. The buffet offered a choice of about 12 items and the place was very busy, ensuring fresh food for all. I recall a couple of curries, two or three noodle dishes and several entrees along with soup, spring rolls. As it was buffet, I didn't expect much service other than keeping my water glass full, and they managed that. 

An excellent choice for a fast, inexpensive and delicious lunch.

Close, but no 5 stars. But really it was!

Last weekend I was in Vegas and our second (and last) night there, we wanted to eat out for dinner again. Again I eyed the local restaurants on yelp and this actually was my second choice. We actually tried to go to this Italian place, but the area was just creeeepy. FAIL. Lol so we let the GPS take us to Lotus of Siam.

I didn't know what to expect because I've been to many Thai places and I only really like a couple. I'm really picky about little aspects of food, but I wanted to be open-minded, especially because my stomach was empty =(. So the wait was 10 minutes, which went by pretty quick! My parents were surprised to find the place PACKED, but we snagged a table at the right time.

We were seated in the mini dining rooms on the side and it was pretty cozy. But more importantly, I wanted some real good food. We ordered:

Pad Thai - Not the best I've tasted, and personally was a little small and a little dry. But pretty good.

Spicy Fried Rice - What the hell?! No one asked how spicy we wanted it?! This shit burned our stomachs and my thai iced tea was goooone. I love spicy food but they were literally trying to start a fire in my throat. Tasty nonetheless!

Chili Mussels - Pretty good, but I'm not too big on mussels. My dad liked it though.

Musaman Curry - The tastiest curry ever. We got it with tofu and it was really good. I was bummed the bowl was so small.

Service was pretty good too, so that of course is a plus. But because I'm real picky about my food (well at least when I went there), it didn't get the 5 stars I was really hoping to give. Great place though, and from the looks of it this place is loved by many. If I'm in Vegas again, I'll definitely come by again. And I'll be prepared for the fried rice!

Considering that Gourmet magazine said it was the best Thai restaurant in North America, AND that Frommers highly recommended it, I expected a lot more. My boyfriend and I both had the wonton soup (excellent) and the chicken with cashew nuts. Personally, I've had much better at other Thai restaurants. 

It's a run-down little place, but obviously plenty of people know about it. Autographed pictures with celebrities adorn the walls. Service is okay, but nothing exceptional. It was often hard to track down our server.

I always hear people namedrop Lotus of Siam when talking about Vegas Thai food. For me, I love Komol in the same business plaza, Commercial Center. I finally decided to check it out. We unwittingly showed up like 15 minutes early. We waited in the car and there was a line forming outside the restaurant. I thought, Holy crap, maybe this is the Holy Grail of Thai food. In Vegas. 

They had a buffet going on for lunch, but I wanted my first LOS experience to be a pure one. I copped a look at the buffet and it didn't look that great anyway. It looked kinda Chinese. 

The menu was large and had clear descriptions (in FOBese) of the items. And although you can make a lot of Thai meat dishes vegetarian, they did not have a section of the menu specifically for vegetarians. Like Komol. 

To start, we ordered the famous tom kah kai soup. It was really good, but really fattening, I think all it is is coconut milk, chili oil, and maybe chicken broth with bland chunks of chicken, straw mushroom, and cilantro (?). But I could sit there and drink the broth all day. You can get a cup, bowl, or hot pot. I think my cup was $4. 

We tried the panang just because I needed to compare and contrast to neighboring Komol's killer panang. I always get the tofu panang because I'm a part-time vegetarian (fair weather, really). LOS's panang was just like red curry. I don't know what's closer to original recipe, LOS or Komol's, but Komol's just tastes better. Its really robust and hearty. LOS's was really smooth and wussy. It just slipped off the tofu. 

We also got the steamed mussels. They steam it in fish sauce and basil leaves and give you a green chili lime dipping sauce which has even more fish sauce and is deceptively spicy. Just because it ain't red, don't mean it ain't spicy. It was really fishy. And the sauce was way too hot for me consume.

We got the sweet sticky rice dessert, which I think is normally supposed to come with mango, but they were 86 for the day. The dessert was good. Standard stuff. But the coconut milk was really thick and they garnished the rice with a crispy topping, like baked rice or something. That gave the texture a nice variation. 

Sorry, I don't have a cost breakdown of all the items, but for the two of us three entrees, two sticky rice, two drinks, and dessert, and some leftovers, our total bill was $53 before tip. Not bad, I guess. Holy crap, we did eat a lot ... Our entrees ranged $8-15.
