My good friend Mike mentioned that this place is amazing and he wasn't kidding! We went here as a group and let him do the ordering. We had this spicy beef (Nua Yum Katiem) that was absolutely delicious! The Crispy duck was amazing as well as everything else he ordered for us. We had  a few appetizers and some noodle dishes as well. The prices were reasonable and there was plenty of food for everyone. It's all served family style. As some other reviewers have mentioned, the location isn't the best, but the food definitely makes up for it. I've always been a fan of Thai food and am a much bigger one since visiting Lotus. It really makes me look forward to my November trip to Thailand!

Not much more can be said about this place that hasn't already...just a quick update: the wine cellar that is under construction is almost done...the current wine list is a fraction of what they have...the full list that can be seen online will be available once the cellar is finished.

Also, don't order anything specific off the menu...trust your waiter/waitress and let them order for you.  You will not go wrong.

OMFG.  The best Thai food I have EVER had! In Vegas, who knew?!

We came here with a large group so we tried several dishes.  First off, service is really great and friendly.  Our server made a lot of great suggestions and had no problem answering our questions about dishes.  We had the deep-fried garlic prawns, khao soi (curry noodle dish), sai oua (sausage), red and green chili dips, kang hung lay (beef stew), crispy duck with panang sauce, sea bass with ginger, pad thai, and some sticky rice.  

The prawns were superb, deep-fried but not greasy at all and the batter has some great seasoning.  For me the khao soi was the standout dish, everyone loved it and by the end of the meal people were spooning up the curry sauce to eat over rice because it was so good.  I also highly recommend the chili dips.  The green chili was my favorite and reminded me of Mexican green chili because it came with tiny little pork rinds to eat with it. The sai oua had a great flavor.  When you bring it up to your mouth to eat it, you can catch a whiff of the aromatics it's spiced with.  I also really enjoyed the crispy duck and the sea bass was perfectly cooked and tender.  I really enjoyed my meal here.  And dessert was fantastic as well. I highly suggest getting the combo desert plate which comes with crispy fried bananas (they look like fried spring rolls with banana inside instead of veggies) and coconut ice cream over sticky rice.  Heavenly.

If you come here and are overwhelmed by the expansive menu, I would highly recommend being adventurous and ordering mainly off the Northern Thai and Chef's Choice menus.  Parking is plentiful, and because there are quite a few bars and clubs in the immediate area, grabbing a cab back to the Strip is not very difficult.  I highly recommend making a reservation because there seems to be a serious wait otherwise.  Definitely worth the 2 mile trip off the Strip for great quality That cuisine. The hype is all true!

Oh Lotus of Siam. How I have been dreaming about you..!

I have been coming to this restaurant for years now. Almost 4x a year on my quarterly Vegas trips...but it had been awhile since I've been back. 

So on my last trip, I decided to reward my belly with the best Thai food ever. Call me crazy, but I totally don't remember Lotus of Siam tasting as good as it did the last time I went. 

I had a party of 4 and no reservations early Sunday night. Luckily there was room for us (typically if you have no reso, you can expect to eat dinner at 9pm..or never!). It's always a good sign to see other customers coming to eat at the restaurant via taxi with all of their luggage in tow. You know they mean business. 

We didn't order too much since we weren't that hungry. We had 2 soups (just cups) of the Tom Yum Kai and wonton soup. They were both great! We then ordered the green papaya salad, and weren't disappointed. It was so perfectly seasoned and refreshing. 

For our entrees we ordered the green curry (it had eggplant..yumm), pad thai and the best chinese broccoli w/ fried pork belly I've ever had in the world. 

Why oh why is fried pork belly bad for you? Well, just for an hour forget about how unhealthy it is and just eat as much as you can!! The 4 of us were fighting over the last piece of crispy goodness. 

They expanded their dining area and even have a bar!! There are also 2 bathrooms for your enjoyment.

There are only 2 things I can complain about Lotus:
1. The portions are smaller than your usual Thai joint. So if we were really hungry, we would have had to have ordered 2 more entrees and 1 more salad for sure for our party of 4. 
2. Service was incredibly slow during our dinner. I'm not sure if this is normal, or if they're still adjusting to the new additional dining area, but we waited a long long time for our food. We had to ask our waiter 2x to check on it. 

But despite these 'complaints', they really won't stop me from coming back. If anything, I've been caught drooling at my desk, thinking about Lotus of Siam. It's definitely the best Thai I've ever had.

Oh my God, oh my God, oh my God. I've been to this place twice on my annual business trips to Vegas, and it's A-MAZING. It's hidden in a sort of shady-looking plaza, but don't let that deter you! They have pictures of celebrities all over the wall, as well as awards and accolades for best food EVER. 

A large and varied menu, the food is darn good. Forgive me that I can't remember the names of everything, but I've had a Thai dish that was out of this world, as well as a really good appetizer that is pork stuffed into chicken. My colleagues loved their dishes (which was good, since I suggested the place), and the coconut ice cream is awesome. The staff is friendly, and it felt really good to sit down there and eat a great meal after a long day at a convention. If I ever make it out to Vegas again, this is my number one spot to hit!

Ok so maybe it was the awesome reviews that I read before I came here that I expected sooo much from them which resulted in the lower rating than I had even expected to give! We came here for lunch on NYE! 10 min wait for a table pretty nice...service was very good...we ordered the Tom Yum Kai soup based on someone's review..and it was just OK..nothing WOW about it...the Green Curry w/Chicken was the BEST thing we tried! It had the awesome spicy factor we loved! The Drunken Noodles w/seafood was disappointing cuz the dish was so greasy...granted we were super full from the meal but based on my BF and our visits to many other Thai places in SoCal..we can't rightly say this was the BEST Thai food we've had...we might have to give it another try on our next visit...

Someone told us this was one of the best Thai food restaurants in the country.  Apparently a lot of the celebrity chefs dine here when they want good Thai food.

I believe it.

Hands down, best Thai food I've ever had.  One of our friends said that he thought it tasted better than what he had in Bangkok.

First we ordered the Crispy Rice with sausage.  This was probably my least favorite dish, but everyone else loved it.  It has very strong mint and lime favors, and it's different than anything I've ever eaten.  It was my least favorite, but it was still good.

Then he had the pad thai, northern red curry, and drunken noodle soft shell crab.  EVERYTHING was absolutely delicious.  The northern red curry looked more like a stew than a curry (I guess that's how they do it in northern Thailand?), but it was still very tasty!  The drunken noodle soft shell crab was AMAZING.  Just writing about it makes me want to drive back out to Vegas...

A MUST-TRY whenever you're in town.
Super good Thai food. Comparable with Ruen Pair in Hollywood.

THE BEST THAI FOOD EVER!  no where else just like it... believe me.... i tried searching for a similar Thai place in LA

i usually stick to the same dishes, which keeps me coming back each time i visit vegas.  I LOVE the garlic prawn and the crispy rice.  

this place is a hole in the wall to me due to the location and the looks of it, but the food really proves itself.  there are even pictures of famous chefs on the wall such as Joel Robuchon, Guy Savoy and much more.

if you haven't tried already, your missing out....

The absolute best Thai restaurant in the entire country! I've been to so many Thai restaurants I can't even count, in places as far flung as Seattle, New York, DC, NC, and TX. Bar none, this place is the best. 

It's in an old and little strip mall, but don't let that fool you. This place rocks. 

I went for dinner on a friday night and basically our whole table didn't order off the menu. We just told the waiter that we had never been there, and to bring out an assortment of their best dishes. A little risky, since there are a number of specific food items I will not eat - but boy was the risk worth it. We had the most amazing food, and unfortunately because we didn't order off the menu I can't tell you what we had. 

Go with a group, have the chef make whatever his favorite dishes are, and you will be awed.

The best Thai food I have ever had! There were so many dishes to choose from that I actually forgot what we ordered. But I remember that the portions were smaller and on the pricey side. But then again, I didn't feel like I was pigging out even though we ordered a lot of dishes. 

If you're in VEGAS with your friends, I highly recommend checking it out! As far as the price, I would rather eat here than shell out $$$ at any of the Asian fusion [insert a chef's famous name here] on the strip.

The crispy duck curry is my favorite, followed closely by the pad thai.  Sortof reminds me of one of those places with secret prostitutes and mahjong parlors filled with old people (yeah I know it's not a Chinese restaurant).  The waiter was very friendly and didn't mind describing the menu items.  Make reservations, they are pretty full.

The service was awesome; very fast, helpful, cheerful, and polite! And the food was absolutely delicious. I visited this place twice during one visit to Vegas bc I couldnt get enough of it :) My favorite was the Drunken Sea Bass, Red Curry, pork larb, and the mint duck... all reasonably priced. I know thai food and this is it, yum.
They bought the unit next door and expanded the restaurant, lots of seating now.   Still exceptional as always.

This is a a fantastic restaurant. Disregard any reviews that try to rate Lotus of Siam based on the lunch buffet. And some of the more common Thai dishes, like pud Thai, are no better here than at your neighborhood Thai restaurant back home.
Lotus of Siam offers an exceptional variety of food. Beef jerky is always a winner for me as an appetizer. I also like the spicy crispy rice and the bacon-wrapped shrimp that are deep fried. (See my photos).
Tom ka gai is a chicken coconut soup they do so well. The way I get it normally in restaurants is that they cook the mushrooms in the soup. At Lotus of Siam they add fresh mushrooms right before they serve it. THat's a different way to do it and I like it. Also, if you look at my picture, you'll see a nice dose of chili sauce floating on top of the soup. Be forewarned about eating that straight. Make sure you mix up your soup before you eat it.
The duck dishes are usually pretty good at Lotus of Siam as well. 
If you're not sure what you want, you can trust your server to order for you. Just tell them what you don't like and they can pick dishes for you.
The wine selection is fantastic and the prices are more than reasonable.

This is my favorite Thai place in Vegas, and my favorite place to send out-of-towners to. It's in a weird strip mall (as most off-strip restaurants in Vegas are) but it's a quick cab ride from most hotels on The Strip. I'm not a big fan of buffets, so I like to order off the menu. Amazing thai red curry chicken, and one of the best reisling lists in the country. Word on the street is that the chef used to cook for the emperor of Thailand.

This is our special occasion restaurant even though it's not too fancy. It's kind of in the ghetto, but it is so worth the drive.  Everything I have ever had here is fantastic.  Not sure what it's called on the menu, but the crispy prawns with their heads are super yummy... and the drunken noodles, nam kao tod, tom kah kai soup, coconut ice cream which seems like it is home made, sticky rice dessert, etc. are all unbelievable.  Oh I can't forget and my new fave green papaya salad...so nummy!

This place disproves the old "location, location, location" line.  Located in a seedy strip mall off E Sahara, these folks talk Thai,  very well.  The key to the menu here is prolificity, with close to 150 items capped off by a series of Chef's dishes and curries all of them fresh and interesting.  For me it was the Roast Duck Red Curry with pineapple and a dash of coconut milk, preceded by an amazing salad of crispy Soft shelled crab tossed with shaved cabbage, lime, peanuts and fresh chili (10/10).  But wait, there's more!  Wine list is crazy extensive for an ethnic joint.  Great German riesling selection, to be expected, but a surprising amount of Burgundy plus a ton of other old and new world juice.  When in Sin City don't forget to tell your cabby (sorry no tram) to hit the Village Square Commercial Center and check out my favorite place for a taste of Thai.

This place has been called "The Best Thai Restaurant in North America." I'm not sure how this was determined, but the food is pretty delicious.  And, yes, you CAN get many items veganized here: the ala carte menu is a great place to get some veggie and/or tofu combinations, from Pad Prik King to Chili Mint, to green curry (one of my faves!).  Just be sure to tell them no fish sauce and ask about which curry bases are OK. (Sometimes red curry is made w/ shrimp paste).  The spicy vegetable soup is amazing and lives up to it's name! The phrase "I can't feel my lips anymore, but I can't stop eating this!" is commonly uttered.  You can actually get a few delicious dessert options here too! Sticky rice w/ mango, coconut ice cream (made w/ coconut milk FTW!), fried bananas.... all delish.

Bonus: they have Albarino(!!!!!) and Stone IPA on their drink menu, so I get my choice of two of my favourite bevvy's to complete my meal.  

They have recently expanded and about doubled their seating capacity, so it's easier than it used to be to get a table too!  I would recommend a reservation on a Fri or Sat.... but if it's packed you can always trot over to Komol for some excellent chow as well.

I will say this though -- I have been vegan about 7 years and don't stray from that.  I also generally try to encourage others to eat in a similar manner.  HOWEVER - when I take meat eaters to Lotus, I pretty much insist that they order off the Northern Thai menu.  Only one item on there doesn't have meat, but the dishes are very rarely found on American Thai menus... So just go for it already! If you're an adventurous eater, you'll probably love it.

This place is sanity off the strip.  

Located in a strip mall cluster of Asian stores that look boarded up and whose names are hard to read, Lotus of Siam eluded me on the first attempt, but I'm glad I pursued it by way of a back street that revealed just how big this shopping center is.  This might help: it is right next door to Namaste Indian.  The restaurant is one of many that line a massive deserted parking lot that will make you think twice about getting out of your car, but inside the feeling was totally different.  

The servers were super friendly and helpful, and there were sane people there, sitting at tables, wearing clothes, on lunch breaks from office jobs or sober enough today to make it a few miles off the strip with cheerful faces, the ability to form coherent sentences, and the sense to seek out real food at reasonable prices.  What a relief!

I'm not a fan of buffet, and looking at this one didn't change my mind.  The selection was limited and the items looked like typical buffet food.  However, for those interested, the couple of main entrees looked decent and smelled good, and the $8.99 it costs seems more than fair.  

I opted for the menu and was completely satisfied.  Interestingly, they have a northern Thai food section, and I got the first dish listed.  It is an egg noodle dish served in a red coconut curry broth.  Even though it wasn't on the menu I was able to get tofu instead of chicken or beef.  The bowl of steaming sweet, spicy, sour, and creamy deliciousness is topped with cilantro, green onion, and a few fried noodles and served with a plate of "sliced" red onion, pickled cabbage, and a lime wedge.  The broth was absolutely delicious!  I savored each spoonful, and before I knew it had eaten the entire bowl.  It was the perfect portion for lunch.  

As for the garnish, the pickled cabbage had an interesting earthy taste underneath the vinegar, but I don't know what vegetable it was exactly.  The server thought it might be napa.  The only thing I would change would be the red onions which I think would have been much better if they were actually sliced rather than coarsely chopped as they were.  I love just about any vegetable ingredient, but huge chunks of raw onion are an exception.  

My general feeling for this place is gratitude and affection.  The food was excellent, the servers earnest, and the atmosphere perfect for decompressing from the chaos of the strip.  I would definitely come back if I happened through Vegas again, but then I might get too curious about the neighboring restaurants...

This place serves pretty good thai food in my opinion.  The portions are a bit smaller than I expected.  The bright side to that is you get to try out other dishes.  I was in a rush so I did not really get to order all out at the time.  

There was a waiting line for 2 people on a Saturday at 9 PM.  The staff were friendly, but it took them a while to come our table to put in our order.  The place was busy at the time or maybe they were short on staff that night.  The inside was nice and clean.  There is a large wall of wine to choose from.  The prices are a bit more than I normally pay for thai food.  Two dishes, thai iced tea, tax, and tip ended up ~$30.

I ordered the beef noodle soup and the pineapple fried rice.  The beef noodle soup was pretty good.  It was spicy, but not too bad.  I normally don't like to eat spicy foods, but I was able to enjoy the noodle soup dish.  The pineapple fried rice had a hint of yellow curry, large chunks of pineapple, chicken, and shrimp.  The rice was nice and fluffy.  The thai iced tea was pretty good too.  

On the way out I saw a picture of Drew Barrymore on the wall.  I don't really like her movies, but at least she has pretty good taste in thai food.  Also a picture of Elvis was on the wall too.  Hey, if the food is good enough for the King, its good enough for me.

I do regret not ordering dessert.  I will definitely go back to this place and try out other items and get dessert.

Bon Appetit!

This was our 2nd time at Lotus of Siam after being introduced to this restaurant years ago by our friends from LA. This restaurant does not skimp on flavors. EVERYTHING is bursting with lots and lots of flavors.

Now I can take some heat; I can take jalapeños no prob and even little bits of habanero in my sushi. But the mild level of spiciness of Lotus of Siam's soup is a bit much for me especially after the chili sits in the soup for a while. So order at your own risk!

Crispy rice mixed with minced sour sausage is one of the popular dishes mentioned here on Yelp and it deserved the reputation. Like I said, BURSTING with flavors.

The crispy duck with chu-chee was delicious!  Now I had no idea what chu-chee is, but the crispy duck came out in a red curry. Both the duck and the curry was very good. My only complaint is the price tag of $20 for a few pieces of duck and not very much sauce. It was good though!

If you took a cab to Lotus of Siam, be sure to ask the cab driver for a card/phone # and call for a cab to pick you up when you get the check. It does take some time for cabs to get to this location so if you call when you get the check, you shouldn't have to wait much longer after you're done settling the bill.

Visit #1: 

To be fair, so far this review is only for the buffet... which was god awful.  I can't see how anyone could rate this as quality food, even those that don't really know authentic Thai food.  In an attempt to be fair though, I will return one day and try their main course dishes.  I've not heard good things about Lotus from friends of mine that know real Thai food.  I'll reserve my own judgment for a time when I can try something other than the horrible buffet they have during lunch.

We had dinner there a year ago, and it was the best Thai food I've ever had.  I've been searching for something comparable since, and have failed.

Do NOT eat at their lunch buffet.  I'd give the lunch buffet 2 stars.  It's like they have two different chefs.

We were here about a year ago and I still remember how good our meal was. I remember that I had something from the 'Northern' part of the menu. I wanted to get another bowl of this right AFTER stuffing ourselves at the Wynn buffet! So that tells you how good the soup was because the Wynn buffet is so good! My husgand had the pad thai and it was good but he was playing it good and there's a lot of places that do good pad thai.

We were there for spring break vacation. Cousin recommended the place. It looks like a dump from outside but it's nice inside and very large place. We skipped the buffet and ordered from the menu. Food was very good.
Went here for Xmas. it's totally worth the cab ride. Fierce!

Widely regarded as one of the best Thai restaurants in the country, Lotus of Siam sits in a semi-dilapidated strip mall.  But don't let the surroundings fool you.  The food here is excellent.  Saipin Chutima was nominated for best chef in the Southwest Region by the James Beard Foundation in 2008.

The classic Pad Thai is a great rendition.  The noodles aren't overcooked, and the sauce is subtle enough to let the flavor of each ingredient shine through.

The Sua Rong Hai (charbroiled beef) is a great dish.  Tender, flavorful slices of perfectly cooked beef come with sauce that is somewhat on the spicy side, but not overly so.  The sauce compliments the beef perfectly, instead of overpowering it.

The Nam-Prik-Noom (Green chili dip) comes with an assortment of vegetables along with fried pork rinds.  Although flavorful, this wasn't as spicy as I was expecting.  A little more heat would have brought an extra dimension to this dish.

The Musaman Curry is unlike anything I have ever had before.  If you are a fan of Satay and enjoy the peanut sauce that comes along with it, you will absolutely love this dish.  It is like a curried version of the peanut sauce, with roasted peanuts, potatoes, carrots, and chicken.  This is a little on the sweet side, but not cloyingly so.

The Thai Beef Salad was the best thing I had on the night.  Although relatively simple, the salad was just bursting with flavor.  An explosion of lime juice, fish sauce, and heat make every bite leaving you wanting more.  The beef is very tender and juicy.

The thing that seems to set Lotus of Siam apart from just about every other Thai restaurant is the BOLDNESS of flavor in each dish and every bite.

Wonderful flavors, great great Thai food!
I also like to come here for the buffet lunch with a friend. It's only ten bucks you can't beat it!
Take your pick you can't go wrong unless you're like Ben Stiller in Along Came Polly.

Wow, the best Thai food I have outside Thailand. Well worth the effort to get there. A word of caution, be conservative with the spice. The papaya salad blew mouth away. The sea bass was magnificent. Let the waiter steer you. Also it was very reasonable priced.
My wife can't stop talking about it.

You know, Lotus of Siam seems like one of those great things that they just happen to forget when they were writing the Bible. I came recently and I must say, I'm LOVING the remodeling. It's so bright and spacious now. But don't let the extra space fool you because you will still need a reservation to escape the extremely long wait. 

1st place winner: Garlic Prawns: I'm not sure exactly what it's called, but this place is famous for it apparently. What they do is that they have these prawns dipped in a light, garlic tempura sauce and then deep fried. Okay, one: it's deep fried, and two it's garlic with prawns. What could possibly go wrong? It's SUPER delicious! Like the shells from the prawns cracks off the meat and becomes super crispy. I personally think the crispy skins are the best part of it because it just has this awesome crunch and then you have this huge explosion of flavor in your mouth... (I just realized how wrong that last part sounds... oh well!) 
2nd Place: the Shrimp Pad Thai: I was really surprised about the execution of the Pad thai. Unlike most Thai restaurants, they use a thinner and skinnier noodle which actually absorbs the peanut sauce a lot better because of the greater surface area AND it's chewey which deserves my love and affection.
3rd Place: all other food items. I can't really go into depth on what else you should order here because I'm already drooling enough as is after explaining the prawns.... hehe

The price is right and it won't leave your wallet crippled, which is excellent because everything else in Vegas is supperrrr expensive! If you want a breather from the strip and delicious food, come here and murder your diet. It is sin city after all. :)

You may get panhandled by a meth addict or two in the parking lot of neglect, but this Thai place is serious business. The menu is huge, and the food is the drug that the masses line up for. Big wine selection if you want to go all the way. Play up the spicyness scale from 1-10 if your server offers.

You really get your money's worth here. Great place to visit when you're broke from frequenting the $50 buffets on the strip.

Their pad thai is one of the best I've tasted. Our serve told us that they use peanut oil and we've had issues with Asian restaurants that mix their seafood and non-seafood pots and pans. My parents explained all my little brother's food allergies and the guy was really understanding and accommodating. He made sure that the dish we ordered for my brother wasn't deadly :]

"Pick your spiciness level on a scale of one to ten for any dish you desire." Hell, yes!

We would have walked the ~1.5-mile distance from Circus Circus, but it was unseasonably wet (and cold) outside. We gave up and took a taxi, which set us back by about $15 round trip, including tip. Our taxi driver asserted that the shopping center that the Lotus of Siam is situated in is the first shopping center in Vegas. I haven't fact-checked him, but it did seem like it'd been around for quite some time, especially the funky parking and overall traffic layout.

Jon A. and I picked out three dishes (with the help of our server), and I opted to try the Thai lime drink. The dishes included a bowl of Tom Yum Plar Dook (hot and sour soup with catfish, lime juice, lemongrass and straw mushrooms), roasted duck curry, and beef Khao Soi (Northern Thai egg noodles in curry sauce and coconut cream with your choice of beef or chicken, served with a side of with sliced red onions, lime, and pickled vegetables). Including Jon's soft drink, we ended up $45 lighter, including tax and tip.

Everything was delectable, but we suspected that they may have mixed up our spice-level orders. Jon's spiciness tolerance level is much higher than mine, so we ordered the communal soup and my roasted duck curry as a six, and the Khao Soi was to be a ten. However, after profusely sweating through the catfish soup and hoping I'd be able to handle my curry, we realized that the soup was probably the ten and the entrees both ended up sixes. Oh, well: everything was delicious, and I'd go back and order that soup at a ten again. The heat from both temperature and spiciness really hit the spot! And the Thai lime drink? Well, it was a little too sweet for my tastes, but it was nice to cool off with while working on that soup.

Don't expect much from the atmosphere, but that hardly matters. The crowds spoke by filling up the place by 7:30 PM on a Thursday evening. (Luckily we arrived before the swarms did. And the swarms had a wait of 45 minutes when we were leaving.) The service is pretty good for an Asian restaurant, but don't expect utter perfection.

The verdict: Excellent Thai restaurant! It ranks up there on my favorites. Not sure when I'll be back in Vegas, but if I do find myself on the Strip, then I'll be sure to stop in at the Lotus again.
i don't get why everyone seems to love this place. service is pretty slow and the food is just ok. the emphasis seems to be on volume over quality.
i went there after reading articles about how amazing this place is and i was somewhat let down :(
one the best thai joints out there; crispy rice is a must try. and there's a dish with raw fresh shrimp with a really tasty spicy sauce.  very creative and very good.

pretty darn good.

the papaya salad, medium, was pretty good.  my coworkers thought it was too spicy but i liked it.

the green curry was good.  creamy.
the tom yum was really good too.  

expect spicy if you order medium. or maybe it was just that day.
willl go back.
season2

(Im rating based on the field of buffets)Thai style lunch buffet for only $8.99? Fast-food chains, who? News flash, just in: Curry and I just eloped. All their herbs and spices are potent, they probably have their own garden outside. but then again, this is Las vegas, so their herb and ingredient source is definitely not local, but nevertheless, fresher than the prince of bel air.

Forgive me for my lack of knowledge in thai eats, but deep curry puffs(wontons)? shaking my head, "yes." Well. It'd be better if it was freshly fried out of the oil tank, but it's a buffet, so it's a compromise. Just like their pad Thai noodles are a little bit on the dry side, but still tastes decent. They have a nice and simple selection on their buffet menu, like the ginger tofu dish. They also offer regular menus as well, which I have yet to try.

Many of the workers here are smiley, which in that moment, makes me just want to book a flight to Thailand, now. And yes they're on top of their service. I really adore this place.

A perfect 10 in my book.  This IS the best Thai Food in Vegas.  Don't folks know this is where the Chef's go to eat.  I believe all these people who gave it bad reviews were paid to write this, because anyone in thier right mind know this is the BEST!

After 4-5 hours of driving from LA, fueled only by Starbucks, honeydew, and pure excitement, the crew and I headed out to Lotus of Siam upon the reco of a friend who was here just last week.

Thinking that it would be packed as it was last week, we tried calling in to make reservations. To our disappointment, they wouldn't accept reservations on a Friday night so we decided to make it out there anyways. It's not too far off the strip but be sure to have a good lookout because we nearly missed it if a friend had not pointed out an Indian cuisine sign right next to Lotus of Siam.

This place is literally fabulous! The food is great, service is fast, and the portions are just right (for those who enjoy moderate portions). Please order the following:

a) Curry Catfish
b) Chicken Spicy Fried Rice (spicy level 6)
c) Seafood Soup
d) Pad Thai

Seriously, this place is legit. You gotta try it, especially when you're sick of paying ridiculous premiums for food on the Strip.

After reading the reviews, I wanted to try the restaurant and this is a first that I've ever heard of a Thai buffet offered.  As a big fan of Thai food, I thought I was going to have a great meal, but.........NOT!!!!

Located in a delapitated strip mall of other restaurants  and shops, this hole in the wall I thought.......might be a surprise and thus this is why there were so many positive reviews on YELP.  However, my experience was not such.

You walk in and the entrance is small and 3 people can not stand comfortably.  It's a small area then you're at the cashier's and the front room is dated and has painted green lattice partitions.  The rugs appeared dirty and the lighting was dim.  this is the area we were seated.  There's another section to th right of this and you can tell it's a newer updated area and open and looked lighter and cleaner.  the bathrooms appear to be remodeled and was nice and clean.

I wanted to try the buffet for $8.99 that seemed reasonable, but they didn't offer any curry dishes, or popular Thai dishes.  the variety was lacking compared to when you go to an Indian buffet restaurant.  they offered only had about 8 entrees, 2 soups, 6 misc of salad, fried shrimp chips, fried banana, fried curry pouches, apple slices and orange slices and that's it.   I was disappointed and do not recommend their buffet at all.   

they had 2 types of soups, duck soup which had bits of duck and was greasy and the other was a egg flower soup and was good.   They had pad thai, but it was nothing special, the fried garlic wings was good, the other dishes were just alot of stir fry vegetables, and a chow mein style noodle dish.  a green salad with ranch dressing, I didn't understand how this is Thai....why didn't they have payaya salad.  Overall, it was more of a chinese buffet type food then all Thai food.

My partner ordered the Pad Sew flat noodle dish, but the waiter came out with another dish altogether.  A disappointment, but he liked the dish anyway.   It was a beef stir fry with cashews and a bowl of rice. 

the waiter charged us for the incorrect dish that cost more, and he wouldn't correct the bill bc he said we accepted the dish and didn't return it back to the kitchen.  He wasn't very nice about this and the mistake was most likely due to a language barrier communication.

So DO NOT go for the buffet.  Make sure you double check your order to get the right dish...best to point to the item on the menu, since English is not their first language.

Most of the dishes were about $9. to $15. per entree and that's expensive compared to the bay area, probably bc they have to ship it to LV.

I can't comment on their Thai dishes, but can say that the buffet is not worth it, and they should get rid of the buffet or expand it and keep it freshly stocked and not sitting there for so long.  No one refilled any of the pans when I was there.

Anyone giving this place 3 or below is simply not being realistic.  GREAT food, great wine list, very good service.  I've been 6 times in 2010 and have never ordered off the menu, I simply ask the server.  

The place itself is not a beauty, but the low prices compared to the great food more than make up for that aspect.

At Lotus I close my eyes and point and that is what I have for dinner.  It has never let me down, and honestly I am not that adventurous an eater. We take everyone here that we can and this is the not so secret gem of the Vegas foodies.

Bacon wrapped prawn wontons are unbelievable. The prawns stay tender while the bacon gets crispy. Sauce is perfect as well.

Seabass with drunken noodles is delicious and useful after drinking.

You'll spend a bit waiting if you don't have a reservation but the bar helps the time go by with a legit wine selection.

Believe the hype.  This place is the real deal.  Hard to say if it's the best Thai food in the country, but it's easily among the best I've ever had.

Everything was a highlight, but in particular the papaya salad and some chicken dish with Thai basil and mint stand out.  Oh, plus the dessert of mango and sticky rice....yummm
.

Best Thai food I have ever had but it almost didn't happen. I was a little leery when we drove up and there was 16 feet of plywood over the front window. But once we stepped in, it was a whole different story. 

Food was great. Complex flavors. Service was great. The only thing I wish is that I could have had was another trip back to eat.

Best Thai food I've had in the US since I moved back from Asia in 2007...and I've been on a constant quest for good Thai food here. 

Don't let the location fool you...go out of your way for this place!

Best Thai food I've had so far in Las Vegas. We ordered the duck curry, pad see yew, soft-shell crab, beef panang, oyster pancake, a ton of Singha beer, and mango/coconut rice to finish it off.  Place is pretty popular now and even though they expanded, you still need a reservation.  Everything is pretty good and might be better than what I've had in LA.

Best Thai place in these great United States!

I've lived everywhere...and I would take a flight to Vegas for Lotus of Siam...and not the slots :)

Go for dinner...its packed...virbrant...and the food is world-class!
Best in Vegas... To date... Curry shrimp and drunken noodles are the best!!! 10 for spice and 10 for flavor...

Best thai food, i am not too sure. BUT i did have the lunch buffet (8.99), pad thai was ok, the curry had too much ginger. I might have to come back for dinner to experience the full effect. I did try the mango with stickey rice...again, not sure what the hype was....i stick with mango pudding.

Service was very good

Came in for dinner last night and was suprised to see it was very busy for a Sunday evening.

I noticed the menu has been revised and prices on some items have increased.  

This is what we ordered:
Seafood soup  5 stars
Pad Woodsen noodles with pork 4 stars
Nua Sao Reno 4 stars
Kang Kare catfish 2 stars
Deep fried bannanas and coconut ice creme 5 stars
Thai ice tea.

Overall the meal was tasty and very filling. I would pass in the future on the northern Thai Kang Kare catfish which is made with curry and veggies, I prefer the Panang curry with coconut milk which has a thicker sauce and less veggies. 

The highlight of the meal was dessert.  Those fried bannanas are the best I've ever had!

Came to Lotus of Siam on a friend's recommendation, told this is one of the best thai places in America. This place was very good, in fact the most complete and consistently good thai restaurant. We got several dishes, pananag, larb, crab fried rice, sea bass with drunken noodles and some others. The larb was my favorite, it was amazing! The only negative is that the portion size is a little on the small side, but other than that the food was good. Definitely would go back next time I'm in Vegas.

Can Lotus of Siam be summed up? Can it be leveled by a few words? You'd be hard pressed. Try criticizing the best Thai meal of your life, one that you paid less for than almost every Thai dinner you've ever had. 

Completely unpretentious, despite an incredible Riesling selection and the most robust and spicy Thai flavors you'll ever come across. Make sure to order Yam Nua, the grilled steak salad with mint and chili.

I am still speechless after my meal, the flavors lingering on my tongue and beckoning me to move to Las Vegas so I can eat here more often. Well, no meal can drive you that far.

Every single guide book touts this place as the bomb.  Why is that?  Sure, they admit that the place is a hidden away in a shopping plaza and doesn't look like much but that the food is phenomenal for the price.  It was ok but not quite what the guide books say, which makes me wonder if they got a kick-back for touting this place.  I was just expecting something different.

We went for lunch.  The food was ok but not the best I've had.  We went with the buffet to have the opportunity to try new things.  It was ok.  Maybe only 1 item on the buffet had any protein in it; most everything else was noodles, rice, and vegetables only.  We were there in the last hour and a half before lunch closed, and there were two buffet items that they never refilled.

The service was nice but not necessarily the most prompt or attentive.  Twice I had to go seek out my own napkins, and we waited a long time to flag down anyone to ask for the check despite the fact that it wasn't that busy.

Every. Bite. Was. The. Best.

Here is the thought that kept coming to my head at lunch hour today as I dined on the lunch buffet and watched a group of 4 waiting for their food, "if you had the buffet, you'd be eating by now". I'm sure their entree's were good but....

Finally tried this place after numerous trips to Vegas.  This is my FAVORITE Thai restaurant if not THE favorite restaurant in Vegas.  It will definitely be my go to place to eat whenever I am in Sin City.  That is quite a recommendation, considering I am part Thai, my father was a Thai chef, and I travel all over Thailand frequently eating my way through the country :-)

It is crazy what you find in a nondescript strip mall off the Strip.  Other diners seemed to be enjoying the lunch buffet...when in Vegas, right?  We did look at the food offered on the buffet and it looked good, but after seeing some of the regional dishes that are not commonly available at most Thai restaurants, we had to bypass that.  

The tod mun pla (fish cakes, sometimes on the menu at Thai restaurants, but more often no) was very good.  The Khao Soi is not offered at very many places.  I can probably count on my hand how many of the thousands of Thai places I have eaten at had this on their menus.  It was phenomenal!  It was authentic to any of khao soi I have had in Chiang Mai and other parts of Thailand.  It was even served with the same garnishes.  The dish was bursting with flavors.  I was in heaven and would have gone back again for dinner that night if I didn't have other obligations.  My friend had the yellow curry and that was very good as well.  

The servers were attentive and good about refilling our water and checking to see that we were doing okay.  I complimented the chef and raved about the khao soi being as good as any I have had in Chiang Mai and was informed that the chef was from Chiang Mai, so it was great.  They looked like they had a solid wine list as well.  The other great part of the dining experience was the price.  It was $30 for two people with an appetizer, two entrees, and one Thai iced tea.  After dropping $20 for breakfast for one while stuck in the hotel, this was a wonderful deal :-)

Great food, awesome wine list, high quality stems, friendly service and reasonable prices.  LoS is justifiably famous.

Crispy pork with Chinese broccoli was incredible as were the Isaan specialties.

Hailed as the best Thai food in America I had to try the food. While I haven't tried every Thai restaurant in America to confirm that it is the Best Thai in America, it certainly was the best Thai I have had in America. Located in an unassuming strip mall from the small door that is the entrance betrays the fairly large and decently appointed interior. I highly recommend making reservations as restaurant gets packed quickly.

The best dishes are in last 4 pages of the 12 page menu under Chefs Selections and Northern Thai. My suggestion would be to tell your waiter what type of food you feel like and let the waiter narrow down the choices for you.

I would certainly come again.

Having just returned to Las Vegas for a quick business trip early this week, I had to make a few visits to some of my fave haunts when I lived here. Of course, LoS was high on the list and it didn't disappoint!

LoS always gets the following accolades: "gotten the nod from the James Beard Foundation", "the place where all the local chefs come to eat", "one of the best Thai restaurants in North America", blah blah blah. Everyone has said it, heard it and knows it. Whatever. It's great and still my gold standard outside of kidnapping my friend's Thai mom and having her cook my dishes out of my own kitchen!

A few noteworthy changes if you haven't been there in awhile (since March 2010 according to our waiter):
1. They've expanded into the now defunct Korean restaurant that used to be on the right side of the LoS.
2. They've remodeled the inside...it's no longer the "hole-in-the-wall" greatness it used to be...everything is def. more upscale albeit in the same dive Commerical Center with the Green Door*.
3. They expanded the old wine "cabinet" into a friggin' 15' glass wine cellar centered prominently in the middle of the newly redecorated interior. Way cool!
4. There's a nice new shiny bar on the far right side of the resto - cool.
5. 2 sets of bathroom now - the older "boys" and "girls" side on the left and now the much nicer and (thank God) larger (multi-stalls) "men" and "women" bathrooms on the left side. No more waiting in the hallways!

A few extra notes/details on the food (this visit):
1. We ordered four entrees (Pad See Ew, Mee Krob, Tofu Penang Curry and a Northern style curry made with catfish) and 2 apps (Tom Kha Gai and Tod Mun) for 5 people. Plenty of food and everyone finished up the meal for bill of $75 including 4 drinks. Not bad!
2. Spice level was low for this meal at a "5"  b/c we were catering to a wide range of palates, but as a note you can always request the pepper rack for those that want more. Honestly tho, if you do request the "10"...it's spicy greatness and you won't be disappointed...but just be aware. I love it at the level. 
3. What I loved the most (generally speaking) was the delicate flavours of the dishes. I didn't find any sort of heavy handedness when it came to the flavor profiles - not too sweet, not too gunky (no fillers), etc.
4. The Penang was incredible and had this beautiful creamy nuttiness to it....you could taste the complexities of flavours in it - a richness from the coconut milk, not too sweet, with hints of the kefir in it. Just a note, if you haven't been here...most dishes can be substituted for veggie friendly (i.e., tofu) and they willingly suggest it if you can't find something you like.
5. The Pad See Ew was gorgeous. It had that high heat smoky flavor to it I crave in the dish. Not too sweet and a balanced flavour with the basil leaves - i.e., not overly "basily" as some places make it. So good...you could taste the individual ingredients in the dish!
6. I wasn't a fan of the Mee Krob, but it was tasty and well done. It's just not my favorite dish for Thai cuisine.
7. The Tod Mun is done the way I like it. Thin patties that are just luscious and perfectly seasoned/fried and complemented with the cucumber dressing. The crispness of the cabbage and the cucumbers provides the perfect textural complement to the home made fish patties with bits of green onions throughout.
8. The Tom Kha Gai had that nice bit of sourness and just enough heat to start off the meal properly. A very flavourful broth with the bits of lemon grass and galangal throughout.
9. The unique and different item was the northern Thai style curry - it was very broth-like but good. Almost reminiscent of the Thom Kha Gai, but no lemongrass in it. I actually enjoyed it quite a bit, but found it more mild in taste and the flavours were *VERY* subtle and refined. So, if you're expecting bold typical Thai flavours...be warned and you might want to pass on this dish. Otherwise, it's a nice change from the usual typical dishes one can order.

A few notes on service:
Excellent as always. Not too invasive, yet not too rushed. We had a leisurely dinner therefor several hours - even after finishing our meal, we sat and continued talking and never once felt like we were being rushed out. They even came by and refilled out drinks while we talked!

If you haven't figured this out...yeah, I love and miss this place a lot. Living on the east coast now really highlights how different and how much better the Thai food is out west. Eitherway, if you're visiting or you already live in Las Vegas, LoS is a helluva good joint! You won't be disappointed. Now, only if they would Fedex their food.....

*If you have to ask...you don't want to know.

Hello, my name is Anhdao and I am a Thai food-addict.  The habit started nine years ago, when I lived in Los Angeles and a drive to Thai town was only 10 minutes.  I cannot go more than a couple of days without getting Thai.  Any longer than that and symptoms such as sleeplessness, lack in work diligence, and even unnecessary irritation will begin.

Lotus of Siam is the Holy Grail for any Thai food addict.  It is the only Thai place outside of the native country and accepts credit cards that claims legions of Thai foodie fans, myself included.  I don't know if the legends are true about the former chef who cooked for Thai royalty.  Legends in this town often spread like wild fire, without true origins.  But Lotus of Siam is not a lie, because the food does not lie.

If you are a undiscriminating Thai food-eater, I don't recommend this place, especially if you've heard too much of its reputation.  Lotus of Siam's pad thai or curries do not taste that differently from Archi's or Pin Kaow, and you're guaranteed to pay more here.  But if you are missing those Bangkok street vendors and want a taste of Thailand in North America, this is where you go.

Here are some adventurous (but not risky) authentic Thai dishes to try at Lotus:

1.  Yum Tale (combination seafood salad): the seafood tastes as if Vegas was a beach town; for the price, I venture to say they don't fly in the seafood daily.  But the marinade and dressing highlight the best in what they have.

2.  Plar Dook O Cha (whole deep-fried cat fish): a traditional Thai classic that is a must-try here.  Although the whole fish (fins, head, eyes and all) may look foreign at first to non-Thai eaters; the crispy-on-the-outside and buttery-soft-on-the-inside is something catfish filets will never entirely own.  Lotus's lime juice & peanut/cashew topping is as good as it gets.

3.  A Nua Dad Deaw (Beef Jerky Issan Style): deep-fried jerky that is salty and savory, perfect to pair with sticky rice and any of their salad.  Many restaurants outside of Thailand don't offer this, including all other Thai restaurants in Vegas.

4.  Khao Soi Braised Short Rib: Khao Soi is a type of Burmese-influenced Northern Thai egg noodles served in curry sauce and coconut cream.  You can order it with chicken or pork also.  But the short ribs are divine.  A very authentic dish that doesn't taste too foreign.

There are restaurants that are one-time affairs, restaurants that are seasonal flings, and restaurants that are long-term relationships.  Lotus of Siam is a relationship for me.  And one that I plan to document on Yelp as I write more updates about this favorite.

Hello. First time diner, long time admirer. 

Okay this will be a somewhat incomplete report. Not that I didn't have dinner there nor did I leave early. Nope. I had appetizer, salad, main course and dessert. So why the incomplete?

Well, with over 150 items (I can't remember the full count) there's a lot to try. With this first visit, we decided to go Thai lite. But not to worry dear Yelpers, I have more visits planned. Luckily, my sister teaches at the high school just down the street so I'll always have an excuse. 

So enough with the pleasantries. Time for the food goodness. To start, we had fried chicken dumplings. It was good though not entirely memorable. I liked eating it but I don't have to have it on my next visit. 

Also up for starters is the traditional Thai salad with peanut dressing. I don't need to say much about this except that my brother in law was slurping up the dressing and kept the bowl of dressing on the table after the salad greens were removed. (He later poured some on his steamed rice. Don't ask.)

For the main dishes, we went with pad Thai (good), sua rong hai (yummy grilled beef with a nice spicy sauce) and panang curry with chicken (my favorite out of the three). 

For dessert we had a rice pudding and fried banana roll. Both if these are very good. I especially enjoyed the banana roll with coconut sugar(?) wrapped in fried crispy wonton goodness. I could've eaten just the innards (good by their lonesome) if I wanted to save a few calories. But why bother living at all? So just shove it all in your mouth and swallow, calories be dammed. (Get your minds out of the gutter, but the double entendre is understandably apropos.) 

So nothing mind-blowingly exciting but good solid eating. I spent a lot of time looking at other tables' orders like the whole fried fish or battered shrimp that caught my eye. Yes, I had prawn envy. 

But I vow to return and try all the other goodies. If my first tastes are good enough to go back before the check has even arrived, then you know me likey. 

Next time you're in Vegas, stop by and get some prawns. I will be.

I had read that this was the best Thai food in North America. That is saying A LOT, so I went in trying not to have super high expectations because I knew I would probably just be disappointed.

I was sooo wrong. This place is AMAZING, and most definitely is, the BEST THAI FOOD IN NORTH AMERICA.

There is a caveat though. We went for dinner on Friday night, and that was the night it was the best Thai food ever. Went again on Monday for lunch, and it was only standard/good Thai food. I don't know if they have different cooks in the kitchen, or if we just ordered the wrong stuff on Monday, but it definitely wasn't as good.

Here are some dishes I'd highly suggest ordering:

-drunken shrimp with noodles underneath -- this was the dish my sister exclaimed she would talk about if she were on the show "Best Thing I Ever Ate" haha. enough said?
-green curry
-fried red snapper 
-they had a veggie dish with fried pork belly. the fried pork belly was DELICIOUS.
-fried banana with coconut ice cream and sticky rice -- THIS IS A MUST ORDER!!! Trust.
-thai tea -- It inexplicably tastes fresher and higher quality that thai tea at other places...

This is going to be a regular stop on future Vegas trips for sure. I can't believe it took me this long to discover it! But I'm so glad I did! =)

I like this place, don't get me wrong. I just haven't been wowed to the extent that I have expected yet... 

Everyone proclaims this to be the best Thai in North America. I can't even safely state that it's the best thai in that particular strip mall... Hard to compete with Komol. The prices are a tad better and I enjoy the spice element a lot more at Komol. 

They specialize in Northern Thai dishes, so it's a good idea to steer clear of the typical Thai dishes you might order and branch out. 

I plan on giving this place yet another try. I tend to think that I might have succombed to all the hype and therefore my expectations were raised to an exceedingly high level, but after several visits I can't safely say that is the case. 

I look forward to another test drive of this place. Any recommendations on what to order are welcomed! Haha.

I must of ordered the wrong items. I liked it but was far from impressed. I'll have to come back and try to find out why this placed is so highly recommended. 
I would not recommend.

I rarely eat Thai food because the places I go to in L.A. either a) serve it too sweet by putting too much coconut milk or b) make it too spicy or hot that it destroys the taste. I almost decided to give up finding a decent Thai restaurant until 1 day driving to a relatives house in Las Vegas I stumbled to this place. Outside it does not look like much but inside it's wonderful and the food is to die for. For those that love Pad Thai go outside the box and try something different. I tried the Green Curry and love it. The prices are cheap and the food is first rate. Also I love their extensive wine list. Casual feel with excellent food make Lotus of Siam a must visit every time I am in Vegas.

I wanted to give it 2 star but i told myself may be the cook had a bad day.   Also, the 3rd star is for the good service.

I found this place while looking up on chef Claude Le Tohic of Joel Robuchon.  Tohic won Best Chef Southwest 2010 from the James Beard foundation  (well deserved), beating Saipin Chutima, of Lotus of Siam and Rick Moonen, of RM Seafood.   

The restaurant walls were covered with framed pictures of the chef/owner and celebrities.  I was excited but when the food arrived i was quite disappointed because it was way too salty for my taste even after i asked the waiter to tell the cook to use less salt (from my experience with most Thai places that i have been to) :-(((

CHARBROILED PRAWN with spicy sauce and tamarind sauce  --- While the prawn were perfectly grilled the green sauce were toooooo salty!

SOM THUM (Thai papaya salad)

NUA NAM TOK (Sliced charbroiled beef mixed with green onion, chili, lime juice & rice powder)  ---- This dish was too wet and the rice powder flavor and texture was buried.

THUM-KA-NOON (shredded young jack fruit, ground pork, tomato, Northern Thai spices and seasoned )  --- the jack fruit and pork was too finely shredded/choped and the dish became mushy. 

TOM YUM SEA BASS (Hot and sour soup with Sea Bass, lime juice, lemon grass and straw mushroom) --- for $23.95 this dish is waaaay overpriced because there was only a tiny amount of fish in small pieces :-( ... we chose 3 out 10 scale for chili hot and it was not hot enough for us, 6 was probably what we should have chosen.

PAD THAI --- nothing special, i've had much better.

MINT AND GREEN CHILI chicken stir-fried --- this was probably the best dish in term of doneness and saltiness 

KANA MOO KROB-Stir-fried Chinese broccoli and crispy side pork slice with oyster flavored sauce

I am really surprise that this place was nominated by the James Beard Foundation, for putting the cooking here on the same par with that of Claude Le Tohic of Joel Robuchon.  May be i should i give it another chance? I don't think so.

I was told that I can't go to Las Vegas without trying the food at Lotus of Siam. I wasn't disappointed. 

For starters, we ordered the Tom Kah Kai and it was definitely a different take on a typical Tom yum soup. It was creamy from the coconut juice with just enough of tart and spiciness to compliment the abundance of chicken, mushrooms, and galanga. It was a great way to start off the meal.

For the appetizer, we ordered the Som Thum (papaya salad) and when asked if we wanted mild, medium, or spicy, we ordered medium. OMG, I am part Thai and I couldn't even take the spiciness. I tried to get seconds, but my friend was able to eat her seconds and my seconds. It was way too spicy for me. If you love hot and spicy, then you won't be disappointed. Before the heat kicked in, I really enjoyed the flavor. Three full glasses of ice water later and I was able to finally taste the next dish.

For the main course, we ordered the yellow chicken curry. This was among the top 10% of the yellow chicken curry dishes that I have ordered at other Thai restaurants. It was as good as my Dad and Mom would make. With rice, it definitely qualified as yummylicious. 

For a good place to go if you are tired of buffets, pay a visit to this place. This was the first time that I was able to go to Las Vegas and not eat at a buffet. :-)

I've been to Lotus of Siam twice, both times with a friend from out of town who insists on going since it's his favorite restaurant in Vegas. I had heard good things from other people as well but had never gone because it's not particularly close to where I live. I'm happy to report that it lived up to expectations and is certainly worth the drive.

Both times, I got Sea Bass. The first time, I got Sea Bass on Drunken Noodles which has a chili and Thai basil sauce. Second time, I got Sea Bass Som Thum, which is over a papaya salad. In both cases, the fish was cooked perfectly and the sauces were tasty but nice and light and didn't overwhelm the fish.

Lotus of Siam has an extensive wine menu. We had the same waiter both times, and he was very well-versed in the selection and guided us to an excellent pairing on both occasions.

I've had Thai in Thailand, and Thai in Little Thai in Hollywood.  

I can only speak of dinner here, since I haven't been in for lunch.

For the US, its pretty close to as good as it gets. I enjoy it more than Palm in Hollywood.

Make reservations if possible. Located in a shanty strip mall. No worries, you're safe and the food and service is excellent.

You'll be hard pressed to find Northern Thai dishes (home style cooking) at many other Thai restaurants, so flip back to the back of the menu and pick an item along with your favorites. 

Pros:
Fried whole snapper
any curry
Nam Sod
...basically any of your favorites are cooked perfectly.

Cons:
Can be long waits
Market price items can be pricey...whole snapper $40, sea bass fried nuggets $25-30.
Beggers in the parking lot
Wish they had shaved ice w/ coco milk and mixed fruit dessert.

If you come to Vegas and fail to visit Lotus of Siam, you're really missing out, unless you're not a fan of amazingly delicious Thai food, that is. There is usually a wait, the atmosphere is classic Vegas strip mall, and the service is not the most friendly, but nothing could dissuade me from going because the food is so good. Come with a group so you can try a bunch of different things, otherwise your head will explode trying to make up your mind. Must try if it's your fist time - the NAM KAO TOD - "Crispy rice mixed with minced sour sausage, green onion, fresh chili, ginger, peanuts, and lime juice."

If you're into wine and Thai food, there isn't a better place in Vegas or anywhere else for that matter. Incredibly authentic cuisine with just a jaw dropping wine list. 

I try to eat here as often as possible.

If you've done any reading on Lotus of Siam, then you know it is consistently rated the top Thai restaurant in the country by many reputable critics and food writers.  While I will not pretend that I have been to the best Thai restaurants in every American city, I will say that this is the best Thai restaurant that I have been to.  I have eaten at many Thai restaurants in Southern California, New York, and Las Vegas, and can definitely say Lotus of Siam beats even the top rated places in those cities.  
Lotus of Siam is located in a run-down, junky shopping plaza in East Las Vegas.  It is literally two doors down from an Asian massage parlor (the kind that we all know doesn't just give massages), and in the same parking lot as one of Vegas' most infamous sex clubs.  Needless to say, the location is rather unexpected for one of the best Thai restaurants in the country.  
The most significant difference between your average Thai restaurant and Lotus of Siam is the plentiful amount of Northern Thai dishes on the menu.  While there are the rare Northern Thai restaurants in the large cities in America, most of the popular Thai food in America is Southern Thai.  Northern Thai cuisine, also known as "Issan" style, has many differences from Southern Thai, often showing influences from Burmese and Indian cuisines.  For example, the Northern Style Thai Curry at Lotus of Siam is a pork braised in a thick, chile-infused curry sauce.  This dish resembles an Indian pork stew, such as korma, yet still has Thai flavors.  There is an entire section of the menu dedicated to the "Issan" style, Northern Thai cuisine.  I always try to order at least two things from this section every time I go, and the Northern Style Pork Curry is a staple in any meal at Lotus of Siam.  

The back story on Lotus of Siam is that their chef, Saipin Chutima, learned to cook from her mother-in-law, who cooked for the royalty of Thailand because her husband was a prominent Thai businessman.  When Bill, Saipin's husband, had to move to America, she followed and eventually opened up a instantly-famous Thai restaurant in Southern California called Renu Nakorn.  Bill and Saipin eventually bought Lotus of Siam in Las Vegas, and they have turned the restaurant into a Vegas institution, and turned Saipin into a celebrity chef.  
The menu at Lotus of Siam can be overwhelming to those who don't like large menus and to those who don't know Thai food well, but ask your server and they will direct you in the right direction.  If you don't like asking your server, then I will give some suggestions that are must-orders at Lotus of Siam.  

Things that must be ordered at Lotus of Siam:
-Issan Style Beef Jerky: Spicy, marinated beef jerky that will make you hate all other beef jerky.  
-Northern Style Larb
-Raw, marinated Sweet Shrimp: Many people are uncomfortable eating raw shrimp, but if you are an adventurous eater then you must order this dish.
- Crispy Duck w/ Cognac Panang Curry: One of the best things you will ever eat.  This is a MUST TRY!
-Sea Bass w/ Drunken Noodle:  Another one of the best dishes you will ever have.  Crispy Sea Bass on wide noodles with aromatic sauce.  MUST TRY!
-Northern Style Pork Curry
-Northern Style Tom Ka Kai: A great version of the classic Thai soup.  
-Charbroiled Shrimp Saab
-Chef Special Garlic Shrimp
-Nam Kao Tod: Crispy rice w/ minced sour sausage.  Great dish!
-Kow Soi: Northern style soup.
-Sai Gog Issan: Sour, Spicy Sausage
-Thai Lime Soda:  Refreshing lime soda similar to limeade.  
-Coconut Ice Cream w/ Mango:  MUST TRY!  very simple, but very good. They only use Mangos when they are in season, so they often use strawberries.

The last thing that puts Lotus of Siam a notch above all other Thai restaurants is their wine list.  Their wine list is the best in Las Vegas.  Yeah, I said it, their wine list beats all the ones created by all the Master Sommeliers at the Bellagio and the strip.  They have the largest selection of German Riesling's that I have ever seen (Bill Chutima swares by the pairing of sweet Riesling with Lotus of Siam's spicy Thai cuisine), and they have a large selection of small-production, rare wines that are often only marked up 20%.  In fact, I've found many bottles on the list that are more expensive at the winery itself.  

In conclusion, whether you think it's ignorant to claim that Lotus of Siam is the best in the country, you should definitely come to eat here because it's a very unique restaurant, and you will have a great experience.  
ALL TOURISTS READ HERE:  Don't stay on the strip and overpay for average food.  Las Vegas is so much more than the strip, and Lotus of Siam is one of the best examples of why the best restaurants in Las Vegas are off the strip!  All you have to do is take a cab less than a mile off the strip and you will enjoy some of the best Thai food you will ever have!

Is it the best thai restaurant in the US?   Hmm... it definitely is one of the most expensive BUT for that price, you can taste that it is a notch above all the other thai restaurants.   We had something like Mi krop with sour sausages (one of their top 3 most popular), sea bass on top of drunken noodles (also another top 3 most popular), minced jackfruit with pork (something different since you don't usually see that) and sticky rice with mango.   Now.... the thing is that I've had almost all these dishes at other thai restaurants.  Each one of the dishes were slightly better (more sour, more greens, better quality fish, better cooking technique, in season fruits, garnishes you can eat, no fillers)  than at my favorite places in Thaitown in Hollywood, CA.     The owner here.... tons of people waiting and the bums in the parking lot asking for money.   Would I recommend a visit....   definitely -- only a few places in the US that you can eat at a James Beard award winner that is reasonable in price.

Just completed my annual getaway to Las Vegas, which always includes a pilgrimage to the dirty strip mall off Sahara for dinner at Lotus of Siam. It still reigns as the best Thai food I've ever eaten. They've renovated and expanded the dining space in the last year, and it looks much nicer. The decor is finally being elevated a little closer to the high quality of the food. Surprisingly, I didn't think my meal was as exceptional as my last visit in September 2009. It was still super yummy, but didn't have the same wow factor. Is it the remodel? Larger dining room? Or have I put Lotus of Siam so high on a pedestal from my last experience, it will never be as insanely satisfying as my first dinner there? Wine flights are no longer offered either.

Just got back from lunch here. From the reviews, I was expecting Lotus to blow my mind - and it didn't. 
Don't judge this place by it's cover - the outside looks pretty ghetto - the inside is MUCH better.

After reading through some reviews, we ended up ordering:
1)Tom Kah Kai - A distinctive soup of sliced chicken with coconut milk, straw mushroom galanga, lemon grass and a touch of lime juice. $4.95 for a cup - it was good, not the BEST I've had, but pretty comparable to other Thai restaurants. 
2)Nam Kao Tod -Crispy rice mixed with minced sour sausage, green onion, fresh chili, ginger, peanuts, and lime juice. - $7.95 : this had a lot of flavor, actually TOO much flavor. It was pretty salty. The first few bites were really good, after that, the flavor kicked in and it was hard to eat. Unique dish though, never had it before.
3) Drunken Noodles with Crispy Duck - Crispy duck topped with homemade fresh chili and Thai basil. Serve on the top of pan fried flat rice noodle. - $21.95 : this dish was GOOD, it could have used more noodles though - they gave us enough for one person, hardly enough for 2 people to share. Most people want more meat - and here we wanted more noodles, they gave us a good amount of crispy duck though. The flavors blended together perfectly. Would def. recommend this dish. 
4) Thai Iced tea - $2.50 each : the tea taste was stronger than any other Thai tea I've had - so if you're really into tea - that's a good thing. I'm not into that strong taste so I handed it over to my bf.

Dinner came out to be $42 exactly before tip. So if you get these dishes, expect to spend about $50. and that's with no dessert. =(

The best Thai restaurant in North America? I have to disagree. It's ok, but definitely not the best. I guess that's what happens when places are hyped - you expect too much. If you come here not expecting much, maybe it will live up to the hype. Sorry ya'll.

Let me preface this by saying that I just got off a plane and was starving and my friends had been rock climbing all day and probably would have thought a Slim Jim was the best thing they ever tasted.

When you arrive, you will think you are in the wrong place.  It's in a crazy seedy strip mall and at night I had trouble picking this restaurant out of the string of strange establishments.  It was so dark that I thought they were closed (none of the strip mall's neon lights were on), but then I saw an open sign.

Inside it is nicer.  Huge wine selection.  On the menu there is an entree specialty section priced in the +$20 range, but the standard menu has lots of options under $10.  My 3 friends and I got 4 entrees and two beers for under $50.

I may get crap for it, but I always order pad thai as a backup when at a new thai restaurant because it's usually edible, even if the other stuff you order is not.  Everything we ordered (cashew nut chicken, lemon pepper pork, yellow curry, pad thai) was great, but I was surprised that the pad thai was phenomenal. 

The guys in the group were scraping every last peppercorn off the dish.  I had to practically stop them from licking the plates!

Even if we were biased by hunger, I have had marginal thai food before.  This place was fantastic and I would definitely go back.

Look,

I couldn't tell you what our party of 8 ordered, per the menu, but I can tell you what we ate. The wantons, the sea bass (which seems to be a perpetual special). We were directed to a tasting menu, with some dishes served ala carte to our respective setting,  and some served family style. Everything was a taste amusement park, from the spicy to the sweet, every note was played out over the course of the meal. Sensational when you sit down expecting a quartet and a symphony shows up. There's no need to do a ton of research here, if you're an expert of this region of Thailand's cuisine,  you'll know what to try. If you're a novice, I mean even a COMPLETE novice, have no fear the excellent staff reads the customer well. It's pretty tough to be disjointed, everything is just in a very base way, delectable. 

The restaurant has updated its look smartly since I first tried it during the "I just discovered this amazing place" days. 

Special.

Get a reservation well in advance, this is one of the hottest tickets in Las Vegas.

Lotus rocks!  My cousin told me of the secret  stripmall Thai tastiness about 5 years ago.  Crispy Duck on alkie noodles!  Order something different!  Spicy flavors... I did order the catfish once, super delicious but came witha 35 dollar price tag. Lobster was cheaper! ? The Idian place nextdoor  is a must taste too!

Loved the food especially #58- marinated sirloin strips and the garlic prawns were r favorite. The staff was also very friendly and helpful in our selections. All our young children enjoyed as well: BBQ chicken and fried rice!

My latest visit to Lotus of Siam was again a success!  Almost every time I come here, someone I am with wants to order something that I know will not be good.  I usually just smile and say, "Sure, let's try it".  I don't want to force my friends to order only what i like, which is why I nod my head and smile, but these dishes remind me each time of why it is so important to order correctly here.  The bad dish this time was the fried dumplings.  Very bland, stuffed with a very small amount of meat, and very average.  

Luckily, they served the Beef Jerky and the dumplings at the same time, so my friend was able to see why i like this place so much.  We got the Beef Jerky, Northern Style Pork Curry, Issan Sausage, Seafood with Drunken Noodle, and Coconut Ice Cream w/ Fried Banana Roll.  Everything was very good.  The sausage was very dry, but had a great fermented flavor, and when combined with the cabbage, fresh chiles, roasted peanuts, ginger, and cilantro, it covers the palate with different flavors that work together perfectly.  

The coconut ice cream was worth writing home about too!  Icy, refreshing, and full of fresh coconut flavor, this was the best way to end the meal since the Sticky rice w/ mango was not available as the mangoes were not in season.  

Once again, Lotus of Siam comes through!

My wife and I dined here on Sunday evening 10/24/10 and enjoyed a wonderful,authentic Thai dinner that included many highlights and some truly amazing dishes with very few misses.

The restaurant itself is located in and aged strip mall off of The Strip on Sahara Ave. and the decor is dated and worn with walls lined by photos of noted past diners including Drew Barrymore, Mario Batali, etc.. I can't decide if this added to or detracted from the ambiance but it's nice to see this chef and cuisine gettings it's rightful due notoriety.

The food at Lotus of Siam is the star and I was by most accounts dazzled. The menu itself is dizzying large with so many different dishes that's it's overwhelming so if you're unsure of what to order then rely on your server to help navigate this menu as they will happily make recommendations that are on point. All dishes are prepared at your requested spice level from 1-10 so be specific. My wife choose a mild level #2 while I opted for a Spicy level #7. This also worked well when moving back and forth between dishes from mild to spicy and back again.

Our Food:

Appetizers:

Chicken Satay (Spice level #2) - Simple but beautifully balanced with a sweet peanut sauce and a cool crisp pickled cucumber salad.

Nam Kao Tod (Crispy Rice w/ minced, sour sausage, peanuts, ginger, green onions, fresh chilies & lime juice & ) (Spice level # 7) - The crispy & crunchy texture is wonderful but this dish definitely takes a little getting used to. My first reaction was "This is really dry", but when combined with the sliced cucumber and fresh cabbage garnishes it was balanced and addictive.

Entrees: (served w/ steamed white rice)

Charbroiled Prawns w/ Spicy & Tamarind Sauce (Spice level # 2) - This was a simple, perfect shellfish presentation with butterflied prawns still in their shells, simply charbroiled and served with two contrasting sauces of spicy vs. sweet & sour.

Thum-Ka-Noon (Pounded Young Jackfruit Shredded)
(Spice level # 7) - This Northern Thai dish was hands down my favorite of the night by far. Shredded jackfruit, ground, sour pork & spicy tomato sauce & herbs. This was so focused and satisfying. Wow!

Koi Soy (Issan Beef Tartare) (Spice level # 7) - I wanted to love this dish but I really was disappointed. The cubed, raw beef was fresh and clearly of good quality with a nice texture provided by the rice powder but I was so overwhelmed with the flavor of lime juice that I couldn't even decipher the actual primary taste of Beef Tartare.

Dessert:

Fresh Mango w/ Sticky Rice & Coconut Ice Cream - 
The mango & sticky rice themselves were awesome. I love the savoriness of this dessert combination however I was not so much a fan of the coconut ice cream as I found the texture icy and the flavor lacking any distinct natural coconut profile. I asked our server if it was made in-house and he stated they bring it in from California. It did provide some welcome temperature contrast to the cool, tart mango and the sweet, warm sticky rice but otherwise it was completely forgettable. 

It's worth drawing attention to the exemplary service here as it truly is by any measure fantastic. The front of the house staff were very welcoming, attentive and provided many good menu suggestions. Our water & drink glasses were never even half empty and plates arrived and were cleared at perfect intervals.

I'd love to return again and try many more dishes along with the hope of finding more magnificent Thai treasures. If your truly love Thai food then you must try Lotus of Siam atleast once if not ten times. 
It really deserves your attention.

Never would think of coming in from the looks on the outside, but jus goes to show you to not judge a book by it's cover. The inside is nicely decorated with even a wine bar . Food did not disappoint. My favorites: garlic prawns and #58 marinated steak on bed of cabbage.

No the best I've had else where in the country, but very very good. 

Huge menu, pages long, WOW 

Prices were very very good, especially for Vegas. 

I would go here again and recommend. 

Great Thai experience. Our server Mike was great. 

Don't let the outside fool you, it's nice and authenticate on the inside.

Northern Thai dishes are excellent.  Mushroom dip with steamed veggies, young jackfruit curry and pad see ew were great.  I also tried a northern Thai sausage, which was very interesting and tasty.  Note, spice level 8/10 was indeed eye watering.

Not the best thai food i've ever had but pretty dang close.  

Living in vegas i'm selfishly glad this place isn't in the middle of the strip.

Awesome $8.99 buffet for lunch.  Incredible bargain.

Very good service and the price tag pushes it up to a 4 star in my book.

They did a great job on the needed expansion completed not too long ago.  Note if you're there there are now restrooms in the back of each room.

Off the strip, hidden in a seedy plaza, is one of the greatest hole in the wall restaurants you will ever stumble upon. Lotus of Siam is tucked away in a sketchy area, but the restaurant was just renovated and its actually nice inside (not fancy, but nicer than the standard hole in the wall asian restaurants).
